We operate a long-term hedging policy with a five-year hedging period to manage the risk of a change in the relative values of the US dollar, Canadian dollar or euros relative to the pound sterling, which may increase our suppliers’ cost of business and ultimately our cost of goods sold with respect to biomass. 9 ----- _Increased control over fuel input costs via an integrated biomass supply chain_ Our wood pellet manufacturing facilities have a combined annual nameplate capacity of 1,475,000 tonnes, comprising capacity of 512,500 tonnes at each of our Amite and Morehouse facilities and 450,000 tonnes of capacity at our LaSalle facility, and have operated at or near nameplate capacity in the six months to 30 June 2020. Our US port facility in Baton Rouge, Louisiana has an annual export capacity of 2,100,000 tonnes (with the scope to expand further to 3,000,000 tonnes), which exceeds our current self-supply, enabling us to consolidate supply from third parties to drive further supply chain efficiencies until we are able to increase our selfsupply of biomass in the coming years. Our current US operations are strategically located near one another for operational efficiencies, including optimising the time and cost of wood pellet deliveries to our Baton Rouge port facility. In the first half of 2020, our wood pellet manufacturing facilities produced approximately 753,000 tonnes of wood pellets and our US port facility shipped 747,000 tonnes of wood pellets to Drax Power Station. In 2019, wood pellets manufactured at our own facilities accounted for 22 per cent. of the biomass used at Drax Power Station with the balance sourced from third party suppliers based in North America and Europe under a series of predominantly long-term contracts from sources also certified as sustainable. We aim to increase the amount of pellets we self-supply up to 5,000,000 tonnes per annum by 2027 (71 per cent. of our internal requirement for the year ended 31 December 2019). In furtherance of this aim, we are in the process of increasing capacity at our LaSalle, Amite and Morehouse facilities by 350,000 tonnes in aggregate over the next two years. In addition, over the same time period we expect to complete construction of three new satellite pellet plants, with nameplate capacity of 120,000 tonnes per year and the potential to increase this to 500,000 tonnes. We expect that the production costs at these plants will be approximately 20 per cent. lower than our existing plants. Our ability to source an increasing proportion of our biomass requirements internally via self-supply allows us to better manage the quality of feedstock and the timing of deliveries. This allows us to drive down the cost of biomass, but also enables us to optimise generation and reduce the risk of fuel shortages and supply chain issues curtailing generation from Drax Power Station. Further to this, it allows us to better ensure a stable cost of biomass and reduce exposure to commodity price fluctuations. At the same time, we maintain the flexibility to participate in the biomass spot market when prices are attractive. To date there has been no material impact from Covid-19 on our biomass supply chain or those of our key biomass suppliers, nor has there been any material disruption due to Covid-19 to the shipping of our biomass by sea freight, port or rail.

Subsubsection Title: Strong financial metrics and conservative financial policies.
Subsubsection Text: Our balance sheet, liquidity and financial policy are strong. These have been maintained since we listed on the London Stock Exchange in December 2005, and is evidenced by our strong credit ratings from S&P, Fitch and DBRS. In recent years, as the Group has diversified and substantially grown, we have also reduced our business risk profile. Any temporary increase in leverage resulting from our corporate acquisitions have been followed by rapid deleveraging back to pre-acquisition levels. Our reported net leverage at the end of the last four calendar years has been between 0.7x and 1.8x. After the completion of the Opus Acquisition in February 2017, our consolidated pro forma net leverage as at 31 December 2016 only increased to 2.7x and decreased to 1.6x by the end of the calendar year; after the completion of the DGEL Acquisition in December 2018, our consolidated pro forma net leverage as at 31 December 2018 was 3.1x and decreased to 1.9x by 31 December 2019 and further decreased to 1.8x by 30 June 2020. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations— Significant Factors affecting Results of Operations”_ for a discussion of factors affecting comparability of information for the six months ended 30 June 2020 and 2019 and the years ended 31 December 2019 and 2018. We are committed to maintaining leverage at a level that is consistent with our current crossover credit rating, which supports our trading strategy. See “Presentation of Financial Information and Other Information— Non_IFRS Financial Measures”. We have a disciplined focus on cash flow and working capital management and have not utilised our cash revolving credit facilities for over two years. We have a strong cash conversion profile with an average annual operating cash conversion for the last four calendar years of approximately 125 per cent., reflecting ongoing low maintenance capital expenditure requirements combined with financial discipline. We announced our current dividend policy in June 2017, and this will pay a sustainable and growing dividend consistent with our commitment to a strong balance sheet and our ambitions for growth. 10 ----- We are focused on targeted selective investments which will help us continue diversifying our earnings and cash flow sources. We also expect our future maintenance capital expenditures to include investments to upgrade our facilities to, among other things, comply with applicable regulatory regimes, which we then expect to translate into greater operating cash flow going forward. Further, future investments to increase our biomass selfsupply capacity have been approved and will commence in the second half of 2020 in respect of three satellite plants. All decisions on investments and capital allocation are made in line with a prudent capital allocation policy. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Capital and _Operating Expenditure”._ We have robust credit policies in place to limit the amount of concentration risk we have with any counterparty (noting that the counterparty’s appetite to trade with us is itself based on its assessment of our credit profile). Sales to the Customers segment (as opposed to third parties) further reduce our concentration risk by spreading the Generation segment’s exposure to third-party credit risk across a wider customer base.

Subsubsection Title: Our proven management team has led our business through an evolving regulatory and commodity market environment.
Subsubsection Text: We and our management team have proven experience in leading our business through an evolving regulatory environment, having delivered Europe’s largest decarbonization programme. Management is supported by a skilled operating team who are at the forefront of biomass conversion technology, including the mechanical, engineering, electrical and civil works required for such conversion. Through the conversion of four coal units to biomass at Drax Power Station, acquisitions and organic growth we have successfully transformed a coal generation business into a vertically-integrated generator focused on flexible, low-carbon and renewable electricity. As a result of this transformation, we are an industry-leader in energy generation from biomass and its associated supply chain. We have also gained significant experience in integrating businesses into our existing operations, in particular following our acquisition of Opus on 17 February 2017 and the DGEL Assets on 31 December 2018. The conversion of the first three of our generation units to biomass remains Europe’s largest decarbonisation project, and was delivered on time and within budget. This experience enabled us to deliver the low-cost conversion of a fourth biomass-fired generation unit in August 2018 and positions us to continue to deliver significant biomass cost-savings and growth projects, as well as providing Drax with the ability to adapt to an evolving energy market and deliver on our pipeline of development projects. Our operational experience in handling biomass is also market-leading. We have developed innovative fuel handling systems, logistics and storage solutions for biomass fuel as well as a bespoke, technically-advanced covered rail wagon with a specialised door design and a patented product flow control system to manage biomass during discharge. Further, we have developed an in-depth understanding of the scientific and technological effects of burning a range of biomass fuels, as well as of the critical combustion characteristics of such fuels. This positions us to identify and utilize new fuels (such as sugar cane and bagasse) at a reduced cost to the wood pellets we currently procure from third parties. Sustainability is at the heart of our culture and the sustainable sourcing of biomass is a core principle of the Group. We aim to lead in this area and, in 2017 we appointed a Senior Independent Non-Executive Director with expertise in sustainability. In 2019, we introduced a new Responsible Sourcing Policy for Biomass, which reflects the evolving science in the area and is based on recommendations by Forest Research and the European Climate Foundation, and which exceeds the requirements of the EU Renewable Energy Directive II. We also established an Independent Advisory Board chaired by Sir John Beddington, the UK’s former Chief Scientific Adviser, and including members of Forest Research. The IAB provides independent advice on the role of biomass in climate change mitigation and in supporting the transition to a net zero energy system, forest science and optimising carbon impacts, and societal expectations for responsible and sustainable biomass. The Independent Advisory  Board  has  reviewed  our  biomass  policy  and  confirmed  that  it  reflects  the recommendations made by Forest Research. We seek to source biomass from countries with large areas of growing forests and established forest industries and we comprehensively audit our carbon footprint across our entire biomass supply chain, conduct regular ISAE 3000 assured independent supplier audits and encourage the use of third party sustainability certification. All our biomass is procured in accordance with our Responsible Sourcing Policy for Biomass. 11 -----

Subsubsection Title: Create a long-term future for sustainable biomass.
Subsubsection Text: The cost of biomass fuel is a key metric in determining the profitability of our biomass generation and our overall financial performance. We have a target to substantially reduce this cost by 2027 through increasing our self-supply of sustainable wood pellets, increasing our operational efficiency and developing a wider fuel envelope. In doing so, we expect to develop a long-term future for sustainable biomass. Our wood pellet manufacturing facilities in the US currently supply all of their output to Drax Power Station and supplied 1,535,000 tonnes (22 per cent.) of our internal requirements for generation from sustainable biomass in 2019. Our target is to increase this self-supply capability to 5,000,000 (71 per cent. of our internal requirement for the year ended 31 December 2019) by 2027, and in doing so become the world’s largest low-cost biomass producer and improve the certainty of self-supply, allowing us to take advantage of economies of scale and making us less susceptible to changes in the wholesale price of biomass. In furtherance of this target, we are increasing capacity at our LaSalle, Amite and Morehouse facilities by 350,000 tonnes in aggregate over the next two years (construction has started at LaSalle and Morehouse, and is expected to begin at Amite in 2021). Our current wood pellet manufacturing facilities are strategically located close to one another in the US Gulf region for operational and supply chain efficiencies. We intend to continue consolidating supply from third parties at our Baton Rouge port facility to utilise unused export capacity and to drive further supply chain efficiencies. Progress in the first half of 2020 included the approval of three new 40kt satellite plants at a cost of approximately $40 million in aggregate ($10-15 million per site). Construction work on the first plant is set to begin this year, which will utilise sawmill residues and share our existing US Gulf infrastructure to produce, we believe, biomass at around 20 per cent. below the current cost of production. Separately, we are undertaking a number of operational, technical and logistical initiatives across our biomass supply chain to further reduce the cost of biomass. This includes increasing the proportion of good quality wood pellets received at Drax Power Station, turbine upgrades and process modifications to improve combustion at Drax Power Station and improving our logistics. For example, in May 2019, we commissioned a new rail spur linking our LaSalle facility to the regional rail network and our port facility at Baton Rouge, which will increase transportation efficiency and economies of scale and reduce the cost and carbon footprint of our operations. Together with the Port of Baton Rouge and the State of Louisiana, we are also commissioning an enlarged chambering yard at our port facilities in Baton Rouge, allowing 80-car train sets to operate from our LaSalle and Morehouse sites. Following the success of the co-location of a sawmill next to our LaSalle facility, which became operational in January 2020, we are looking at identifying additional opportunities to locate sawmills near to our pellet facilities, in order to increase operational efficiency, secure low-cost fibre residues and ultimately to reduce the cost of biomass production. This programme of improvements is expected to deliver savings of $27 million per year by the end of 2020 and $64 million per year by the end of 2022. In addition to the above, we aim to leverage our knowledge of fuel chemistry obtained from our sustainable biomass generation to widen the sustainable biomass fuel options which we are able to use at Drax Power Station. We have set up a dedicated team tasked with identifying new fuels (such as sugarcane bagasse, woodchips and nutshells), forms and geographies which we could utilise at a reduced cost to the pellets we currently procure from third parties.

Subsubsection Title: Delivering on our ambition to become a carbon negative company by 2030 through BECCS.
Subsubsection Text: Delivering on BECCS will also leave us well placed to fulfil our longer-term ambition of becoming a carbon negative group by 2030. To deliver on this carbon negative ambition we are developing a range of engineering options and working with a range of technology and industrial partners to apply BECCS technology to the biomass units at Drax Power Station. This technology will safely capture the vast majority of the carbon dioxide emitted in the biomass generation process and transports it via pipelines to storage sites under the North Sea. Our BECCS ambition aligns with the Government’s target to achieve net zero emissions across the UK economy by 2050 and the advice of its statutory advisory body, the CCC, which highlights that BECCS is both a critical part of the solution to achieve net zero whilst also being part of an evolving, stable and flexible generation mix. Each biomass unit utilising BECCS technology could capture approximately 4,000,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide per annum. Working in partnership with a range of stakeholders, and with the right support from Government, we believe we are well placed to develop BECCS at scale in advance of 2030 and, in all, could provide up to a third of the negative emissions that the CCC has identified that the UK may require. 12 ----- We also expect global demand for wood pellets to increase this decade as other countries develop decarbonisation programmes which acknowledge the benefits of sustainable biomass for generation. Whilst there is an abundance of sustainable biomass globally, there remains limited capacity to convert these fibres to energy dense pellets, which have a low-carbon footprint and lower cost associated with transportation. As a result, we expect the global market for biomass to remain structurally short. We are therefore exploring options to service biomass demand in other markets, such as Europe, North America and Asia alongside the UK. In doing so, we are creating optionality over our use of sustainable biomass. The technology to deliver post-combustion BECCS exists and is proven at scale. We recently commenced a trial of one such technology provided by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries at the technology testing zone at Drax Power Station. This solvent technology is well established and is being used at 13 sites globally, notably at the Petra Nova facility in Texas, USA, the world’s largest post-combustion carbon capture plant, which is capable of capturing 1,400,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide a year. We are piloting the carbon capture potential of an organic and potentially lower cost alternative solvent treatment developed by C-Capture Limited, and we expect to carry out further trials in 2021. This technology is also being piloted at the Tiller facility in Norway. We are also exploring the viability of alternative uses for CO2 including trials to assess use of biogenic CO2 in plastic and animal food use, and the development of synthetic zero-carbon fuels from hydrogen. Subject to the right support from the Government, we stand ready to develop and deliver this critical contribution to the UK achieving net zero emissions by 2050, which will also help us to achieve our ambition of becoming a carbon negative company by 2030.

Subsubsection Title: Be the leading provider of system support in the UK.
Subsubsection Text: Historically, the vast majority of the Group’s earnings were derived from the operation of Drax Power Station as a merchant plant, selling wholesale power independently to third parties. Accordingly, the Group’s earnings were volatile and exposed to commodity price and/or merchant risk. In recent years, our earnings have diversified and the Group’s exposure to commodity price risk has been substantially reduced. In the Generation segment, we maintain our visibility of future earnings and cash flows through the contracted earnings of Capacity Market and System Support Services payments. We expect that, combined with the support we receive under the CfD Regime and RO Scheme for our biomass and hydro generation assets, this will continue to result in a reduced level of commodity markets exposure and increased stability and visibility of earnings. We have secured index-linked Capacity Market agreements for certain of our pumped storage, hydro and CCGT assets, which are expected to result in contract-based revenues in excess of £209.4 million in aggregate between January 2019 and 30 September 2024. We have similar agreements for our two coal-fired generation units until 30 September 2022 and the three small ancillary gas turbines located at Drax Power Station until 30 September 2024, which are expected to result in contract-based revenues of approximately £84.3 million between January 2019 and 30 September 2024 in aggregate. Looking forward, any final investment decision in respect of any one of our pipeline of development options will be subject to appropriate support to deliver stable contract-based revenues in line with our capital allocation policy whilst maintaining a conservative net leverage profile. With increasing levels of intermittent generation on the UK electricity system, we are continuing to identify opportunities to flexibly operate our generation assets according to prevailing market conditions, such as the provision of short-term power and balancing market activity and the provision of other System Support Services. The flexible, dispatchable and responsive nature of our generation assets positions us to compete in the market over the short and medium term and our pipeline of development projects will, if developed, further bolster our offering in this regard. With the changing grid dynamic, we expect the market for System Support Services to grow. As the UK’s electricity market evolves, the types and tenor of System Support Services being procured by the System Operator is changing. For example, in January 2020, one of the Cruachan pumped storage hydro station’s four turbines secured a six-year contract to provide System Support Services to the UK electricity system, which commenced in July 2020 and is expected to result in contract-based revenues of approximately £29 million between 1 April 2020 and 31 March 2026 in aggregate. In addition, our Drax Power Station and Damhead Creek assets both provide foot room reserve services. It is our intention to offer further assets to tender for similar 13 ----- System Support Services in the future and we will continue to position the business so that it is able to meet the requirements of an increasingly complex UK electricity system.

Subsubsection Title: Develop our Customers segment by giving customers control of their energy.
Subsubsection Text: The Customers segment has a differentiated market position—selling purely renewable power while helping over 2,000 independent renewable generators, access the market. In the same way that the Generation segment provides system support, so too can our industrial customer portfolio. Over time, we expect this business, through efficiency and demand-side response, to contribute increasingly to system support. We continue to believe this approach will support long-term growth. Our Customers segment was the fifth largest supplier of electricity to businesses in the UK by volume supplied as of 30 April 2020, was the largest provider of renewable energy to businesses and the UK leading business to business only supplier. As at 30 April 2020, we supplied 281,500 electricity and gas meters and, in the six months ended 30 June 2020, we supplied 8.8TWh of electricity and gas and our fuel mix disclosure for the period April 2019 to March 2020 100 per cent of our electricity was from renewable generation. As at 30 April 2020, our share of the B2B electricity market was 8 per cent.. As the power system decarbonises, we believe that there is a significant opportunity for the Group to leverage our status as a vertically integrated utility with a diverse range of assets to provide an evolving range of innovative and flexible solutions to business customers enabling them to manage their energy demand and requirements, which will drive market share growth and increased profitability in the Customers segment. In the first half of 2020, the Customers segment reported a loss. This reflects the significant reduction in demand caused by Covid-19, the cost associated with exiting hedged positions as market prices have fallen and the increased risk and provisioning for business failure and bad debt—principally in the SME market, which represents 30 per cent. of monthly billing. The combined revenues for Opus Energy Limited and Opus Gas Supply Limited, which supply SME customers, were £626.8 million in 2019, 27 per cent. of our £2.35 billion total revenues in the Customers business. We estimate that there is approximately £100 million of SME revenue within the Haven Power Limited revenues in 2019, which would increase this to 31 per cent. However, even with social distancing measures eased we expect the impact of Covid-19 to continue in the second half of 2020 and 2021. Despite the Covid-19 pandemic, the I&C business performed better and has added long dated contracts with water utilities to the portfolio, providing revenue visibility over the next five years. Looking beyond the impact of Covid-19 we will continue to monitor the portfolio to ensure alignment with the Group’s strategy. The Customers business has a differentiated market position—selling purely renewable power while helping over 2,000 independent renewable generators, access the market. In the same way that the Generation business provides system support, so too can our industrial customer portfolio. Over time, we expect this business, through efficiency and demand-side response, to contribute increasingly to system support. We continue to believe this approach will support long-term growth. 14 -----

The following diagram sets forth a simplified summary of our corporate and financing structure after having given effect to the Offering. The diagram does not include each member of the Group or all of the debt obligations thereof. Drax Group plc £350m Senior Secured Fixed Rate Notes due 2022 and Senior Facilities: $500m Senior Secured Fixed Drax Group Holdings £160m Private Placement Rate Notes due 2025 Limited £375m Private Placement £125m ESG Term Loan £350m Revolving Credit Notes offered Proceeds Loans Drax Corporate Facility Drax Finco plc hereby Limited Non-Guarantor Drax Smart Generation Drax Smart Supply Drax Research and Drax Smart Sourcing Restricted HoldCo Limited HoldCo Limited Innovation HoldCo HoldCo Limited Subsidiaries Limited Drax Power Limited Drax Biomass Inc. Opus Energy Group (USA) Other Guarantor Limited Secured hedging obligations Other Guarantors Non-Guarantor Restricted Subsidiaries Restricted Subsidiaries Key Restricted Subsidiaries Restricted Group Non-Guarantor Restricted Subsidiary Guarantor (1) The Issuer of the Notes will be Drax Finco plc, a public limited company incorporated in England and Wales on 10 March 2017, a direct wholly-owned subsidiary of DGHL, which is in turn a direct wholly-owned subsidiary of Drax Group plc. As at 31 December 2019, the share capital of the Issuer comprised 30,050,000 ordinary shares of £1.00 each, all of which were fully paid. The Issuer is a finance company that conducts no business operations of its own and its only material assets and liabilities as of the Issue Date are expected to be its rights and claims under various intercompany financings (including under the New Proceeds Loan and the Existing Proceeds Loans) and its outstanding indebtedness (including its obligations under the Notes, the 2022 Notes, the 2025 Notes and its guarantees in respect of the Senior Facilities Agreement, the Private Placement Agreement, the ESG Facility Agreement, the Term Facilities Agreement and certain hedging obligations). (2) The Notes will be senior secured obligations of the Issuer and will rank pari passu in right of payment with all of the Issuer’s existing and future obligations. The Notes will be guaranteed on a senior secured basis (the “Guarantees” and each, a “Guarantee”) by DGHL and each of (i) Drax Power Limited (“Drax Power”), Drax Corporate Limited, Drax Group Holdings Limited, Drax Smart Generation Holdco Limited, Drax Fuel Supply Limited, Drax Smart Supply Holdco Limited, Haven Power Limited, Haven Heat Limited, Drax Retail Developments Limited, Opus Energy Group Limited, Opus Energy Limited, Opus Energy (Corporate) Limited, Opus Gas Supply Limited, Opus Energy Renewables Limited, Farmoor Energy Limited, Donnington Energy Limited, Drax Research and Innovation Holdco Limited, Drax Corporate Developments Limited, Drax Smart Sourcing Holdco Limited and Drax Innovation Limited, each of which is a direct or indirect wholly-owned subsidiary of the DGHL incorporated under the laws of England and Wales; (ii) Drax Biomass Transit LLC, Morehouse BioEnergy LLC, Drax Biomass International Holdings LLC, Drax Biomass Holdings LLC, Drax Biomass Inc., Baton Rouge Transit LLC, DBI O&M Company LLC, Amite BioEnergy LLC, Tyler BioEnergy LLC, Jefferson Transit LLC and LaSalle BioEnergy LLC, each of which is a direct or indirect wholly-owned subsidiary of DGHL organised under the laws of State of Delaware; and (iii) DGEL, an indirect wholly-owned subsidiary of DGHL, incorporated under the laws of Scotland (the “Subsidiary Guarantors”, and together with DGHL, the “Guarantors”). Each Subsidiary Guarantor is a Restricted Subsidiary and is subject to the restrictive covenants under the Indenture. The Guarantees are subject to certain contractual and legal limitations, and may be released under certain circumstances. Please see “Description of Notes—Note Guarantees—Release of Notes Guarantees”, “Risk Factors—Risks Related to _the Notes, the Guarantees and Our Capital Structure—Each Guarantee and security interest is subject to certain limitations on enforcement and may be limited by applicable law or subject to certain defences that may limit its validity and enforceability”, and_ “Certain Insolvency Considerations and Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and Security”. For the twelve months ended 30 June 2020, the Guarantors generated £442.1 million of the DGHL Group’s Adjusted EBITDA (excluding the impact of IFRS 16), representing 99.2 per cent. of the DGHL Group’s Adjusted EBITDA (excluding the impact of IFRS 16). As of 30 June 2020, the total assets of the Guarantors were £4,379.1 million (excluding intra-Group assets, goodwill and the impact of IFRS 16), representing 98.8 per cent. of the Group’s total assets DGHL (excluding intra-Group assets, goodwill and the impact of IFRS 16). As of 30 June 2020, after giving pro forma effect to the Offering, as if it had occurred on that date, DGHL and its 15 ----- Restricted Subsidiaries would have had £1,520.6 million of borrowings outstanding, of which £226.7 million (equivalent) is represented by the Notes (being the pound sterling equivalent of €250.0 million, converted at a rate of €1.1027 to £1.00, which was the market rate on 30 June 2020, sourced from Reuters, used for the preparation of the balance sheet contained in the 2020 Drax Group Unaudited Financial Statements), £350.0 million is represented by the 2022 Notes, £405.8 million (equivalent) represented by the 2025 Notes (being the pound sterling equivalent of $500.0 million, converted at a rate of $1.2380 to £1.00, which was the market rate on 30 June 2020, sourced from Reuters, used for the preparation of the balance sheet contained in the 2020 Drax Group Unaudited Financial Statements), £38.1 million represented by the Senior Facilities Agreement (which provides for committed loans of up to £350 million), £125.0 million represented by the ESG Facility Agreement (which was fully drawn), £375.0 million represented by the Private Placement Agreement (which was fully drawn), as well as £nil represented by the Term Facilities Agreement (which provides for committed loans of up to £126.5 million and £45.0 million). As of 30 June 2020, after giving pro forma effect to the Offering, as if it had occurred on that date, the Restricted Subsidiaries of DGHL that will not guarantee the Notes would have had no outstanding third- party Indebtedness. The Guarantees of the Guarantors may be released as set forth under “Note Guarantees—Release of Note Guarantees”. On 30 June 2020, DGHL and its Restricted Subsidiaries had £1,273.9 million of borrowings outstanding. On the Issue Date, the Notes and the Guarantees will (subject to the Agreed Security Principles) be, secured by first-priority security interests in the Collateral, as set out under “Description of Notes—Security”. (3) Certain Restricted Subsidiaries are subject to the restrictive covenants under the Indenture, but will not guarantee the Notes or provide any security in respect of the Notes. As of 30 June 2020, such non-guarantor subsidiaries had no outstanding third party indebtedness. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, all of DGHL’s subsidiaries will be “Restricted Subsidiaries” for purposes of the Indenture, except that Abbott Debt Recovery Limited, Opus Energy Marketing Limited and Opus Water Limited (which represent less than 0.1 per cent. of the DGHL Group’s Adjusted EBITDA (excluding the impact of IFRS 16) and total assets (excluding intra-Group assets, goodwill and the impact of IFRS 16) will be “Unrestricted Subsidiaries” for purposes of the Indenture. (4) On 21 April 2017, the Issuer issued £350 million aggregate principal amount of 4 [1]⁄4% senior secured fixed notes due 2022 (the “2022 Notes”). The 2022 Notes were issued pursuant to an indenture dated as of 5 May 2017 (as amended and restated from time to time, the “2022 Indenture”). The 2022 Notes are guaranteed on a senior secured basis by the Guarantors and are secured by the same Collateral as the Notes. We intend to repay the 2022 Notes in full before 31 December 2020. See “Use of Proceeds”. (5) On 26 April 2018, the Issuer issued $300 million aggregate amount of 6 [5]⁄8% Senior Secured Notes due 2025, and on 16 May 2019, the Issuer issued a further $200 million aggregate amount of 6 [5]⁄8% Senior Secured Notes due 2025 (the “2025 Notes”). The 2025 Notes were issued pursuant to an indenture dated 26 April 2019, as supplemented by supplemental indentures dated 12 February 2019 and 16 May 2019 (the “2025 Indenture”). The 2025 Notes are guaranteed on a senior secured basis by the Guarantors and are secured by the same Collateral as the Notes. (6) On 21 April 2017, with effect from 5 May 2017, we amended and restated a revolving credit facility agreement originally entered into on 20 December 2012, as amended and restated on 8 December 2015, between, among others, Drax Power, Barclays Bank PLC as facility agent and Drax Corporate Limited and its subsidiaries as guarantors, pursuant to an amendment and restatement agreement (the “Senior

Subsection Title: Facilities Agreement”). The Senior Facilities Agreement comprises a £315 million committed multicurrency revolving credit facility and
Subsubsection Text: a drawn £35 million term facility (the “Senior Facilities”). The original borrower under the Senior Facilities Agreement is Drax Corporate Limited. The Senior Facilities are guaranteed on a senior secured basis by the Guarantors (other than Drax Corporate Limited) and the Issuer and are secured by the same Collateral that secures the ESG Facility, the Private Placement Facilities, the 2022 Notes, 2025 Notes and the Term Facilities and that will secure the Notes. In the event of enforcement or certain distressed disposals, any liabilities in respect of obligations under the Senior Facilities and certain hedging obligations and liabilities to lenders or creditors under certain other indebtedness permitted to be incurred under the Indentures (subject to the Intercreditor Agreement) and then outstanding will receive priority in relation to any proceeds received from the Collateral. We are currently contemplating a potential amendment and restatement of the Senior Facilities Agreement, which may include a reduction in the commitments under the Revolving Facility to £300 million and an extension of the maturity until 31 January 2025 with a discretionary extension option of 1 year (until 31 January 2026). Please see “Description of Notes—Security”. For more information on the terms of the Senior Facilities Agreement and the possible amendment and restatement, please see “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Senior Facilities Agreement”. (7) On 24 July 2019, we also entered into a private placement agreement between, amongst others, Drax Corporate Limited as borrower, DGHL as parent guarantor and Banco Santander S.A., London Branch as facility agent (the “Private Placement Agreement”). The Private Placement Agreement comprises a £375 million term facility available in four tranches (the “Private Placement Facilities”). The Private Placement Facilities are guaranteed on a senior secured basis by the Guarantors and the Issuer and are secured by the same Collateral that secures the Senior Facilities, the ESG Facility, the 2022 Notes and the 2025 Notes and that will secure the Notes. For more information on the terms of the Private Placement Agreement, please see “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements— Private _Placement Agreement”._ (8) On 10 June 2020, we amended and restated an environmental, social and governance facility agreement originally entered into on 24 June 2019 between, amongst others, Drax Corporate Limited as borrower, DGHL as parent guarantor and Barclays Bank PLC as facility agent (the “ESG Facility Agreement”). The ESG Facility Agreement comprises a £125 million term facility (the “ESG Facility”). The ESG Facility is guaranteed on a senior secured basis by the Guarantors and the Issuer and is secured by the same Collateral that secures the Senior Facilities, the Private Placement Facilities, the 2022 Notes, 2025 Notes and the Term Facilities and that will secure the Notes. For more information on the terms of the ESG Facility Agreement, please see “Description of Certain Financing _Arrangements—ESG Facility Agreement”._ (9) On 18 August 2020, we entered into a term loan facilities agreement between, amongst others, Drax Corporate Limited as borrower, DGHL as parent guarantor and Banco Santander S.A., London Branch as facility agent (the “Term Facilities Agreement”). The Term 16 ----- Facilities Agreement comprises a €126.5 million and £45 million term facility available in six tranches (the “Term Facilities”). The Term Facilities are guaranteed on a senior secured basis by the Guarantors and the Issuer and are secured by the same Collateral that secures the Senior Facilities, the Private Placement Facilities, the 2022 Notes, 2025 Notes and the ESG Facility and that will secure the Notes. Pursuant to the Term Facilities Agreement, the commitments under Facility F in the amount of €31.5 million will expire after 3 November 2020. Accordingly, on or prior to that date, we expect to submit a request to draw €31.5 million under the Term Loan Facilities, to be funded on or before 13 November 2020, which is the final utilisation date under Facility F. We expect the proceeds thereof to be used for general corporate purposes. For more information on the terms of the Term Facilities Agreement, please see “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Term Facilities Agreement”. (10)  Drax Power has the ability to enter into currency, interest rate and inflation rate hedging arrangements on a senior secured basis, with such counterparties also benefiting from the same Collateral as the 2022 Notes, the 2025 Notes, the ESG Facility, the Private Placement Facilities, the Term Facilities and the Senior Facilities, and such Collateral will also secure the Notes and the Guarantees referred to above. Such hedging arrangements may, in the future, also be entered into by other members of the Group. In the event of enforcement or certain distressed disposals, any liabilities in respect of obligations under the Senior Facilities and certain hedging obligations (including under the currency, interest rate and inflation hedging referred to above) and liabilities to lenders or creditors under certain other indebtedness permitted to be incurred under the Indentures (subject to the Intercreditor Agreement) and then outstanding will receive priority in relation to any proceeds of certain distressed disposals or enforcement of the Collateral. Please see “Description of Notes— Security”._ For more information on the terms of these arrangements, please see “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements— _Hedging”. These arrangements are in addition to any commodities and/or currency and interest rate trading that the Group undertakes on_ an unsecured basis. (11)  Under the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, in the event of an enforcement of the security interests over the Collateral and certain distressed disposals, the holders of the Notes will receive proceeds from such Collateral pari passu with the holders of the 2022 Notes and the 2025 Notes and with the lenders under the ESG Facility Agreement, the Private Placement Agreement and the Term Facilities Agreement and only after the lenders under the Senior Facilities Agreement, counterparties to certain hedging agreements and lenders or creditors under certain other indebtedness permitted to be incurred under the Indentures (subject to the Intercreditor Agreement) and then outstanding have been repaid in full. For more information on the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, please see “Description of _Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement”._ (12)  On or about the Issue Date, the Issuer will lend the gross proceeds of the Offering to Drax Corporate Limited pursuant to the New Proceeds Loan. Those proceeds will then be applied as described in “Use of Proceeds”. 17 -----

_This summary highlights selected information about the Group and the Offering contained elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. The following summary is not complete and does not contain all the information you should consider before investing in the Notes. The following summary should be read in conjunction with, and is qualified in its entirety by, the more detailed information included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. Before making an investment decision, you should read this entire Offering Memorandum carefully, including the Drax Group Audited Financial Statements and the notes thereto and the other financial information contained in this Offering Memorandum, as well as the risks described in the section entitled “Risk Factors”. Certain defined terms used herein are defined elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. Certain statements include forward-looking information that involves risks and uncertainties. See “Forward-Looking Statements”._

Interest Payment Dates** . . . . . . . . . . . . .  Semi-annually in arrears on 1 May and 1 November of each year, commencing on 1 May 2021. Interest on the Notes will accrue from (and including) the Issue Date.

Subsection Title: Denomination and Form . . . . . . . . . . . .  The Issuer will issue each Note in global registered form in minimum
Subsubsection Text: denominations of €100,000 and in integral multiples of €1,000 in excess thereof  maintained  in  book-entry  form.  Notes  in denominations of less than €100,000 will not be available. Ranking of the Notes** . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .  The Notes will: - be general senior obligations of the Issuer; - rank _pari passu_ in right of payment with all existing and future obligations of the Issuer that are not expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes, including the obligations of the Issuer under the 2022 Notes, the 2025 Notes, indebtedness incurred under the Senior Facilities Agreement, the ESG Facility Agreement, the Private Placement Agreement and the Term Facilities Agreement and certain hedging obligations; - be senior in right of payment to all existing and future obligations of the Issuer that are expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes; - be secured by the Collateral on and from the Issue Date, but the Holders of the Notes will only receive proceeds from the enforcement over the Collateral and certain distressed disposals after certain obligations of DGHL and its subsidiaries, including the indebtedness under the Senior Facilities Agreement and certain hedging obligations, have been repaid and discharged in full; - be effectively subordinated to any existing and future obligations of the Issuer that are secured by property or assets that do not secure the Notes, to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such obligations; and - be structurally subordinated to all existing and future obligations of the subsidiaries of DGHL that are not Subsidiary Guarantors. Guarantees** . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .  The Notes will be guaranteed on a senior basis by DGHL, Drax Corporate Limited, Drax Smart Generation Holdco Limited, Drax 18 ----- Fuel Supply Limited, Drax Power Limited, Drax Smart Supply Holdco Limited, Haven Power Limited, Haven Heat Limited, Drax Retail Developments Limited, Opus Energy Group Limited, Opus Energy Limited, Opus Energy (Corporate) Limited, Opus Gas Supply Limited, Opus Energy Renewables Limited, Farmoor Energy Limited, Donnington Energy Limited, Drax Research and Innovation Holdco Limited,  Drax  Corporate  Developments  Limited,  Drax  Smart Sourcing Holdco Limited, Drax Innovation Limited, Drax Biomass Transit LLC, Morehouse BioEnergy LLC, Drax Biomass International Holdings LLC, Drax Biomass Holdings LLC, Drax Biomass Inc., Baton Rouge Transit LLC, DBI O&M Company LLC, Amite BioEnergy LLC, Tyler BioEnergy LLC, Jefferson Transit LLC, LaSalle BioEnergy LLC and DGEL (collectively, the “Guarantors”). The validity and enforceability of the Guarantees and the liability of each Guarantor is subject to the limitations described in “Certain _Insolvency Considerations and Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and Security”. In addition, the_ Guarantees of the Guarantors may be released under certain circumstances.  See  “Description  of  Notes—Note  Guarantees— _Release of Note Guarantees” and “Risk Factors—Risks related to the Notes, the Guarantees and our Capital Structure—There are circumstances other than repayment or discharge of the Notes under which the Collateral securing the Notes and the Guarantees will be released automatically, without the consent of the holders of the Notes or the consent of the Trustee”._

Subsection Title: Ranking of the Guarantees . . . . . . . . . .  The Guarantee of each Guarantor will be a general, joint and several,
Subsubsection Text: senior obligation of that Guarantor and will: - rank _pari passu_ in right of payment with all existing and future obligations of that Guarantor that are not expressly subordinated in right of payment to such Note Guarantee, including the guarantees in respect of the 2022 Notes, the guarantees in respect of the 2025 Notes, indebtedness incurred under the Senior Facilities Agreement, the ESG Facility Agreement, the Private Placement Agreement and the Term Facilities Agreement and certain hedging obligations; - rank senior in right of payment to all existing and future obligations of such Guarantor that are expressly subordinated in right of payment to such Guarantee; - (subject to the Agreed Security Principles) be secured by the Collateral as set forth under “Description of Notes—Security”, but the holders of the Notes will only receive proceeds from the enforcement over the Collateral and certain distressed disposals after certain obligations of DGHL and its subsidiaries, including the indebtedness under the Senior Facilities Agreement and certain hedging obligations, have been repaid and discharged in full; - be structurally subordinated to all existing and future obligations of any subsidiaries of DGHL that are not Guarantors or the Issuer; and - be effectively subordinated to all existing and future obligations of such Guarantor that are secured by property or assets that do not secure such Guarantee, to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such obligations. 19 -----

Subsection Title: Collateral . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .  On the Issue Date, the Notes and the Guarantees will (subject to the
Subsubsection Text: Agreed Security Principles) be secured by first-ranking security interests over the following: - all of the issued share capital of DGHL and certain receivables owed to Drax Group plc by DGHL; - substantially all of the assets of the Issuer, including the receivables owed to the Issuer in respect of the New Proceeds Loan pursuant to which the proceeds of the Notes will be on-lent; - all of the issued share capital of the Issuer and each Subsidiary Guarantor; - substantially all of the assets of each Guarantor incorporated or organised under the laws of England and Wales; - substantially all of the assets of each Guarantor organised in or under the laws of the United States (or any state or territory thereof or the District of Columbia) other than any real property located in the United States; and - substantially all of the assets of the Guarantor incorporated or organised under the laws of Scotland, (together, the “Collateral”). For more information on the Collateral, see “Description of Notes— _Security”._ The Collateral securing the Notes and the Guarantees also secures liabilities under the 2022 Notes, the 2025 Notes, the Senior Facilities Agreement, the ESG Facility Agreement, the Private Placement Agreement, the Term Facilities Agreement and certain hedging obligations. Under the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, in the event  of  enforcement  of  the  Collateral  and  certain  distressed disposals, the holders of the Notes will receive proceeds from such Collateral _pari passu_ with the holders of the 2022 Notes, the 2025 Notes and with the lenders under the ESG Facility Agreement, the lenders under the Private Placement Agreement and the lenders under the Term Facilities Agreement and only after the lenders under the Senior Facilities Agreement, counterparties to certain hedging obligations and lenders or creditors under certain other indebtedness permitted to be incurred under the Indenture (subject to the Intercreditor Agreement) and then outstanding have been repaid and discharged in full. The security interests in the Collateral will be subject to certain contractual and legal limitations and defences under applicable law as described in “Certain Insolvency Considerations and Limitations on _Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and Security”. In_ addition, the security interests in the Collateral may be released under certain circumstances. See “Description of Notes—Security—Release of _Liens” and “Risk Factors—Risks related to the Notes, the Guarantees and our Capital Structure—There are circumstances other than repayment or discharge of the Notes under which the Collateral securing the Notes and the Guarantees will be released automatically, without the consent of the holders of the Notes or the consent of the Trustee”._

Subsection Title: Intercreditor Agreement . . . . . . . . . . . .  Each holder of a Note, by accepting a Note, will be deemed to have
Subsubsection Text: agreed to, accepted and be bound by, the terms of the Intercreditor 20 ----- Agreement. The Indenture is subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, and the rights and benefits of the holders of the Notes will  be  limited  accordingly  and  subject  to  the  terms  of  the Intercreditor Agreement. See “Description of Certain Financing _Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement”._ Optional Redemption** . . . . . . . . . . . . . .  At any time prior to 1 November 2022, the Issuer may redeem all or, from time to time, part of the Notes at a redemption price equal to 100 per cent. of the principal amount of such Notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but not including, the redemption date, plus the applicable “make-whole” premium set forth in “Description of Notes—Optional Redemption”. At any time on or after 1 November 2022, the Issuer may redeem all or, from time to time, part of the Notes at the redemption prices as described under “Description of Notes—Optional Redemption”, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but not including, the redemption date. In addition, at any time prior to 1 November 2022, the Issuer may on any one or more occasions redeem up to 40 per cent. of the original principal amount of the Notes (including the original principal amount of any Additional Notes issued after the Issue Date) with the net cash proceeds from certain equity offerings at a redemption price of 102.625 per cent. of the principal amount of the Notes redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but not including, the redemption date; provided that (i) at least 50 per cent. of the original principal amount of the Notes (including the original principal amount of any Additional Notes issued after the Issue Date) remain outstanding after each such redemption and (ii) the redemption occurs within 180 days after the closing of such equity offering. In connection with any tender offer for, or other offer to purchase, all of the Notes, in the event that holders of not less than 90 per cent. of the aggregate principal amount of the outstanding Notes validly tender and do not validly withdraw such Notes in such tender offer or offer to purchase and the Issuer or a third party making such tender offer or offer to purchase all the Notes held by such holders, the Issuer will have the right to redeem all (but not less than all) the Notes  that remain  outstanding  following  such  purchase  at  a redemption price equal to the highest price (excluding any early tender premium or similar payment) paid pursuant to such tender offer or offer to purchase. See “Description of Notes—Optional Redemption upon _Certain Tender Offers”._ Additional Amounts** . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .  Except as provided in “Description of Notes”, all payments made by or on behalf of the Issuer or any Guarantor or any successor entity in respect of the Notes or the Guarantees will be made without withholding or deduction for any taxes or other governmental charges, except to the extent required by law. If any such withholding or deduction is required by law in any Relevant Taxing Jurisdiction (as defined under “Description of Notes—Withholding Taxes”), subject to certain exceptions, the Issuer or the relevant Guarantor or any successor entity, as appropriate, will pay additional amounts so that the net amount received is no less than would have been received in the absence of such withholding or deduction. See “Description of Notes— _Withholding Taxes”._ 21 ----- Tax Redemption** . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .  The Issuer may redeem the Notes in whole, but not in part, at any time upon giving proper notice if certain changes in the tax law of any Relevant Taxing Jurisdiction (as defined under “Description of Notes— _Withholding Taxes”) become effective that would impose withholding_ or deduction for taxes on amounts payable on the Notes or the Guarantees, as applicable, in respect of which the relevant payor would be required to pay additional amounts, such redemption being at a redemption price of 100 per cent. of the principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the redemption date. See “Description of Notes—Redemption for Taxation Reasons”. Change of Control** . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .  Upon the occurrence of certain events constituting a “change of control”, the Issuer is required to offer to repurchase all outstanding Notes at a purchase price in cash equal to 101 per cent. of the aggregate principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but not including, the date of purchase. See “Description of Notes—Change of Control”.

Subsection Title: Certain Covenants . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .  The Indenture restricts the ability of DGHL and the Restricted
Subsubsection Text: Subsidiaries of DGHL to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain preferred stock; - pay dividends on, or redeem, capital stock and make certain other restricted payments; - make certain investments; - create or permit to exist certain liens; - sell, lease or transfer certain assets, including subsidiary stock; - agree to restrictions on dividends by Restricted Subsidiaries; - enter into certain transactions with affiliates; - merge or consolidate with other entities; - engage in certain activities (with respect to the Issuer); - make certain amendments to the New Proceeds Loan; and - impair the security interests for the benefit of the holders of the Notes. Certain of the covenants will be suspended if the Notes obtain and maintain an investment-grade rating. Each of these covenants is subject to significant exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of _Notes—Certain Covenants”._ Use of Proceeds** . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .  We intend to use the gross proceeds of the Offering (i) for general corporate purposes,  which  may  include  the  repayment  of indebtedness, and (ii) to pay estimated fees and expenses of the Offering, including Initial Purchasers’ fees and commissions, professional fees and other associated transaction costs. We intend to repay the 2022 Notes in full before 31 December 2020. See “Use of _Proceeds”._ Transfer Restrictions** . . . . . . . . . . . . . .  The Notes and the Guarantees have not been, and will not be, registered under the US Securities Act or the securities laws of any other jurisdiction. The Notes are subject to restrictions on transferability and resale. See “Notice to Investors”. The Issuer has not agreed to, or otherwise undertaken to, register the Notes or the Guarantees under the securities laws in any jurisdiction (including by way of an exchange offer) and does not intend to do so. 22 -----

Notes** . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .  The Notes will be new securities for which there is currently no established trading market. Although the Initial Purchasers have advised the Issuer that they intend to make a market for the Notes, they are not obligated to do so and they may discontinue market making at any time without notice. Accordingly, there can be no assurances as to the development or liquidity of any market for the Notes. Listing** . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .  Application will be made to list the Notes on the Official List of the Luxembourg Stock Exchange, and to have the Notes admitted to trading on the Euro MTF Market (the “Euro MTF Market”).

Subsubsection Text: (1) Our revenue and cost of sales includes certain remeasurements on derivative contracts which are not designated as hedging instruments under IFRS which comprise gains or losses on derivative contracts to the extent that those contracts do not qualify for hedge accounting, or hedge accounting is not effective, and those gains or losses are either (i) unrealised and relate to the delivery of commodity contracts in future periods, or (ii) are realised in relation to the delivery of commodity contracts in the current period. The effect of excluding certain remeasurements from results of operations is to reflect commodity sales and purchases at contracted prices— i.e., at the all-in-hedged amount paid or received in respect of the delivery of the commodity in question. (2) We define Adjusted EBITDA as profit/loss for the year before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation, excluding the impact of exceptional items and certain remeasurements. Adjusted EBITDA has limitations as an analytical tool and should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for analysis of our results of operations as reported under IFRS. Subsubsection Text: (a) “Certain remeasurements” represent the effect of changes in fair value of derivative contracts at the relevant balance sheet date, to the extent such derivative contracts do not qualify for the own use exemption or as effective hedges in accordance with IFRS. See “Presentation of Financial Information and Other Information”. (2) We define Adjusted EBITDA as profit/loss for the year before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation, excluding the impact of exceptional items and certain remeasurements. As a result of the temporary suspension of the Capacity Market, Adjusted EBITDA for the six months ended 30 June 2019 does not include £36 million of Capacity Market income due in respect of the first half of the year that was not recognised until the reinstatement of the Capacity Market in November 2019, and Adjusted EBITDA for the year ended 31 December 2019 includes £6.8 million related to the period in 2018 subsequent to the Capacity Market suspension. Adjusted EBITDA is not a measurement of financial performance under IFRS and should not be considered as an alternative to profit or any other performance measure derived in accordance with IFRS. We present Adjusted EBITDA for informational purposes only. It may not give an accurate or complete picture of the results of operations and should not be relied upon when making an investment decision. See “Presentation of Financial Information and Other Information—Non-IFRS Financial Measures” for more information. Adjusted EBITDA is affected by a number of factors, including availability of our generation units, electricity wholesale prices, seasonality and the level of our operating expense. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations— _Significant Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations” for a description of certain significant factors that are expected to have an impact_ on our Adjusted EBITDA going forward. For reconciliations from profit for the year to Adjusted EBITDA, see footnote (2) above under the caption “—Summary Historical Financial and Other Information”. (3) Adjusted EBITDA Margin for a given period is defined as Adjusted EBITDA divided by Adjusted Revenue for that period. See “Presentation of Financial Information and Other Information—Non-IFRS Financial Measures” for more information. (4) _As adjusted cash and cash equivalents gives effect to the Offering as if the Offering had taken place on 30 June 2020. The effect of the Offering on our cash and cash equivalents depends upon a number of factors and may vary from the expected effect reflected in this as adjusted_ figure including the use of proceeds from the Offering, all or a portion of which may be used for the repayment of indebtedness. See “Use of Proceeds” and “Capitalisation”. (5) _As adjusted consolidated debt gives effect to the Offering as if the Offering had taken place on 30 June 2020, but does not reflect the use of proceeds, all or a portion of which may be used for the repayment of indebtedness. and excludes the available commitments under the Senior Facilities Agreement and the Term Facilities Agreement. Pursuant to the Term Facilities Agreement, entered into on 18 August 2020, the commitments under Facility F in the amount of €31.5 million will expire after 3 November 2020. Accordingly, on or prior to that date, we expect to submit a request to draw €31.5 million under the Term Loan Facilities, to be funded on or before 13 November 2020, which is the final utilisation date under Facility F. We expect the proceeds thereof to be used for general corporate purposes. As adjusted consolidated debt is defined to be as adjusted current and non-current borrowings excluding deferred finance costs. See “Use of Proceeds” and “Capitalisation”. (6) _As adjusted consolidated net debt is net financial debt adjusted for the effect of the Offering (assuming the proceeds therefrom are used for general corporate purposes, although all or a portion of the proceeds may be used for the repayment of indebtedness) as if the Offering had taken place on 30 June 2020. As adjusted consolidated net debt is defined to be as adjusted consolidated debt less as adjusted cash and cash equivalents. See “Use of Proceeds” and “Capitalisation”. (7) _As adjusted net interest expense gives effect to the Offering (assuming the proceeds therefrom are used for general corporate purposes, although all or a portion of the proceeds may be used for the repayment of indebtedness) as if the Offering had taken place on 1 July 2019 and has been calculated after taking into account currency hedging arrangements. This figure does not include commitment fees in respect of our Senior Facilities Agreement. See “Use of Proceeds”, “Capitalisation” and “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Senior Facilities Agreement”._ _As adjusted_ net interest expense has been presented for illustrative purposes only and does not purport to represent what our interest expense would have actually been had the Offering occurred on the date assumed, nor does it purport to project our interest expenses for any period or our financial condition at any future date. (8) Ratio of as adjusted consolidated net debt to Adjusted EBITDA for a given period is defined to be as adjusted consolidated net debt divided by Adjusted EBITDA for that period. (9) Ratio of Adjusted EBITDA to _as adjusted_ net interest expense for a given period is defined as Adjusted EBITDA divided by _as _adjusted net interest expense for that period._ 30 ----- _Key Performance Indicators_
