Section Title: SUMMARY HISTORICAL CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL AND OTHER DATA
Subsubsection Text: The Issuer is a public limited company incorporated under the laws of England and Wales on 10 March 2017, and is a direct wholly-owned subsidiary of DGHL, which is in turn a direct wholly-owned subsidiary of Drax Group plc. The Issuer is a finance company that conducts no business operations of its own and as of the Issue Date its only material assets will be its rights and claims under various intercompany financings (including under the New Proceeds Loan) and its only material liabilities will be its outstanding indebtedness (including its obligations under the Notes, the 2022 Notes and the 2025 Notes, as well as its guarantees in respect of the Senior Facilities Agreement, the ESG Facility Agreement, the Private Placement Agreement, the Term Facilities Agreement and certain hedging obligations). For further information, please see “Summary—Corporate and Financing Structure”, “Our Business” and “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements”. Unless otherwise indicated, this Offering Memorandum does not include any historical financial information relating to the Issuer. This Offering Memorandum presents consolidated financial information for the Group on the level of Drax Group plc, the immediate holding company of DGHL. Drax Group plc will not be subject to the restrictive covenants under the Indenture, will not provide a Guarantee in favour of the Notes and will not grant security in favour of the Notes, except with respect to the shares it owns in DGHL and certain receivables owed to Drax Group plc by members of the Group. Drax Group plc is a holding company and as at 30 June 2020 its only material assets and liabilities were its interest in the issued and outstanding shares of DGHL, its rights and obligations under the Shareholder Support Agreement and a net intercompany liability (including the balance of intercompany liabilities and intercompany receivables) of £30.1 million and cash of £51.6 million. The following tables present summary historical consolidated financial data for Drax Group plc as at and for the six months ended 30 June 2020 and 2019 and the years ended 31 December 2019 and 2018. Unless otherwise specified, the summary historical consolidated financial data of Drax Group plc as of and for the six months ended 30 June 2020 and 2019 have been derived from the 2020 Drax Group Unaudited Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum and the summary historical consolidated financial data of Drax Group plc as of and for the years ended 31 December 2019 and 2018 have been derived from the 2019 Drax Group Audited Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. The financial information of the Group as of and for the year ended 31 December 2018 (i) includes the assets and liabilities of the DGEL Group acquired in connection with the DGEL Acquisition in the Drax Group’s balance sheet as of 31 December 2018 and (ii) does not include income, expenditure or cash flows of the DGEL Group. The 2019 Drax Group Audited Financial Statements have been prepared in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards as adopted by the European Union (“IFRS”). The following tables also present historical consolidated financial data for Drax Group plc for the twelve months ended 30 June 2020, which were calculated by adding the unaudited condensed consolidated financial information for the six months ended 30 June 2020 to the audited consolidated financial information for the year ended 31 December 2019 extracted from the Group’s audited financial statements as of and for the year ended 31 December 2019, and subtracting the unaudited condensed consolidated financial information for the six months ended 30 June 2019. As discussed in Note 19 to the 2020 Drax Group Unaudited Financial Statements, the unaudited consolidated financial statements as of and for the six months ended 30 June 2019 have been restated to reflect adjustments resulting from (i) the finalisation of the acquisition date fair values of assets and liabilities of the DGEL Group acquired on 31 December 2018, as the finalisation of the terms of the defined benefit pension scheme transfer resulted in a reduction in the net opening surplus recognised by £1.1 million, and the finalisation of the Group’s assessment of cash-generation units (“CGUs”) and their fair values resulted in a net reduction in property, plant and equipment values by £0.2 million and a reduction in deferred tax liabilities by £0.1 million; these adjustments had corresponding impacts on goodwill, (ii) the correction of a historical error identified in respect of the translation of fixed assets in our US-based business into the Group’s audited consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended 31 December 2019, as the application of the correct foreign exchange rates resulted in an increase in fixed asset carrying values at 30 June 2019 and 1 January 2019 of £56.6 million and £55.5 million, respectively, with an equivalent amount recognised in the translation reserve; the correction has no impact on profit or cash amounts, and (iii) a change in the presentation of amounts in relation to rebased foreign currency exchange contracts in the balance sheet, which resulted in a £42.9 million reduction in derivative assets and a £42.9 million reduction in deferred income in the balance sheet as of 30 June 2019. 25 ----- Furthermore, as discussed in Note 8.3 to the 2019 Drax Group Audited Financial Statements, the unaudited comparative information as of and for the year ended 31 December 2018 included in the 2019 Drax Group Audited Financial Statements has been restated to reflect the same adjustments described in (i) and (ii) above, as follows: (x) adjustments to the fair value of assets and liabilities as set for in clause (i) above and, as a result of the conclusion of the completion statement process, an increase in consideration of £4.8 million and an increase in the net financial assets acquired of £2.5 million, with a corresponding £2.3 million increase in goodwill and (y) the correction as set forth in (ii) above, resulting in an increase in fixed asset carrying values at 1 January and 31 December 2018 of £37.8 million and £55.5 million, respectively, with an equivalent amount recognised in the translation reserve; the correction has no impact on profit or cash amounts. In this Offering Memorandum, we present consolidated balance sheet information as of 30 June 2020 and 31 December 2018 on a restated basis. The financial information below includes certain Non-IFRS Measures used to evaluate the Group’s economic and financial performance. These measures are not identified as accounting measures under IFRS and therefore should not be considered as an alternative measure to evaluate the Group’s performance. See “Presentation of Financial Information and Other Information—Non-IFRS Financial Measures”. The financial information below is not necessarily indicative of future results of operations. Prospective investors should read the summary data presented below in conjunction with “Use of Proceeds”, “Capitalisation”, “Selected Financial _Information”, “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations”, as_ well as the 2020 Drax Group Unaudited Financial Statements for the six months ended 30 June 2020 and 2019 and the 2019 Drax Group Audited Financial Statements for the years ended 31 December 2019 and 2018, along with the related notes thereto, which are included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. The financial information presented below includes certain unaudited financial information, presented on an _as adjusted basis to give effect to the Offering. The unaudited as adjusted financial information is for illustrative_ purposes only and is not intended to represent or to be indicative of the consolidated results of operations or financial position the Group would have reported had (i) the Offering been completed as of 1 July 2019 for the purposes of the calculation of _as adjusted_ interest expense or (ii) the Offering been completed as of 30 June 2020 for the purposes of the calculation of as adjusted cash and cash equivalents, as adjusted consolidated debt and as adjusted consolidated net debt. The unaudited _as adjusted_ financial information should not be taken as indicative of the Group’s future consolidated results of operations or financial position. The as adjusted financial data have not been prepared in accordance with the requirements of the Prospectus Regulation, IFRS, or any other generally accepted accounting standards. Neither the assumptions underlying the as _adjusted adjustments nor the resulting as adjusted financial data have been audited or reviewed._

_An investment in the Notes involves risk. You should carefully consider the risks described below as well as the other information contained in this Offering Memorandum before making an investment decision. Any of the following risks could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations, and as a result you may lose all or part of your original investment. The risks described below are not the only risks that we face. Additional risks and uncertainties not currently known to us or that we currently deem to be immaterial may also materially adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations which, in turn, could have a material adverse effect on the Issuer’s ability to pay interest and repay the principal amount in respect of the Notes. Except as the context otherwise indicates and as discussed in this paragraph, when discussing historical financial or operating information in this section, “we”, “us”, “our”, “Drax Group” and “Drax,” are generally used to refer to the business of the Drax Group plc and its subsidiaries. This Offering Memorandum also contains forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. Our actual results may differ materially from those anticipated in those forward-looking statements as a result of various factors, including the risks described below and elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. See “Forward- Looking Statements”._

Section Title: RISKS RELATING TO OUR BUSINESS AND INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Obligation** **ROCs presented** **Headroom Period** **(in million ROCs)** **(in million ROCs)** **(in per cent.)
Subsubsection Title: The amount of the Ofgem buy-out fund payment that will be paid over to us is unpredictable and difficult to forecast.
Subsubsection Text: The RO buy-out fund is made up of payments from suppliers who do not have sufficient ROCs to Ofgem to meet their RO for the relevant compliance period and who therefore are required to pay the ROC buy-out price for each ROC that they failed to procure. Its quantum therefore increases proportionally to the scarcity of ROCs in any given compliance period. Many of our contracts for the sale of ROCs to suppliers contain provisions that require the supplier to pay a fixed upfront fee and then an additional fee at a later date equal to the proportion of the recycle fund that is received by the supplier from Ofgem following submission of the purchased ROCs. If renewable output differs materially from DBEIS’s expectations, more or fewer ROCs will have been generated during the compliance period than forecast, which will affect the level of the recycle payment. This volatility increases the difficulty in forecasting the expected pay-out from the RO buy-out fund. There is, therefore, inherent uncertainty in the amount of recycle benefit to which we will be entitled and, while we may attempt to hedge our exposure to any fluctuations in the amount of recycle benefit from wind, any significant fluctuations could have a material adverse effect on our business, operations, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Section Title: RISKS RELATING TO OUR BUSINESS AND INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Obligation** **ROCs presented** **Headroom Period** **(in million ROCs)** **(in million ROCs)** **(in per cent.)
Subsubsection Title: Third party mutualisation charges may affect our results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: The failure of several small energy suppliers in 2018 and 2019 led to a shortfall in payments into the various government schemes where energy suppliers are collectively obligated to pay charges for low carbon generation and capacity costs, most notably the RO Scheme. In 2018 and 2019 this led to mutualisation of costs associated with the RO Scheme and SS-FiT, which increased our cost of sales by £3.9 million for the year ended 31 December 2018 and £0.9 million for the year ended 31 December 2019. A similar mutualisation process was invoked in respect of costs associated with the Capacity Market in the fourth financial quarter of 2019, which increased our cost of sales by £0.7 million. In all these circumstances, the remaining energy suppliers are obligated to make up the shortfall. 56 ----- Further energy supplier failures to pay such costs, including costs associated with the Capacity Market could lead to further industry cost mutualisation. To the extent that these increased costs are not mitigated by customer pass-throughs or similar solutions, they may adversely affect our business, operations, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Section Title: RISKS RELATING TO OUR BUSINESS AND INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Obligation** **ROCs presented** **Headroom Period** **(in million ROCs)** **(in million ROCs)** **(in per cent.)
Subsubsection Title: We operate in a seasonal industry, which may affect our results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: Demand for electricity is seasonal, with demand and prices generally being higher during the winter months. Demand for gas in the Customers segment is also dependent on weather, with periods of cold weather usually resulting in an increase in demand. In addition, revenue from the sale of ROCs is subject to annual patterns. Generators typically sell ROCs to suppliers for delivery and payment in the months of June or July following the end of the relevant compliance period as suppliers need to submit the ROCs to Ofgem by the end of August following the end of the compliance period. Therefore, the results of a single financial half-year may not be a reliable basis for the expectations of a full fiscal year and may not be comparable with the results in other financial half-years. See also “—An inability to _source fuel to the correct technical specification could lead to a reduced output from Drax Power Station”._

Section Title: RISKS RELATING TO OUR BUSINESS AND INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Obligation** **ROCs presented** **Headroom Period** **(in million ROCs)** **(in million ROCs)** **(in per cent.)
Subsubsection Title: The performance of our pumped storage and hydro assets could be impacted by unseasonal or extreme weather conditions, which may affect our results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: The performance of our pumped storage and hydro assets could be impacted by unseasonal or extreme weather conditions. The economic case underpinning the acquisition of the pumped storage and hydro assets assumes that the assets will be generally capable of being dispatched at times of peak demand and pricing. However, unseasonal or extreme weather may prevent this. If, for example, droughts restrict water flows and consequent generation or excess rainfall leads to a need to dispatch the assets at suboptimal times to avoid flooding, this could have a material adverse effect on our business, operations, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Section Title: RISKS RELATING TO OUR BUSINESS AND INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Obligation** **ROCs presented** **Headroom Period** **(in million ROCs)** **(in million ROCs)** **(in per cent.)
Subsubsection Title: Expansion of the generation and supply business into biomass supply markets could expose the business to new risks, such as increased anti-competition scrutiny, as a supplier rather than a consumer of biomass.
Subsubsection Text: When building or acquiring new assets across our business portfolio, it is necessary to ensure that our businesses comply with anti-competition laws like the Hart-Scott-Rodino Antitrust Improvements Act in the US and meet the standards of regulators like the Competition Markets Authority in the UK. In particular as we seek to expand our self-supply of biomass to five million tonnes per annum, we will take a greater market share of a relatively small market which could bring our business under greater scrutiny under anti-competition laws and regulations. Our ambitions to self-supply five million tonnes of biomass per annum include proposals to develop a biomass trading capability that may also involve the supply of biomass to third parties. This is a market which we do not currently operate within on a large scale as currently we only sell biomass when we have a surplus relative to projected generation. Entering this market may expose the business to new risks of acting as a supplier to third parties with associated contractual obligations and potential cost implications for failing to meet such contractual obligations.

Section Title: RISKS RELATING TO OUR BUSINESS AND INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Obligation** **ROCs presented** **Headroom Period** **(in million ROCs)** **(in million ROCs)** **(in per cent.)
Subsubsection Title: A failure of, or a malicious attack in relation to, our IT systems could adversely affect our reputation, business and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: We are highly dependent on our IT systems and networks and our operational performance could be materially adversely affected by a failure to maintain the health of our IT systems and networks, with inadequate record keeping, poor control of data and failure to support key technologies being among the key risks. Attempts may be made to gain unauthorised access to, or deliberately breach, our IT systems in order, for example, to manipulate our proprietary business data or customer information. Other examples include breaching of a licence agreement, regulatory requirement or contractual obligation, and even incidents that do not amount to a breach could result in adverse regulatory and financial consequences, as well as harming our reputation. In addition to these risks, we may be affected by other potential events that are largely outside our control. Malicious attacks, including cyber-attacks, may damage our assets, or prevent generation at our generation facilities. Any cyber-attack on the Group and, in particular, on Drax Power Station could have wide-ranging and devastating consequences. Such an event could have a material adverse effect on our business, operations, 57 ----- prospects, financial condition and results of operations. As our business grows, our information security capability will need to be expanded and improved to accommodate the businesses’ increasingly complex and demanding requirements. For example, following the DGEL Acquisition, we now operate multiple IT systems across multiple sites and, where appropriate, we are taking steps to replace DGEL’s legacy systems with new systems. Failure to make these improvements in an efficient and timely manner could have a detrimental impact on our systems or networks availability or efficiency, leading to a material adverse impact on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISKS RELATING TO OUR BUSINESS AND INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Obligation** **ROCs presented** **Headroom Period** **(in million ROCs)** **(in million ROCs)** **(in per cent.)
Subsubsection Title: Failures of our IT systems for our Customers segment may negatively impact future business development and adversely affect our existing customer base.
Subsubsection Text: Our Customers segment depends on its IT systems for regulatory compliance, such as the effective and compliant roll-out of Smart Meters to customers. See “—Our business is subject to complex regulation by the _Government, the EU and other authorities that has in the past and could in the future materially adversely affect us”._ Any failings in our IT systems and IT architecture may adversely affect the customer experience, our monthly billing and debt collection cycle, and our ability to comply with regulatory obligations. Such occurrences may have a material adverse effect on the ability of the Customers segment to retain and develop its customer base and may adversely affect our business, operations, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Section Title: RISKS RELATING TO OUR BUSINESS AND INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Obligation** **ROCs presented** **Headroom Period** **(in million ROCs)** **(in million ROCs)** **(in per cent.)
Subsubsection Title: Failure to comply with data protection legislation or the disclosure of customer and employee data could result in harm to us.
Subsubsection Text: Our Group, and in particular our Customers segment, requires the processing of customer personal data and/ or special category personal data. Examples of such data include information identifying a person as a customer by reference to an identifier such as a name, address, an identification number, location data, an online identifier or to one or more factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity of that person. In the ordinary course of business, we also collect, transmit and store employee data, including dates of birth and medical information as well as business contact data of suppliers. Our use of this personal data is subject to laws, regulations and guidance designed to protect personal data that a business processes, including, among others, the EU-wide General Data Protection Regulation (the “GDPR”), which came into force on 25 May 2018 and was substantively transposed into UK law by the Data Protection Act 2018 (the “DPA”, and together with the GDPR, the “2018 Laws”), which imposes significant compliance obligations. The 2018 Laws implement more stringent operational requirements for controllers and processors of personal data than the previous legislative framework, including, for example, expanded disclosures about how personal information is to be used and more extensive rights for individuals in relation to their personal data. The Information Commissioner’s Office (the “Regulator”) now has more extensive enforcement powers including the ability to impose larger fines of up to €20 million or up to 4 per cent. of the total worldwide annual turnover of the preceding financial year, whichever is higher. Privacy is a fundamental human right and individuals are more likely to complain or bring a claim over misuse of their personal data. If a significant or widely publicised unlawful disclosure of employee or customer data were to occur, whether as a result of a failure of our IT security systems, employee negligence or wilful act or the actions of our suppliers, our reputation may be adversely affected, employee, customer or investor confidence may be diminished and we may be subject to legal claims by individuals, fines or other enforcement action by the Regulator. Company directors can also be disqualified following material breaches. Additionally, individuals who are the subject of the personal data have much more control over their personal data under the 2018 Laws and if there is a failure to accommodate the exercise of their expanded individual rights, then similar consequences could flow from such failures. The 2018 Laws also place responsibility on the business to ensure that its suppliers, third party intermediaries and contractors have appropriate safeguards in place against data breaches and comply with the principles of data protection. This applies across the entirety of our business portfolio and means that we must take steps to ensure that third parties we share personal data with and that we control also comply with the 2018 Laws, in particular where there are any international transfers or accessing of personal data outside the UK/EEA. This can be difficult to manage as we do not have control of such third parties’ IT security systems and any breaches could cause reputational damage for our business. We therefore have to carry out due diligence of relevant third parties and ensure appropriate data protection terms are in our agreements with them. In relation to 58 ----- an international transfer risk, the UK will need to become a European Commission ‘approved country’ to continue to receive EU citizen personal data at the end of the Transition Period and there is a risk that this approval process will not be completed within the Transition Period. If this approval is not forthcoming, UK businesses will need to enter into an alternative transfer mechanism to be compliant. The main alternative transfer mechanism, the EU Model Clause Agreement, was challenged in the EU but was found to be adequate. There was a specific transfer mechanism between the EU and US, namely the Privacy Shield, which (in the same challenge) was invalidated. Organisations that transfer personal data to the US relying upon the Privacy Shield are reviewing those arrangements and adopting EU Model Contractual Clauses. There is a risk that the Regulator may take action in the meantime but to date, the Regulator has not taken any enforcement action and guidance is awaited. The 2018 Laws also introduce other obligations, such as having procedures in place to ensure privacy by design and default to minimise the collection of personal data, to ensure data is accurate and up to date and to ensure data is appropriately protected and is not kept for longer than necessary. In addition, there is an increased need to have relevant processes and systems to respond adequately to the exercise of individual rights including subject access requests and erasure requests. Above all, we are required to demonstrate our accountability in relation to the personal data we process. A failure to comply with these obligations or put in place adequate procedures may result in fines or other regulator sanctions. Recent developments in case law in the UK suggest that energy generators may be considered public sector bodies for the purpose of the Environmental Information Regulations 2004. This could result in information access requests being made by the public for information which previously may not have been disclosed willingly into the public domain such as emission levels and other environmental matters.

Section Title: RISKS RELATING TO OUR BUSINESS AND INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Obligation** **ROCs presented** **Headroom Period** **(in million ROCs)** **(in million ROCs)** **(in per cent.)
Subsubsection Title: Our inability to attract, train or retain appropriately qualified personnel could adversely affect our business.
Subsubsection Text: Our success depends on our ability to attract and retain highly qualified employees and contractors. The need for such employees is particularly enhanced in light of the current pace of strategic change we are experiencing and we have actively recruited a number of employees in senior management and technical roles to ensure our enlarged Generation segment has an appropriate level of skills and experience following the DGEL Acquisition on 31 December 2018. The unplanned departure of any of our executive officers or key employees could have a negative impact on our operations, including possibly adversely affecting our ability to provide the service levels our customers expect. This risk is particularly true with respect to electricity regulation and the renewable energy industry. Electricity regulation and trading is a highly specialised field with a limited pool of qualified and experienced personnel while the renewable energy industry is a highly specialised and relatively new industry and, as a result, there is a limited pool of technically qualified personnel, particularly outside London. Certain of our generation assets are in remote locations and require employees with sufficient technical engineering and operational expertise to maintain and operate them safely and optimally. We compete with a number of companies as well as Government entities and other organisations for such personnel and, consequently, we have encountered and may continue to encounter difficulties in retaining certain key employees and attracting new personnel. Any such difficulty in retaining and/or attracting key personnel could have a material adverse effect on our business, operations, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. The multi-site, multi-fuel generation model operated by the Group requires an adequate number of sufficiently qualified employees to dispatch our complex portfolio of assets optimally. Energy trading on this scale is a highly specialised field and it may be difficult for us to retain or attract the personnel required.

Section Title: RISKS RELATING TO OUR BUSINESS AND INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Obligation** **ROCs presented** **Headroom Period** **(in million ROCs)** **(in million ROCs)** **(in per cent.)
Subsubsection Title: We are dependent on good working relations with our employees, unions and employee representatives to avoid business interruptions or amend collective bargaining agreements.
Subsubsection Text: As of 30 September 2020, approximately 62.5 per cent. of our employees in the Generation segment were covered by collective bargaining arrangements. We are in consultation with 203 of our employees as a result of our recent decision to cease commercial coal generation at Drax Power Station by March 2021, and whilst we have recently avoided industrial action, if our employees were to react adversely to the ongoing consultation, terminations, or the forthcoming pay negotiations, we may face labour disputes or work stoppages at our generation facilities. The operations at Drax Power Station have not recently been adversely affected by disputes with employees, contractors or trade unions. However, we can give no assurance that future industrial action may not disrupt our operations. For example, in 2019 our initial pay offer to employees subject to collective bargaining arrangements at Drax Power Station was rejected and a formal industrial action ballot was undertaken and strikes were planned. However, acceptable terms were subsequently agreed and averted the strikes. 59 -----

Section Title: RISKS RELATING TO OUR BUSINESS AND INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Obligation** **ROCs presented** **Headroom Period** **(in million ROCs)** **(in million ROCs)** **(in per cent.)
Subsubsection Title: We may suffer damages as a result of our employees or agents acting outside applicable law or regulation or our policies and procedures.
Subsubsection Text: We may suffer damage if an employee or someone acting on our behalf, for example a TPI, breaches our internal controls or internal governance framework or contravenes applicable laws and regulations. Such breach or circumvention may include, for example, inadvertent or careless mistakes or intentional acts or misrepresentations by our employees or agents, breaches of applicable laws or regulations in the course of their duties, breaches of operational guidelines or other improper acts. Any such misconduct could have an impact on our reputation and our relationship with our regulators and other stakeholders or lead to regulatory or legal action, which in turn could adversely affect our business, operations, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. The customers, suppliers, financial institutions, contractors and other third parties that we do business with may not fulfil their obligations to us and may expose us to credit and operational risks, which could adversely affect our financial position. _Credit Risk_ We purchase from and sell commodities to a range of counterparties in a number of different countries. Collateral is not required from all counterparties and the failure of one or more of these counterparties to perform its contractual obligations might lead to reduced profits for us or result in us incurring additional costs in replacing the relevant transactions. We may also find ourselves unable to procure or sell replacement commodities elsewhere. We derived revenues of £575.7 million in 2019 and £555.8 million in 2018 from one individual customer that represented 12.2 and 13.1 per cent of total consolidated revenue respectively for the period. These revenues arose in the Generation segment. A default by one of these customers could lead to such customer failing to make a substantial payment to us, thereby causing a loss of revenue and adversely affecting our business, operations, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. The failure of one or more of the large customers in our Customers segment (who are generally not required to deliver collateral in respect of their contractual obligations) may lead to bad debts and, consequently, reduced profits for us, particularly if the electricity or gas then needs to be sold in the market at a lower price than that previously contracted. We are also exposed to the credit risk of banks that hold our deposits and of financial counterparties with whom we hedge foreign exchange, commodity price, interest rate or inflation rate exposures. Our foreign exchange exposures are routinely hedged in line with our hedging policy and so any default or insolvency of a counterparty could lead to a failure by such counterparty to make termination payments payable to us and an inability to obtain sufficient replacement currency to enable us to meet our liabilities in a particular jurisdiction on a timely basis. _Operational Counterparty Risk_ The nascent nature of the biomass supply market means that a number of our third party biomass suppliers business are subject to degree of financial uncertainty. There is a risk that these biomass suppliers may default on their supply obligations and, in such circumstances, the potential for us to recover our losses as a result of a supplier default may be limited. A default by one of our main biomass suppliers could lead to such supplier failing to deliver biomass to us, causing a loss of revenue and adversely affecting our business, operations, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Section Title: RISKS RELATING TO OUR BUSINESS AND INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Obligation** **ROCs presented** **Headroom Period** **(in million ROCs)** **(in million ROCs)** **(in per cent.)
Subsubsection Title: We are exposed to foreign currency exchange risk and our business and results of operations may be negatively affected by fluctuation of different currencies.
Subsubsection Text: Our business is subject to risks due to fluctuations in currency exchange rates. Most of the biomass we purchase is priced in US dollars, Canadian dollars or euro. Changes in the relative value of the US dollar, Canadian dollar or euro, or relative to other currencies (including the pound sterling), may increase our suppliers’ cost of business and ultimately our cost of goods sold with respect to biomass. As such, our failure or inability to hedge currency exchange rate risks within our expected five-year hedging period (see “Our Business— Generation—Trading _sustainable biomass units”) or fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates beyond this period could have a_ material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. To the extent unhedged, any weakening of pound sterling would increase the currency exchange rate risk which we face, which could adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition. 60 -----

Section Title: RISKS RELATING TO OUR BUSINESS AND INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Obligation** **ROCs presented** **Headroom Period** **(in million ROCs)** **(in million ROCs)** **(in per cent.)
Subsubsection Title: Our financial models may be flawed and inaccurate.
Subsubsection Text: We use a number of financial models to manage our business and there is a risk that the financial models used by us to calculate important information such as generation forecasts and fuel pricing models, optimisation of fuel deliveries and infrastructure investment may produce inaccurate information. This could be due to a model itself being incorrect or corrupted, or the assumptions that we use in a model being inaccurate. Such failures could adversely affect our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Section Title: RISKS RELATING TO OUR BUSINESS AND INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Obligation** **ROCs presented** **Headroom Period** **(in million ROCs)** **(in million ROCs)** **(in per cent.)
Subsubsection Title: Our insurance policies may not provide cover for all losses incurred and we may not be able to maintain the same level of insurance cover in the future.
Subsubsection Text: Our operations are subject to various hazards common to the industry, such as explosions, fire, severe weather conditions, toxic emissions and equipment breakdowns. This risk is particularly acute because most of our revenue and gross profit for 2019 was derived from the sale of electricity produced from biomass generation and the subsidies related thereto (in the form of ROCs earned by Drax Power Station or CfD payments). As protection against operating hazards, we maintain insurance cover against some, but not all, of the potential losses which may arise. There is no assurance that catastrophic or other events relating to uninsured or uninsurable risks will not occur. Furthermore, if we suffer a loss in relation to an insured risk, there is no guarantee that the amount of insurance protection to which we would be contractually entitled will be sufficient to cover the entire loss incurred. Insurance, warranties or performance guarantees may not cover all or any lost revenues or increased expenses from business interruptions or other events. If we suffer an uninsured or underinsured loss, this could adversely affect our business, operations, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. As would be expected with a Group of this size we have a series of minor incidents that may result in either a property damage or business interruption claim. Insurance cover for particular risks or limits of indemnity may not continue to be available on commercially reasonable terms or cost. It is possible that in the future insurance providers may no longer wish to insure businesses in the biomass or coal industry against certain risks, or may charge generators significantly higher premiums for such cover. Moreover, if one of our operating facilities were to suffer an insured loss, the insurance proceeds received by us might not be sufficient to cover the business loss, or to repair and reinstate the affected facilities, or to satisfy liabilities to third parties. The occurrence of an event that is not fully covered by insurance could adversely affect our business, operations, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Section Title: RISKS RELATING TO OUR BUSINESS AND INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Obligation** **ROCs presented** **Headroom Period** **(in million ROCs)** **(in million ROCs)** **(in per cent.)
Subsubsection Title: We may be required to pay increased pension contributions to our pension schemes in the future.
Subsubsection Text: We maintain a variety of pension schemes, including two defined benefit schemes in the UK. We and our pension scheme trustees aim to meet the defined benefit liabilities from a combination of sources including investment returns and cash contributions from Drax Power and DGEL, the respective sponsoring companies, in respect of ongoing benefit accrual and deficit repair contributions for Drax Power. Each defined benefit scheme is exposed to risks relating to interest rates, inflation, returns on assets and the longevity of scheme members and as such a mismatch between asset and liability value movements. The defined benefit scheme’s investment portfolio contains a proportion of assets that are expected to provide a better return in the long term than alternative investments such as gilts; however, in the short term, the difference between the value of liabilities and assets may vary significantly, potentially resulting in an increase in the funding requirements. The current business environment, with low long-term interest rates, long-term gilt yields, corporate bond yields, equity values and credit spreads, could also affect the value of the deficit having to be recognised. Furthermore, a quicker than expected increase in life expectancy and/or employee pensionable salaries increasing above the rates assumed in the previous scheme valuation could increase the defined benefit liabilities. Further changes in the accounting standards relating to defined benefit pension liabilities could also lead to an increasing accounting deficit arising in our defined benefit pension scheme, albeit this would not impact the funding requirement. As of 31 December 2019, our Drax Power Defined Benefit Pension Scheme had a surplus of £3.1 million (compared to a surplus of £18.9 million as of 31 December 2018). Our DGEL defined benefit pension scheme was set up in 2019 following the DGEL Acquisition for certain employees with defined benefit pension rights that were transferred to the Group and had an initial restated surplus of £2.7 million increasing to £3.9 million as of 31 December 2019. As of 31 December 2019, a decrease of 0.25 per cent. in the discount rate or an increase of 0.25 per cent. in the inflation rate would have resulted in decreases in the net surplus under the defined benefit schemes of £18.2 million and £14.9 million, respectively. Also, as of 31 December 2019, an increase in life expectancy by one year would have resulted in a decrease in our net surplus under the defined benefit pension schemes of £13.3 million. 61 ----- Our defined benefit pension scheme is subject to triennial actuarial valuations, with the next valuation for the Drax Power Defined Benefit Scheme scheduled for a March 2021 balance sheet date and for the DGEL Defined Benefit Scheme for a March 2020 balance sheet date. The level of funding deficit calculated at the time could, subject to agreement between us and the pension scheme trustees, result in additional deficit repair contributions being required or possibly our offering more contingent assets or asset-backed contributions as further security. Any requirement to make significant immediate cash contributions into our defined benefit scheme to cover any such deficit could adversely affect our business, operations, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. Unanticipated actions by the pension regulator and/or any material revisions to existing pensions legislation could require accelerated and increased contributions to our defined benefit scheme which may restrict our financial flexibility. The pension scheme trustees could also seek accelerated and increased contributions should we plan to make material disposals or else fail to comply with certain financial covenants when raising additional debt. This could adversely affect our business, operations, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Section Title: RISKS RELATING TO OUR BUSINESS AND INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Obligation** **ROCs presented** **Headroom Period** **(in million ROCs)** **(in million ROCs)** **(in per cent.)
Subsubsection Title: We may become involved in legal proceedings which could have a material adverse effect on our reputation, financial condition, results of operation and cashflows.
Subsubsection Text: We may become involved in a variety of legal proceedings based on, for example, environmental, health and safety issues, land use and other matters. These may include complaints and statutory nuisance actions and claims by third parties based on their common law rights. Such complaints and actions may be related to issues such as personal injury, property damage, trespass, odour, emission and other such nuisances at our power stations, wood pellet manufacturing facility sites or biomass-from-waste facility. These types of lawsuits are often lengthy and can be expensive to defend. A successful third party claim could materially hinder our operations, prejudice our reputation and result in the imposition of penalties or substantial damages.

Section Title: RISKS RELATING TO OUR BUSINESS AND INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Obligation** **ROCs presented** **Headroom Period** **(in million ROCs)** **(in million ROCs)** **(in per cent.)
Subsubsection Title: Changes in tax laws or challenges to our tax position could adversely affect our results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to complex tax laws. Changes in tax laws could adversely affect our tax position, including our effective tax rate or tax payments. We often rely on generally available interpretations of applicable tax laws and regulations. There cannot be certainty that the relevant tax authorities are in agreement with our interpretation of these laws. If our tax position is challenged by the relevant tax authorities, the imposition of additional taxes could require us to pay taxes that we currently do not collect or pay or increase the costs of our services to track and collect such taxes, which could increase our costs of operations or our effective tax rate. The occurrence of any of the foregoing tax risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, operations, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Section Title: RISKS RELATING TO OUR BUSINESS AND INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Obligation** **ROCs presented** **Headroom Period** **(in million ROCs)** **(in million ROCs)** **(in per cent.)
Subsubsection Title: The Notes may not be a suitable investment for all investors seeking exposure to assets with sustainability characteristics and our climate transition plan may not be successful.
Subsubsection Text: The Notes are not being marketed as green bonds or sustainability bonds and thus may not satisfy an investor’s requirements for investment in assets with sustainability characteristics. There can be no guarantee that our transition to net zero emissions will be successfully realised. Moreover, while we have been recognised in the top 25 per cent. within our industry by rating environmental, social and governance (“ESG”) agencies like Sustainalytics and MSCI for our sustainability strategy and disclosure, their views may change or the standards around biomass may become more stringent. In addition, there are a variety of ESG rating agencies with differing methodologies. We expect to use the net proceeds of this offering to refinance our existing Senior Secured Notes due 2022 and our ESG Facility therefore we do not intend to allocate the net proceeds specifically to projects or business activities meeting environmental or sustainability criteria, or be subject to any other limitations associated with green bonds.

Section Title: RISKS RELATING TO OUR BUSINESS AND INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Obligation** **ROCs presented** **Headroom Period** **(in million ROCs)** **(in million ROCs)** **(in per cent.)
Subsubsection Title: The coronavirus outbreak and the responses thereto have adversely affected our business, operations and financial results, and the ultimate effects thereof on our business, operations and financial results remain highly uncertain; the emergence of new diseases could materially and adversely affect our business, operations and financial results.
Subsubsection Text: Covid-19 has spread throughout the world. On 11 March 2020, the World Health Organisation confirmed that its spread and severity had escalated to the point of pandemic. The Covid-19 pandemic, and the governmental and regulatory actions taken to mitigate its effects, has had a significant impact on many aspects of society and the global economy, and the duration and depth of this impact remain uncertain. 62 ----- The resulting market environment has led to a reduction in demand for power and gas during 2020, an increase in the costs of selling pre-contracted power back into the market, an increase in third party costs (e.g. Balancing Services Use of System charges, which relate to the costs of the day-to-day operation of the transmission system), a reduction in the amount of units of energy supplied and hence margin realized, and the increased risk of business failure and bad debt in the businesses we supply, all of which to date have primarily impacted our Customers segment. In the first half of 2020, our Customers segment reported a loss at an Adjusted EBITDA level of £37 million, which reflected the significant reduction in demand due to the Covid-19 pandemic, the costs associated with exiting hedged positions in the context of falling market prices and the increased risk of business failure and bad debt. Each of these, and other developments such as sustained local lockdown measures and those which have not yet been identified due to the uncertainties associated with Covid-19, could adversely affect our business. We have undertaken Covid-19 risk assessments in all parts of our business and have adjusted our working practices, by introducing widespread remote working and by implementing measures to safeguard all those who are still required to attend our operational sites to ensure compliance with the Government guidelines. Planned outages at our generation facilities have become more costly and time-consuming as a result of the physical restrictions required due to Covid-19, and the same would be the case for forced outages. Future projects and facilities upgrades may be cancelled or delayed as a result of Covid-19. We may take further actions required or advised by authorities or that we determine are in the best interests of our employees, contractors or suppliers. There is no certainty that such measures (or the measures that we have already put in place) will be sufficient to mitigate the risks posed by Covid-19, and the implementation of such measures (or their insufficiency) could harm our ability to perform critical functions. The unavailability of staff could adversely impact our operations, the continuity of service to customers and our reputation. As at the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Covid-19 pandemic has had significant impacts on the financial markets. The associated principal risks to us as a result of this volatility in the financial markets include weaker sterling affecting the cost of biomass in the long-term (over the next five years, the Group has forward hedged its currency requirements for its contracted and expected biomass requirements, protecting the Group from currency driven movements in biomass cost) and the liquidity risk associated with potential increases in borrowing costs and the availability of debt financing. The further economic impact of Covid-19 will depend on the continuing spread of the virus and the responses of the authorities and the global community. The degree to which the pandemic continues to impact our results will depend on future developments, which, as at the date of this Offering Memorandum, are highly uncertain and cannot be predicted. These developments may include, but are not limited to, the duration and spread of the outbreak, its severity, actions taken to contain the virus or treat its impact, the extent and effectiveness of economic stimulus packages and how quickly and to what extent normal economic and operating conditions can resume. In the medium- to long-term, if the spread of Covid-19 is prolonged, or new diseases emerge that give rise to similar macroeconomic effects, macroeconomic conditions will be adversely affected and could lead to further economic downturn in the countries in which we operate and the global economy more broadly (which could be widespread, severe and long lasting). Our supply chain has been disrupted as a result of the pandemic. As at the date of this Offering Memorandum, we have delayed some investments in our biomass supply chain due to the impact of Covid-19. Further, whilst our suppliers have largely managed to mitigate the impact of Covid-19, this position could deteriorate and result in disruption to the supply chain and the associated economic downturn could put us at increased risk of supplier failure. We continue to monitor and assess developments and the potential impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on our operations and financial performance. The factors described above could, together or individually, have a material and adverse impact on the business, results of operations and our financial condition which could be severe.

Section Title: RISKS RELATING TO OUR BUSINESS AND INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Obligation** **ROCs presented** **Headroom Period** **(in million ROCs)** **(in million ROCs)** **(in per cent.)
Subsubsection Title: The impact of climate change may materially adversely affect our business, operations, financial condition and results of operations
Subsubsection Text: According to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, global warming is likely to reach 1.5 degrees celsius as early as 2030, causing changes in the climate system with associated impacts. This may be manifested through the physical impacts of climate change on our operations, such as an increased incidence of extreme weather events. In early 2019, production at our US pellet business was restricted following weather-related events in the southern states of the US. There is also a risk that climate change policy, innovation and technology do not develop as expected, impacting delivery of the UK’s net zero ambition, and the Group’s strategy. In 63 ----- addition, increased governmental or public pressure to address any perceived environmental issues could damage our reputation and cause us to make additional investments in facilities and equipment. Any of the foregoing risks may adversely affect our business, operations, financial condition and results of operations.

Section Title: RISKS RELATING TO OUR BUSINESS AND INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Obligation** **ROCs presented** **Headroom Period** **(in million ROCs)** **(in million ROCs)** **(in per cent.)

Banking increases supply and thereby may impact prices in the following compliance year. Any oversupply of ROCs could therefore adversely affect our business, operations, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Total Sources of Funds . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** **226.7** **Total Uses of Funds  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** **226.7
Subsubsection Text: (1) Represents the pound sterling equivalent of the €250 million gross proceeds of the Notes offered hereby calculated using a currency exchange rate of €1.1027 to £1.00, which was the market rate on 30 June 2020, sourced from Reuters, used for the preparation of the balance sheet contained in the 2020 Drax Group Unaudited Financial Statements. (2) We intend to repay the 2022 Notes in full before 31 December 2020. (3) Represents estimated fees and expenses associated with the Offering, Initial Purchasers’ fees and commissions, professional fees and other transaction costs associated with the Offering. 81 -----

The gross proceeds from the Offering will be £226.7 million (equivalent), which represents the pound sterling equivalent of the €250 million gross proceeds of the Notes converted at a rate of €1.1027 to £1.00, which was the market rate on 30 June 2020, sourced from Reuters, used for the preparation of the balance sheet contained in the 2020 Drax Group Unaudited Financial Statements. We intend to use the gross proceeds of the Offering (i) for general corporate purposes, which may include the repayment of indebtedness, and (ii) to pay estimated fees and expenses of the Offering, including Initial Purchasers’ fees and commissions, professional fees and other associated transaction costs. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are an innovative electricity generation and supply business in the UK with the goal of enabling a zerocarbon, lower cost energy future. Over the last decade, we have undertaken the largest single site decarbonisation project in Europe as we converted four of the six generation units at Drax Power Station, historically the largest coal-fired power plant in Europe, to run on sustainable biomass, becoming the largest single-site generator of renewable electricity in the UK. We also expanded our business across the value chain through organic growth and complementary acquisitions and now have an integrated utility business model focused on renewable-led, lowcarbon and flexible power generation, the production of sustainable biomass wood pellets and the supply of renewable electricity, gas and other related services to business customers. Our business activities are grouped within three distinct segments: Generation, Pellet Production and Customers. Through our Generation segment, we own and operate a multi-site, multi-technology portfolio of power plants across the UK with a total generation capacity of approximately 6.5GW. We are the UK’s largest renewable generator and the fourth largest electricity generator in the UK based upon anticipated output (as published by the System Operator). We play a significant role in providing reliable, renewable and flexible electricity generation capacity along with increasingly important System Support Services, enhancing the security of the UK’s electricity supply and supporting the UK’s transition to a low-carbon future. Our generation assets include sustainable biomass, pumped storage, hydro and thermal power plants. In 2019, we produced 17.3TWh of electricity, out of which 79.2% came from renewable sources, 16.8% from natural gas and 3.5% from coal. Our generation assets are located across the UK, and we have options to develop further generation capacity in the UK. The multi-site, multi-technology nature of our generation assets and diversified fuel sources allow us to generate flexible and low-carbon electricity and enable us to provide System Support Services to the UK energy system. The System Operator has a growing need for System Support Services and we have a number of contracts in place with the System Operator to supply such services. We own and operate Drax Power Station, which is the largest power plant in the UK by generation capacity with an installed capacity of approximately 4.0GW. Drax Power Station is a critical part of the UK’s energy infrastructure, generating approximately 5 per cent of the UK’s total electricity, and 12 per cent. of the UK’s renewable electricity between January 2018 and December 2019. Based on the 2018-2019 compliance period, Drax Power Station is also the UK’s largest single-site generator of renewable electricity in the UK. Drax Power Station provides flexible and reliable generation and produced 14.0TWh of electricity in 2019, of which 96 per cent. was generated from sustainable biomass, making us a core part of the UK’s decarbonisation strategy. Between 2013 and 2016, we converted three coal-fired generation units at Drax Power Station to biomass-fired generation and in August 2018, we completed the conversion of a fourth coal-fired generation unit at Drax Power Station to biomass-fired generation (at a lower cost than that of converting each of the previous three biomass- fired generation units). Our four biomass-fired generation units receive regulatory support through the index- linked CfD and RO regimes, leading to enhanced earnings streams with a significant component of stable and predictable revenue extending to 2027. Our biomass-fired generation assets are served by an efficient and reliable biomass supply chain comprising dedicated port handling infrastructure and rail paths, thereby enhancing security of supply of fuel for our electricity generation activities. Following a comprehensive review of operations and discussions with National Grid, Ofgem and the Government, we have determined to end commercial coal generation at Drax Power Station in March 2021, with formal closure of coal units to occur in September 2022 at the end of existing Capacity Market obligation ahead of the UK’s 2025 deadline. Our hydropower generation assets include Cruachan pumped storage power plant and hydro power plants at Galloway and Lanark. Cruachan provides over 28 per cent. of the UK’s useable pumped storage capacity and is capable of generating 440MW of large-scale storage and flexible electricity continuously for 16 hours. It also provides contracted System Support Services to the UK electricity system and participates in the Balancing Mechanism, in addition to merchant power generation. In January 2020, Cruachan participated in the stability tender and won a six-year contract which commenced in July 2020 to provide System Support Services to the System Operator, and we are well-positioned to participate in forthcoming auctions for different support service requirements across the UK. The Galloway and Lanark hydro power plants are capable of generating up to a combined 126MW of stable renewable electricity. Lanark (17MW) receives regulatory support from the RO Scheme in respect of its full generation capacity, and Galloway (109MW) receives regulatory support from the RO Scheme with respect to approximately 28MW of its generating capacity, in addition to operating a reservoir and dam system providing power storage capabilities and opportunities for peaking and System Support Services. 89 ----- Our gas-fired generation assets include four CCGT power stations in southern and northern England. Our CCGT power stations at Damhead Creek (805MW), Rye House (715MW), Shoreham (420MW) and Blackburn Mill (60MW) provide baseload and peak power generation, in addition to other System Support Services. We are further responding to the growth in intermittent renewable capacity on the electricity grid by developing a pipeline of flexible generation options, including options to develop up to four 299MW rapid- response standalone OCGT projects and options to repurpose and repower one or both of our remaining coal- fired generation units at Drax Power Station to gas-fired generation. In addition, our Damhead Creek site benefits from an option for the development of a further CCGT asset, Damhead Creek II, which would provide us with an additional 1.8GW of gas generation capacity. We are also exploring an option to expand Cruachan pumped storage plant by up to 0.4GW. Each of these projects has the potential to provide flexible and reliable electricity to the UK electricity system and further diversify our future energy generation capability. However, each project is subject to our long-standing capital allocation policy which seeks to maintain robust financial metrics and a stable net leverage profile and would require an appropriate Capacity Market agreement in future Capacity Market auctions. Through our Pellet Production segment, we produce compressed wood pellets from sustainable sources such as managed forests and sawmill residue in three plants in the US Gulf region. These pellets are used as fuel for our biomass-fired generation in the UK and provided 22 per cent. of our total biomass requirement for the year ended 31 December 2019. The manufacturing process entails purchasing low-grade wood and residues from suppliers local to the manufacturing facilities and transforming them into pellets that can be transported costeffectively to Drax Power Station to generate low-carbon energy. All three of our wood pellet manufacturing facilities are certified under the industry standard Sustainable Biomass Program as producing legally and sustainably sourced biomass. Our wood pellet manufacturing facilities currently have a capacity of 1,475,000 tonnes which we aim to increase to 1,825,000 tonnes by 2021. We are targeting to self-supply five million tonnes of biomass per annum by 2027 as part of our broader initiative to reduce operating costs and expect this increased capacity to deliver returns significantly in excess of the Group’s cost of capital, with strong cash flow generation and fast payback. In furtherance of these objectives, we are investing in three new satellite plants in the US Gulf, which will utilise sawmill residues and leverage our existing US Gulf infrastructure to produce, we believe, biomass at around 20% below the current cost of production. In addition to sustainable biomass pellet plants, we own and operate dedicated port handling infrastructure and rail paths which allows us to achieve economies of scale and reduce the cost and carbon footprint of our operations by allowing us to aggregate small shipments from smaller suppliers into larger shipments, thereby reducing the overall carbon footprint of the relevant shipments. In addition to selfsupply from our manufacturing facilities, we have a network of third party suppliers of sustainable biomass pellets and have a number of long-term contracts with suppliers in North America and Europe to support a long-term, stable supply of biomass. 100 per cent. of the biomass used at Drax Power Station is from sustainable sources (such as sawmill residues, forest thinnings, low value roundwood and branches, but no saw logs are permitted to be used) and the use of SBP certification provides independent assurance that woody biomass is supplied from legal and sustainable sources and that all regulatory requirements in relation to biomass for energy production are met. Our Customers segment, comprising leading challenger brands Haven Power and Opus, is the fifth largest supplier of electricity to businesses in the UK by volume supplied as of 30 April 2020 and the largest provider of renewable energy to businesses. As of 1 October 2020, we supplied over 281,500 electricity and gas meters and, in 2019, we supplied 18.9TWh of electricity and gas. Our Customers segment had an 8 per cent. share of the B2B 90 ----- electricity market by volume of supply in Great Britain as at 30 June 2020 and provides us with a direct route to market for much of the electricity and RoCs we generate and a more diversified counterparty base with less concentrated counterparty credit risk than direct sales by our Generation segment in the wholesale market. We are committed to operating a sustainable business. We are continuing to make progress pioneering world-leading bioenergy with carbon capture and storage (“BECCS”), to deliver negative emissions and help the UK meet its 2050 net zero carbon target. BECCS can play an important role by removing CO2 from the atmosphere and safely storing it, creating negative emissions. The UK’s Committee on Climate Change (“CCC”) has clearly set out what is required for the country to achieve its legally binding objective of being net zero by 2050, including an important role for BECCS. In its response to the CCC report, the UK Government confirmed that there is widespread acceptance that carbon capture and storage has a key role to play in achieving net zero, and announced it is developing a new cross-government Biomass Strategy to assess how biomass should be used across the economy to contribute to the Government’s net zero target. We have identified, track and report on nine non-financial priorities that are material to our business and important to our stakeholders: carbon emissions; environmental impact; sourcing sustainable biomass; healthy forest landscapes; people and culture; health, safety and wellbeing; ethics and integrity and positive social impact. Our strategy is aligned with the UN Sustainable Development Goals and we have identified SDG numbers 7 (affordable and clean energy), 9 (industry, innovation and infrastructure), 11 (sustainable cities and communities), 13 (climate action), 15 (life on land) and 17 (partnerships for the goals) where we can have the greatest positive impact. To ensure the biomass we use meets the highest standards, we have set up an Independent Advisory Board (“IAB”) which provides independent advice in all areas of biomass sourcing and performance, and its role in achieving Drax’s ambition of being a carbon negative company. Our efforts have been recognised externally as we are a member of the FTSE4Good Index. In addition, Sustainalytics and MSCI, leading independent providers of environmental, social and corporate governance (“ESG”) research and ratings, have awarded Drax Group PLC an ESG Risk Rating of 25.9 (Medium Risk) and a relative performance ranking of 2nd out of 61 for Independent Power Production and Traders by Subindustry Group and AA respectively. The ESG Risk Rating and sector ranking of Drax Group PLC are subject to ongoing review by Sustainalytics and may be suspended, amended or withdrawn at any time. Sustainalytics is an independent ESG and corporate governance research provider and has provided the ESG Risk Rating research as set forth in the ESG Risk Rating Summary Report. Such information and data do not constitute an endorsement of any product or project, nor investment advice and are not warranted to be complete, timely, accurate or suitable for a particular purpose. The use of information developed [by  Sustainalytics  is  subject  to  conditions  available  at  https://www.sustainalytics.com/legal- disclaimers.](http://www.sustainalytics.com/legal-) The MSCI ratings information contained herein (the “Information”) has been sourced by MSCI ESG Research LLC, a Registered Investment Adviser under the Investment Advisers Act of 1940, or its affiliates or information providers (together, the “ESG Parties”), and it may not be reproduced or redisseminated in whole or in part without prior written permission. The Information has not been submitted to, nor received approval from, the US SEC or any other regulatory body.
