Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Impact of the Covid-19 Pandemic and Associated Responses on Our Business
Subsubsection Text: Covid-19 has spread throughout the world. On 11 March 2020, the World Health Organisation confirmed that its spread and severity had escalated to the point of pandemic. The Covid-19 pandemic, and the governmental and regulatory actions taken to mitigate its effects, has had a significant impact on many aspects of society and the global economy, and the duration and depth of this impact remain uncertain. The Covid-19 pandemic and associated lockdown and social distancing measures have adversely affected workforces, consumer sentiment, economies and financial markets around the world. The Covid-19 pandemic and the measures taken to reduce the spread of the virus have had and are likely to continue to have negative impacts on our business, particularly in our Customers segment, such as a significant reduction in demand from business customers, the increased cost associated with exiting hedged positions due to the drop in market prices, the increase in costs of selling pre-contracted power and gas back into the market, as well as the heightened risk of customer business failure and the increase in bad debt (from £12.5 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £26.2 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020), principally in the SME businesses we supply. Our Generation and Pellet Production segments were less affected by the outbreak of the Covid-19 pandemic and associated response measures; in the Generation segment, our contracted positions provided protection from lower demand and the reduction in ROC recycle prices was offset by increased System Support Services, while the Pellet Production segment was not affected as the fibre supply chains have been kept open throughout the pandemic and there was no reduction in demand, given that the segment’s sole customer is Drax Power Station. The increase in System Support Services reflects a reduction in demand for electricity caused by Covid-19, which has meant that the UK electricity system has become increasingly dominated by low marginal cost, intermittent and inflexible generation, such as wind, solar and nuclear, which requires the System Operator to take more actions to balance the system and contract System Support Services from flexible generators like the Group. The Covid-19 pandemic and associated response measures have resulted in an estimated reduction of approximately £44 million on our Group Adjusted EBITDA as of 30 June 2020, and we estimate a potential 2020 full year impact on the Group Adjusted EBITDA of approximately £60 million, which assumes that continued social distancing measures will remain in place throughout 2020 with local measures necessary in highly affected parts of the country. Our full year expectations for capital expenditure have reduced, with a number of projects delayed due to Covid-19. This includes non-essential works at Drax Power Station, and delayed timing of some investments in our biomass supply chain. There remains a range of potential outcomes for the Group’s financial performance in 2020 depending on the depth and duration of the wider economic downturn caused by Covid-19. The health, safety and wellbeing of all employees (all of which were classified as essential workers, both in the UK and in the US, and were thus able to continue carrying on their functions), contractors and visitors remains of paramount importance to us and we are taking all practicable actions to help them, whilst continuing to support the UK’s energy market. In respect of our Generation segment, reflecting its importance as critical national infrastructure, we have focused on being able to operate and generate whilst protecting our employees and contractors, and accordingly this has been, and is expected to continue to be, a matter of priority. Our Customers business has demonstrated that it can still operate effectively through remote working. The Group has adjusted its working practices, implemented new IT infrastructure to support those changes in working practices and tracked business performance. We have not sought any Covid-19-related financial support from any governmental authorities and none of our employees has been furloughed following the outbreak of the Covid-19 pandemic. We have modelled both a reasonable worst case and more extreme scenarios to test the Group’s financial resilience and none of the 92 ----- scenarios modelled would result in an impact to the Group’s liquidity, solvency, ratings or covenants that could not be remediated by taking mitigating action. However, it is recognised that Covid-19 continues to carry inherent uncertainties (as would any subsequent outbreak or pandemic) and the impacts continue to evolve, which could lead to further changes in government policy, macroeconomic policy and the behaviours of people and markets that may impact some risks. We continue to assess and monitor these risks and any evolving impact of Covid-19 on our operations and business, including impacts for all our stakeholders. See “Risk Factors—The _coronavirus outbreak and the responses thereto have adversely affected our business, operations and financial results, and the ultimate effects thereof on our business, operations and financial results remain highly uncertain; the emergence of new diseases could materially and adversely affect our business, operations and financial results.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: On 31 December 2018, we acquired the DGEL Group, a UK electricity generation business which owns and operates a portfolio of pumped storage, hydro and gas-fired electricity generation assets, including the Cruachan Power Station, one of only four pumped storage assets in the UK, run-of-river assets in Lanark and Galloway and gas-fired CCGT power stations at Damhead Creek, Rye House and Shoreham in the south of England and Blackburn Mill in the North. DGEL also owns SMW Limited, a company operating a biomass-from-waste facility on the outskirts of Glasgow. The assets and liabilities acquired were included in Drax’s consolidated balance sheet at 31 December 2018. Due to the timing of the DGEL Acquisition, no income, expenditure or cash flows were included in Drax’s consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended 31 December 2018 in respect of the DGEL Group. Furthermore, neither the £550 million drawn under the 2018 Bridge Facility after the balance sheet date on 2 January 2019 nor the £141.8 million reduction in cash in respect of the consideration paid (including both the original consideration of £137.0 million and £4.8 million of additional consideration agreed upon in 2019) were reflected in our consolidated net debt as at 31 December 2018, also due to the timing of the payment for the DGEL Acquisition. We incurred integration costs of £nil, £2.7 million and £9.0 million in respect of DGEL for the six months ended 30 June 2020 and 2019 and for the year ended 31 December 2019, respectively. See “Our _Business—Generation—DGEL: General” for more information regarding the DGEL Group._ In April 2017, as part of our strategy to supply Drax Power Station with up to 30 per cent. of its annual demand for wood pellets from our own production, we completed the acquisition of the LaSalle wood pellet facility in Louisiana, which was fully commissioned in the year ended 31 December 2018 and has a nameplate production capacity of 450,000 tonnes. Our Amite, Morehouse and LaSalle facilities produced approximately 753,000 tonnes of pellets in the six months ended 30 June 2020 compared to approximately 646,000 tonnes of pellets in the six months ended 30 June 2019, an increase of 15.4 per cent. period-on-period, and approximately 1,407 kilotonnes (“kt”) of pellets in the year ended 31 December 2019 compared to approximately 1,351 kt of pellets in the year ended 31 December 2018, up 4.1 per cent. year-on-year. In June 2019, we approved an investment of £50.0 million for the expansion of our Morehouse, Amite and LaSalle facilities. Such expansion projects are under way in our Morehouse and LaSalle pellet production facilities, and expansion works are expected to begin in our Amite facility in 2021. Furthermore, on 30 June 2020, we approved a $40 million investment in three new satellite pellet plants in the US Gulf region, which will utilise sawmill residues and leverage our existing infrastructure in order to increase production and reduce pellet costs. We expect the expansion of our existing pellet production facilities and our investment in these three new satellite pellet plans will provide an additional nameplate capacity of approximately 350,000 tonnes per annum and 120,000 tonnes per annum, respectively, by early 2022. In the year ended 31 December 2019, the cost of generation across our portfolio was £73.5 per MWh and, in the long-term, our aim is to reduce the cost of generation from self-supplied biomass to £50 per MWh by 2027.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: _Bark Spread, Clean Spark Spread, Dark Green Spread, Hydro and Pumped Storage_ The core elements to our Generation gross profit are the “bark spread” for electricity generated from biomass, the “clean spark spread” for electricity generated from gas, the “dark green spread” for electricity generated from coal and revenues from our hydro and pumped storage facilities. The “bark spread” is the wholesale electricity price plus renewable support, less the cost of sustainable biomass. The cost of sustainable biomass is the gross cost of purchasing the fuel, which includes the cost of the raw material, processing costs, logistics, handling and storage costs, and is influenced by exchange rates where the fuel is contracted in a foreign currency. The renewable support reflects the value of either the ROCs earned or 93 ----- payments under the CfD Regime through generating electricity from burning sustainable biomass. As a renewable fuel, sustainable biomass is exempt from the EU ETS and Carbon Price Support. The “clean spark spread” is the difference between the wholesale electricity price and the cost of gas and carbon, including emission allowances under the EU ETS and Carbon Price Support and exchange rate differences. The cost of gas and emissions allowances is dependent on market prices at the time the purchases are secured, typically at the same time the power sales take place. The UK’s status as a participant in the EU ETS following Brexit, or any future plan regarding carbon emission allowances or prices, is uncertain after the expiration of the Transition Period. See “—Factors Affecting Gross Margins—Fuel and Carbon Prices”. The “dark green spread” is the difference between the wholesale electricity price and the cost of coal and carbon, including emissions allowances under the EU ETS and the Carbon Price Support and exchange rate differences. The cost of coal and emissions allowances is driven by market prices at the time the purchases are secured. In February 2020, we announced that we expect our coal-fired commercial electricity generation to come to an end in March 2021, following which the “dark green spread” will no longer be a source of gross profit. Historically, revenues from our hydro assets have primarily reflected power sales from levels of electricity generation, which is dependent on rainfall levels and river management and the wholesale electricity price plus renewable support under the ROC Scheme. There is no cost of fuel associated with our hydro assets. The core margin from our Cruachan pumped storage asset was historically the difference between prices achieved through the generation of electricity and the cost of pumping to refill the reservoir at times of low demand. Our hydro assets continue to generate revenues from power sales, although an increasing proportion of their revenues is derived from System Support Services. _Generation Capacity, System Support and the Capacity Market_ With increasing levels of intermittent generation in the industry, we are continuing to identify opportunities to create value from our ability to flexibly operate our generation assets according to prevailing market conditions. This includes short-term power and balancing market activity and the provision of System Support Services on both a short and long-term basis, which are increasingly important for managing the UK electricity system. To capture value in this market, we continue to focus resources on optimising the availability and flexibility of all our generation assets. We compete with other generators for System Support Services contracts. Our margins from System Support Services amounted to £66.1 million, £60.7 million, £120.0 million and £56.9 million for the six months ended 30 June 2020 and 2019 and the years ended 31 December 2019 and 2018, respectively. The increase in the year ended 31 December 2019 was primarily due to the contribution from the DGEL Assets, which we acquired on 31 December 2018 and were fully consolidated in our results for 2019. The increase in the six months ended 30 June 2020 primarily reflects a period of very high winds in the first quarter of 2020 and the increased need for System Support Services following the outbreak of the Covid-19 pandemic in the second quarter, as the reduction in electricity demand has made the UK electricity system increasingly reliant on intermittent and inflexible generation options, such as wind, solar and nuclear power generation, all of which require the System Operator to take more actions to balance the system and contract System Support Services from flexible generators like the Group. Additionally, our Cruachan Power Station was successful in a stability tender for a six-year contract to provide System Support Services to the System Operator, starting in July 2020. We expect the demand for System Support Services to grow as the system decarbonises and becomes increasingly reliant on intermittent inflexible generation. Revenues from short-term power and balancing market activity, the provision of System Support Services and the use of out-of-specification fuels in our coal-fired generation assets are combined into the key performance indicator “value from flexibility”, and are tracked on this basis. In total, our value from flexibility was £66.0 million, £69.0 million, £129.0 million and £79.0 million for the six months ended 30 June 2020 and 2019 and the years ended 31 December 2019 and 2018, respectively. Under a Capacity Market agreement, a generator is entitled to fixed monthly payments in exchange for a commitment to deliver energy during a system stress event, which occurs when the System Operator has to resort to emergency actions in order to balance supply. In November 2018, the General Court of the European Union issued a ruling annulling the European Commission’s 2014 decision to approve the UK Government’s Scheme establishing the Capacity Market and imposed a “standstill period” while the European Commission completed a further “phase two” state aid investigation into the Capacity Market. Payments to generators under existing Capacity Market agreements and the holding of future capacity auctions were suspended as a result. The “phase 94 ----- two” investigation found that state aid was lawfully provided and the Capacity Market was reinstated in October 2019. The net impact of the Capacity Market suspension was a decrease of £6.8 million in our Adjusted EBITDA for the year ended 31 December 2018, which was ultimately recognised in our Adjusted EBITDA for the year ended 31 December 2019. Our revenue from the Capacity Market was £34.0 million for the six months ended 30 June 2020, compared to £nil in the six months ended 30 June 2019 (in 2019, £36.7 million of such income due in respect of the first half of the year was not recognised until the reinstatement of the Capacity Market in October 2019). For the year ended 31 December 2019, our revenue from the Capacity Market was £78.1 million (including £6.8 million related to the period in 2018 subsequent to the Capacity Market suspension), compared to £8.5 million for the year ended 31 December 2018. Prior to the DGEL Acquisition, the DGEL Group received £11.7 million in Capacity Market revenues for the year ended 31 December 2018. See “Risk Factors—Risks _Relating to Our Business and Industry—The reduction or abandonment of governmental support for generation of electricity from biomass or other forms of renewable generation or other relevant changes in governmental energy policy may materially adversely affect our business, operations, financial condition and results of operations”._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: _Electricity prices_ The wholesale electricity price is affected by a variety of factors, including the price of underlying commodities such as oil, natural gas and emissions allowances, the availability and type of generating capacity (and, in particular, the level of intermittent generation from sources such as wind and solar compared to baseload generation from gas and nuclear power stations), the level of demand and wider macroeconomic conditions. A power station’s cost of generation is determined largely by the cost of the type of fuel used, which can be susceptible to market forces and vary significantly. Some power producers have negative costs of generation, such as those which generate electricity using wind or solar, as the renewable support provided to these renewable generators exceeds the cost of generation. Power plants can be modelled, according to their different costs of generation, as a stack, which is overlaid with forecasted demand for electricity. The available power producers are drawn on to generate electricity to fulfil this demand, starting with those that have the lowest costs of generation. At the point in the demand stack where forecast demand intersects with available supply, the type of generator supplying electricity at the point of intersection is known as the “marginal plant”. The price at which the marginal power plant is willing to generate therefore dictates the overall market price. Since 2016, we have seen significant volatility in the electricity price. This is largely attributable to fluctuations in the cost of carbon and gas prices. The cost of carbon for fossil fuel generators increased as a result of a significant increase in the price of emissions allowances under the EU ETS, from approximately €4 per tonne of CO2 on certain days in September 2016 to over €25 per tonne of CO2 on certain days in February 2020. Gas prices increased in 2018 following an increase in demand for gas generation due to lower-than-expected liquified natural gas (“LNG”) deliveries, reduced wind throughout the Summer Season and low nuclear output across Europe, and substantially decreased since the beginning of the 2019 Winter Season due to mild weather across the northern hemisphere, high wind generation and increased LNG supplies. Additionally, the high levels of intermittent generation capacity on the system results in thermal generation being displaced in some periods (by generation without a cost of fuel, such as wind generation) but being required in others. As of 22 July 2020, we had contracted fixed price power sales (including both forward sold electricity and gas proxy hedges) of approximately 17.6TWh, 11.4TWh, and 4.8TWh for delivery in 2020, 2021 and 2022, respectively. Average achieved prices for fixed price power sales of forward sold electricity in 2020, 2021 and 2022 were £53.8 per MWh, £49.0 per MWh and £48.2 per MWh, respectively. During periods of low electricity prices, the electricity price that we can achieve in the market may not cover our costs of fuel in our thermal plant and, in the case of generation from coal and gas, the cost of carbon. As a result, it may be more economical for us to idle, or reduce the load factor on, all or some of our generating assets. The continuing increase in generation from intermittent renewables such as wind or solar power, combined with the continuing decrease in available conventional generation capacity due to the retirement of older, less efficient and mostly coal-fired power stations, has resulted in more volatile wholesale electricity prices. This volatility presents an opportunity for generators like the Group that can produce significant amounts of electricity at relatively short notice at times of peak demand, for example, at times of lower production from intermittent renewables due to adverse weather conditions. We expect that the increasing trend of intermittent renewables generation, coupled with a decrease in conventional generation, in particular from coal-fired power stations (given the UK Government’s intention to 95 ----- end electricity generation from unabated coal by 1 October 2024), will continue in the short-to-medium term and will continue to contribute to less liquidity in forward wholesale markets and more volatile wholesale electricity prices in the UK generally. _Fuel and carbon prices_ The spot market prices for wood pellets increased in the year ended 31 December 2018 and reached approximately $200 per tonne of wood pellet in the first quarter of 2019 due to a shortage caused by unseasonal weather, followed by a decrease to approximately $160 per tonne of wood pellet in the last quarter of 2019 and a further decrease to approximately £135 per tonne of wood pellet in the second quarter of 2020, due to the impact of Covid-19 on prices. We were partially protected from these fluctuations in price by our focus on long-term contracts and self-supply. Our average cost of biomass fuel, before the impact of costs of emissions allowances, the Carbon Price Support and ROC support, was approximately £78.2 per MWh in the six months ended 30 June 2020, compared with approximately £74.8 per MWh, £76.3 per MWh and £74.2 per MWh in the six months ended 30 June 2019 and the years ended 31 December 2019 and 2018, respectively. In addition, we have recently engaged in several initiatives aimed at increasing the operational efficiency of our facilities and reducing the cost of our self-supply of sustainable biomass pellets from our Pellet Production segment to our Generation segment. For example, we have entered into a co-location agreement with Hunt Forest Products to develop a sawmill next to our LaSalle site, which commenced production in February 2019 and has provided us greater access to low-cost sawmill residues, lower transportation costs and a reduction in the number of stages in the pellet production process. We also commissioned a new rail spur linking the LaSalle facility to the regional rail network and our port facility at Baton Rouge in May 2019, which also aims at achieving economies of scale and reducing both our costs and carbon footprint. At the port of Baton Rouge, as part of a cooperative endeavour with the port of Greater Baton Rouge and the state of Louisiana, we are commissioning an upgraded chambering yard in 2020 that will allow 80-car train sets to continue to operate from our LaSalle and Morehouse sites, further increasing our economies of scale in rail. These initiatives and others have contributed to a reduction in our biomass cost by $15.6, or 9.2 per cent., from $169.7 per tonne in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to $154.1 per tonne in the six months ended 30 June 2020. In June 2019, we approved an investment of £50.0 million in the expansion of our Morehouse, Amite and LaSalle pellet production facilities. Such expansion projects are under way in our Morehouse and LaSalle pellet production facilities, and expansion works are expected to begin in our Amite facility in 2021. Furthermore, on 30 June 2020, we approved a $40 million investment in three new satellite pellet plants in the US Gulf region, which will utilise sawmill residues and leverage our existing infrastructure in order to increase production and reduce pellet costs. As part of the programme of improvements, efficiencies and investments we have previously identified we believe we will reduce the cost of biomass by £13 per MWh on our existing portfolio by 2022 compared to 2018, assuming a constant exchange rate. In the year ended 31 December 2019, the cost of generation across our portfolio was £73.5 per MWh and, in the long-term, our aim is to reduce the cost of generation from self-supplied biomass to £50 per MWh by 2027, and we continue to progress a number of initiatives in furtherance of this aim. We are generally protected from short-term volatility in foreign exchange rates, due to having an active rolling five-year foreign exchange hedging programme with respect to the currencies in which fuel and carbon prices are denominated (predominantly US dollars, Canadian dollars and euro). Additionally, our focus on long- term contracts and our increasing proportion of self-supply, which enables an ability to adjust production at our selfsupplied biomass facilities to take advantage of attractively priced spot cargoes and provides protection from fluctuations in wider fibre and biomass prices. The cost of carbon in the dark green spread is made up of two elements, the cost of emissions allowances under the EU ETS and Carbon Price Support. The market price of emissions allowances under the EU ETS increased significantly in 2018 and remained higher in 2019 and in the first half of 2020 than in the prior period as a result of the introduction of the Market Stability Reserve in January 2019, aimed at addressing the current surplus of allowances by reducing the supply of allowances to be auctioned, and also due to the future expected value of emissions allowances, which is influenced by political developments. New market entrants and the switching of generation from gas to coal by some generators due to high gas prices also contributed to the increased market price of emissions allowances. The average cost of emissions allowances in support of coal- fired generation was approximately £19.1 per MWh in the six months ended 30 June 2020 compared to approximately £7.8 per MWh in the six months ended 30 June 2019. The Carbon Price Support rate for the first year of operation (2013/2014) was £4.94/tonne, increasing to £9.55/tonne in 2014/2015 and £18.10/tonne in 2015/16; however, the Carbon Price Support price has been capped at £18.00/tonne from 2016 until 2021. In 96 ----- January 2019, the UK Government reaffirmed that the UK will continue to maintain a total carbon price (the combined Carbon Price Support and the EU ETS) until such time as unabated coal-fired generation in the UK has ceased. As a result of the withdrawal of the UK from the EU, it is unclear what the UK’s legislative and regulatory framework in relation to carbon emissions and carbon pricing will be following the end of the Transition Period. In particular, the UK’s status as a participant in the EU ETS following the Transition Period is unclear. The UK Government has indicated that it is continuing to develop options for long-term carbon pricing, including establishing a UK ETS (linked to the EU ETS or standalone) or introducing a carbon tax. Previously, in October 2019, the UK Government had published its response to its consultation on the future of carbon pricing and set out its preferred approach, which included securing a linking agreement with the EU for a linked UK ETS. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to our Business and Industry—Changes in governmental policy, regulation or _legislation in relation to carbon emissions and carbon pricing may materially adversely affect our business, operations, financial condition and results of operations.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: We receive a significant proportion of our revenues from wholesale electricity sales from Drax Power Station, and for periods beginning on or after 1 January 2019, from wholesale electricity sales from the generation facilities acquired in connection with the DGEL Acquisition. Our revenues are therefore affected by the amount of generation at these facilities, which is in turn underpinned by the availability of these facilities to generate when market conditions dictate that it is economical to do so. Availability of the generating units at our generating assets is impacted by planned maintenance outages, as well as unplanned or forced outages, which are required from time to time to rectify malfunctions or other failures, or other safety-related incidents. Forced outages decrease the amount of electricity that a relevant generation unit is able to generate over a given period, which translates into decreased potential revenue for us. Furthermore, additional costs may be incurred in recovering from any such forced outage, and such costs may be increased by the social distancing measures in place due to Covid-19 to make sure the work is carried out safely. Each of our six generation units at Drax Power Station typically has a planned outage every four years and these outages are usually scheduled for the summer months, when electricity demand and power prices are lower. In the UK power generation industry, the “summer” season comprises the calendar months April to September (the “Summer Season”), and the “winter” season comprises the calendar months October to March (the “Winter Season”). Our maintenance regime for the traditional turbine generator assets at our hydro facilities typically includes annual inspections, minor planned outages every four years and major planned outages every 12 years to complement a routine preventative maintenance regime. We currently plan to undertake a major planned outage on our CfD unit at Drax Power Station (including a high pressure turbine upgrade) and have completed an outage at our Damhead Creek CCGT power station and a number of smaller planned outages across our wider generation fleet in 2020. Reflecting the physical restrictions and the increased costs in carrying out outages as a result of the outbreak of the Covid-19 pandemic and associated response measures, a planned turbine upgrade at our Shoreham Power Station has been postponed until 2021. We expect that none of these outages will have a notable impact on profitability (excluding operating expenditure) given that generation from our biomass units is commercially constrained by the operation of the ROC cap and the seasonality of the outages, which are concentrated in the Summer Season when electricity demand is lower. We also sometimes experience unplanned outages. The most frequent cause of a forced outage of a thermal generation unit is a boiler tube leak in that generation unit. For example, such leaks have occurred at Drax Power Station approximately 20 times a year over the last five years and ordinarily take two to three days to remedy. However, more severe forced outages can take a longer time to remedy. For instance, in December 2017 a fire on a biomass conveyor between Drax Power Station’s rail unloading facility and its biomass storage domes resulted in an unplanned outage and cessation of generation on two biomass generating units for a period of approximately four weeks. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—We are dependent on continued _output from our facilities and outage at any of our facilities could negatively affect our business, operations, prospects, financial condition and results of operations”._ During the six months ended 30 June 2019, we undertook a major planned outage at our fourth biomass unit, followed by a major outage at our second biomass unit in July 2019. We also undertook a planned outage at our Rye House CCGT power station and a minor inspection at our Damhead Creek CCGT power station during the year ended 31 December 2019. We undertook no major planned outages during the six months ended 30 June 2020, which improved our profitability in this period. The biomass availability for the year ended 31 December 2018 was impacted by unplanned outages during the first quarter of 2018 due to a fire in December 2017 in our biomass rail unloading facilities and an unplanned 97 ----- outage at one of our biomass units. Availability for 2018 was also impacted by a planned outage of one coal unit and the conversion of a fourth unit from coal to biomass. During the six months ended 30 June 2019, we also managed lower levels of biomass availability due to high levels of rainfall in the US Gulf, which restricted the level of commercial forest extraction and the availability of low-cost fibre for wood pellet production. The resulting adverse impact of restricted biomass generation in the first half of 2019 was partially offset by optimisation of our biomass generation under the RO Scheme and higher levels of biomass generation in the second half of 2019. During the six months ended 30 June 2020, there have been no significant issues with biomass availability.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: _Renewables_ Revenue from our first, second and fourth biomass-fired generation units at Drax Power Station is supported by the RO Scheme, while the third biomass-fired generation unit is supported by the CfD Regime. Our Galloway and Lanark hydro assets are also supported by the RO Scheme, though the Galloway hydro facility receives ROCs only with respect to approximately 28MW of its 109MW capacity, with the remainder being available for participation in the Capacity Market. The RO Scheme is a market-based mechanism that was introduced in 2002 to support the deployment of large scale renewable energy in the UK. The RO Scheme requires licensed electricity suppliers to submit a specified number of ROCs to Ofgem per MWh of electricity they supply or to make a buy-out payment (which increases annually in line with the UK Retail Price Index). ROCs are issued by Ofgem to accredited renewables generators for each MWh of renewable electricity generated. The number of ROCs received by a generator per MWh of electricity produced differs depending on the type of renewable generation technology utilised. We receive one ROC per MWh of electricity generated from each of our units that is supported by the RO Scheme, though Drax Power Station is subject to an overall station-level ROC cap. This cap is set annually at such a level that the incremental amount of ROCs received by Drax Power Station as a result of the conversion in 2018 of our fourth generation unit to biomass is, and will continue to be, lower than the average number of ROCs we had received in generation from the first two units we converted to biomass under the RO Scheme. Each of our facilities currently supported under the RO Scheme is eligible to receive ROCs until March 2027, at which point we will lose support under this regime. For more information on ROCs, see “Industry _Overview—UK clean energy legislation—Operation of the renewables obligation” and “Risk Factors—Risk Factors Relating to Our Business and Industry—The reduction or abandonment of governmental support for generation of electricity from biomass or other forms of renewable generation or other relevant changes in governmental energy policy may materially adversely affect our business, operations, financial condition and results of operations”._ ROCs are tradable certificates that have no fixed price, so the amount an electricity supplier pays for a ROC is negotiated between the generator and supplier. However, the buy-out payment that a supplier would have to make if it failed to present a sufficient number of ROCs to Ofgem effectively sets a price cap on ROCs and historically the purchase price paid to generators by suppliers has been marginally lower than the buy-out payment. Each ROC is also entitled to a share of the buy-out fund, in which all buy-out payments from suppliers are pooled and then recycled back to suppliers in proportion to the number of ROCs they have validly submitted toward discharging their obligation in the relevant period. Many of our contracts for the sale of ROCs to suppliers contain a provision that requires the supplier to pass the recycle payment received by the supplier following submission of the ROC to Ofgem on to us. The value of ROC generation was negatively impacted by a reduction in ROC recycle in the six months ended 30 June 2020 due to reduced demand during the Covid-19 lockdown. Revenues from the external sale of ROCs amounted to £327.5 million, £309.6 million, £733.7 million and £664.5 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020 and 2019 and the years ended 31 December 2019 and 2018, respectively. External ROC sales increased in the six months ended 30 June 2020 and the year ended 31 December 2019 with respect to the respective prior corresponding periods mainly as a result of actions taken to accelerate the timing of cash flows from ROCs. Where we choose to sell ROCs to accelerate cash flows, we may choose to purchase ROCs at a later date for submission by our Customers segment, ultimately leading to a similar offsetting charge in cost of sales. Our CfD provides a variable top-up to a reference price which reflects average wholesale electricity prices over a certain period. Our CfD was entered into between Drax Power and the Low Carbon Contracts Company Limited, a limited company owned by the UK Government (the “LCCC”), as the CfD counterparty, under which payments are made by reference to a fixed price for each MWh of electricity produced, known as the “strike price”. Our CfD has a term until 2027, at which time biomass generation will cease to be supported under the 98 ----- CfD scheme and, as of 1 April 2020, provided for a strike price of £116.49 per MWh compared to a strike price of £113.65 per MWh as of 1 April 2019. The strike price is adjusted annually on 1 April to reflect consumer price inflation and system balancing costs in the UK. Under the CfD, we sell the electricity in the wholesale market, and when the reference price (which is an average price and therefore not directly related to the price at which we sell the underlying electricity) is below the strike price, we receive a top-up payment from the LCCC for the additional amount we generate and when the reference price is above the strike price, we must pay back the difference it generates to the LCCC. _Generation_ In January 2018, the UK Government reaffirmed its intention to phase out electricity generation from coal by 2025 in order to reduce overall carbon dioxide emissions, and announced the introduction of an emissions intensity limit, which will make generation from unabated coal units uneconomical. More recently, the UK Government announced its intention to bring the deadline for ending unabated coal generation forward to 1 October 2024, although no specific arrangements have been put in place yet. Against the background of these plans, we announced in February 2020 that we expect commercial electricity generation from coal at Drax Power Station to end by March 2021, although our two remaining coal units would remain available to fulfil Capacity Market obligations until September 2022, well ahead of the UK Government’s deadline. Following our decision to end commercial coal generation in March 2021, an impairment review was undertaken for the coal generation assets CGU and we recognised an asset obsolescence charge of £224.2 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020 in respect of the coal generation assets CGU. See “—Depreciation of Coal-Specific Assets”. The IED sets limits on rates of emissions (hourly, daily and monthly) on the amount of NOx, SO2 and particulate matter that we can emit from Drax Power Station and our CCGT power stations. We must ensure that the generation profile of our thermal generation assets operates within such limits. The limits reflect achievable emissions rates from plants such as Drax Power Station and our CCGT power stations, and each of our facilities remains compliant with them. We are focused on meeting the requirements of the Best Available Techniques Reference Document for Large Combustion Plants, published in August 2017 (“BREF”). BREF has reduced air emission limits and further reductions are due mid-2021. The type and quality of fuel used in generation and the load factor of the generation units have an impact on the amount of NOx and other gases released by Drax Power Station and our CCGT power stations. We also have selective non-catalytic reduction technology fitted to five of Drax Power Station’s six generation units which can, at a cost, be turned on to reduce NOx emissions. However, ultimately, if Drax Power Station or one of our CCGT power stations were about to exceed one of the applicable annual limits, we would have to reduce the level of otherwise profitable generation.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Following the UK Government’s consultation to end unabated electricity generation from coal by 2025 (recently brought forward to 1 October 2024), we completed the conversion of a further coal-fired generation unit to biomass in August 2018 at a cost of approximately £29 million (which was lower than the cost of converting each of the previous three biomass-fired generation units as the domes had already been built). In February 2020, we announced that we expect our coal-fired commercial electricity generation to come to an end in March 2021, although our two remaining coal units would remain available to fulfil Capacity Market obligations until September 2022. Accordingly, we have adapted the maintenance and upgrade schedule for our two remaining coal-fired generation units and expect our annual capital expenditure to maintain operational performance with respect to these units to continue to be lower than those seen in past years. We are also working on the expansion of our existing three pellet plants (LaSalle, Morehouse and Amite) by 350,000 tonnes in aggregate over the next two years, amounting to an estimated aggregate investment of £50.0 million. These projects aim to expand total capacity to around 1.85Mt, provide economies of scale and allow greater utilisation of low-cost residues, in order to support our goal of reducing the cost of our sustainable biomass pellets. On 30 June 2020, we approved a $40 million investment in three new satellite pellet plants in the US Gulf region, which will utilise sawmill residues and leverage our existing infrastructure in order to increase production and reduce pellet costs. We expect our investment in these three new satellite pellet plans will provide an additional nameplate capacity of approximately 120,000 tonnes per annum by early 2022. The majority of our recurring capital expenditure is concentrated in the Generation segment. In contrast, the operations of the Pellet Production segment and the Customers segment require relatively small amounts of capital expenditure to maintain operational performance. Within the Generation segment, recurring capital 99 ----- expenditures mainly relate to scheduled maintenance work, periodic replacements and unscheduled repairs. See also “—Depreciation of Coal-Specific Assets” below. See “—Liquidity and Capital Resources—Capital Expenditure” for a discussion of our expectations relating to future capital expenditure. Our results of operations are also affected by our operating and administrative expenses. In the six months ended 30 June 2020 and 2019 and the years ended 31 December 2019 and 2018, operating and administrative expenses (excluding bad debt charges) were £196.2 million, £213.2 million, £439.3 million and £320.0 million, respectively. The increase in the year ended 31 December 2019 compared to the year ended 31 December 2018 was primarily due to costs associated with our acquisition of the DGEL assets, a planned outage at our Rye House CCGT power station and a minor inspection at our Damhead Creek CCGT power station during 2019, while the decrease in the six months ended 30 June 2020 compared to the six months ended 30 June 2019 was primarily due to the absence of major planned outages and major acquisitions during the six months ended 30 June 2020.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: We are exposed to commodity price, foreign currency exchange rate, interest rate and inflation rate risks in the course of our business and financing activities. We seek to hedge our exposure to these risks by entering into derivative financial instruments where appropriate. For example, we had outstanding derivative financial instruments with an aggregate notional value (based on the undiscounted net cash inflows/outflows) of £4,485.1 million and £4,821.5 million, respectively, as of 31 December 2019 and 2018. During the six months ended 30 June 2020, the pound sterling depreciated significantly against the US dollar following the outbreak of the Covid-19 pandemic. The market value of our derivative contracts was positively affected by these shifts in exchange rates and we recognised a non-cash, unrealised gain in our income statement, cost of hedging reserve and hedge reserve for the six months ended 30 June 2020 as a result of the higher mark-tomarket values of these hedging arrangements at the end of such period relative to the beginning of the year. During the six months ended 30 June 2019, the pound sterling depreciated slightly against the US dollar. The market value of our derivative contracts was positively affected by these shifts in exchange rates and we recognised a non-cash, unrealised gain in our income statement, cost of hedging reserve and hedge reserve for the six months ended 30 June 2019 as a result of the higher mark-to-market values of these hedging arrangements at the end of such period relative to the beginning of the year. During the year ended 31 December 2019, the pound sterling appreciated slightly against the US dollar. The market value of our derivative contracts was adversely affected by these shifts in exchange rates and we recognised a non-cash, unrealised loss in our income statement, cost of hedging reserve and hedge reserve for the year ended 31 December 2018. During the year ended 31 December 2018, the pound sterling depreciated significantly in part due to uncertainty around the UK’s withdrawal from the European Union. The market value of our derivative contracts was positively affected by these shifts in exchange rates and we recognised a non-cash, unrealised gain in our income statement, cost of hedging reserve and hedge reserve for the year ended 31 December 2018 as a result of the higher mark-to-market values of these hedging arrangements at year-end relative to the beginning of the year. We are extensively hedged against foreign currency volatility until the end of 2024. Should there be any renewed and prolonged weakness in the pound sterling beyond this period, it may lead to higher fuel prices for us.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Electricity generation and supply are affected by seasonality. Demand in the UK for electricity and gas is typically higher, and thus drives higher electricity prices and dispatch, in the Winter Season when temperatures are colder. Conversely, demand is typically lower in the Summer Season, when temperatures are higher, thus driving lower electricity prices and dispatch. This trend is experienced by all of our UK-based businesses, as they variously operate within the UK electricity and gas markets, and is most notable within our Generation segment due to its scale and the flexible operation of coal-fired plants when prices are low in the Summer Season. The performance of DGEL’s pumped storage and hydro assets could also be impacted by unseasonal or extreme weather conditions. Our hydro generation facilities are dependent upon hydrological conditions prevailing from time to time in the geographic regions in which our hydro facilities are located. Our Pellet Production segment 100 ----- has a regular production and dispatch schedule, which generally insulates it from demand fluctuations caused by seasonality, although unseasonal weather can reduce the availability of raw materials to produce wood pellets as our fibre suppliers may experience difficulties or may be unable to access harvesting sites. Overall, as a result of these seasonal patterns, profit margins are lower in the Summer Season, partially offset by a related reduction in working capital requirements, with any fluctuations in our cash flow cycle principally managed through cash at hand or borrowings under our debt facilities.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: In February 2020, we announced that we expect our coal-fired commercial electricity generation to come to an end in March 2021, although our two remaining coal units would remain available to fulfil Capacity Market obligations until September 2022, in each case well ahead of the UK Government’s deadline (currently intended for 1 October 2024). Following the closure decision, an impairment review was undertaken for the coal generation assets CGU. This review indicated that the recoverable amount of the coal assets, calculated with reference to a value in use calculation based on the Group’s latest approved forecasts, was significantly lower than their carrying value. An asset obsolescence charge of £224.2 million has been recognised in the Drax Group Unaudited Financial Statements as of 30 June 2020 in respect of the coal generation assets CGU. There were no reasonably possible changes in the assumptions underlying the value in use calculation that would have resulted in a material change to the value of the asset obsolescence charge. The asset obsolescence charge has been treated as an exceptional item and excluded from the Group’s Adjusted results. In August 2018, we completed the conversion of our fourth generation unit from coal to biomass at Drax Power Station, leading us to write down £26.8 million of coal-specific assets relating to such unit for the year ended 31 December 2018.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our operating results are affected by a combination of economic, regulatory and industry and companyspecific factors. Economic conditions influence electricity demand, the pricing of fuel, electricity, biomass, fibre residues and other commodities and emissions allowances, which affect both our revenues and the costs associated with our operations. The regulatory framework determines the parameters in which the industry, generally, and we, specifically, operate. Industry-specific factors include technology, competition, capacity, government subsidy programmes and supply/demand balance. Factors that specifically impact our operating results include, but are not limited to, acquisitions, plant reliability and efficiency, capital expenditure levels, the ability to benefit from subsidies for the generation of electricity from renewable sources, the ability to receive revenues from the provision of System Support Services (which includes balancing market activities, portfolio optimisation and ancillary services) and the Capacity Market and the extent to which we have hedged our exposure to commodity, foreign exchange and interest rate risks. The most important of such factors are discussed below.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Comparability of Financial Information
Subsubsection Text: As described in note 8.3 to the 2019 Drax Group Audited Financial Statements, the Group has adopted IFRS 16 from 1 January 2019, using the modified retrospective method of adoption. The new requirements have impacted the Group’s accounting for lease contracts. The Group’s lease portfolio predominantly relates to properties and the hire of plant and equipment at operating sites. On transition to IFRS 16 on 1 January 2019, assets controlled under lease contracts were brought onto the balance sheet as right-of-use assets, and the Group has recognised a corresponding liability for the amounts payable under its lease contracts. Comparative information for the year ended 31 December 2018 has not been restated. Under the previous accounting standards, operating leases were expensed to the income statement on a systematic basis over the lease term (in the year ended 31 December 2018, £6.3 million was expensed to operating expenses for the operating lease rentals). Under IFRS 16, operating leases are recognised on the balance sheet as right-of-use assets with a corresponding lease liability, resulting in a reduction in operating expenses by £7.4 million in 2019 and an equivalent amount of improved EBITDA in the same year. As at 1 January 2019, right-of-use assets of £37.1 million were recognised and presented separately in the balance sheet (which includes £0.6 million of lease assets recognised previously under finance leases that were reclassified from property, plant and equipment) and additional lease liabilities of £37.6 million were recognised separately on the balance sheet (including £0.5 million previously recognised as finance leases that were reclassified from borrowings). Prepayments of £0.1 million and trade and other payables of £0.7 million related to previous operating leases were derecognised.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Comparability of Financial Information
Subsubsection Text: As discussed above under “—Sources of Gross Profit—Generation Capacity, System Support and the Capacity _Market”, the General Court of the European Union imposed a “standstill period” in November 2018 and the_ Capacity Market was not reinstated until October 2019. Following the reinstatement of the Capacity Market in October 2019, we recognised £78.1 million of income from Capacity Market Payments in the year ended 31 December 2019, including £6.8 million of such income relating to the period in 2018 subsequent to the suspension of the Capacity Market. The net impact of the Capacity Market suspension was a decrease of £6.8 million in our Adjusted EBITDA for the year ended 31 December 2018, which was ultimately recognised in our Adjusted EBITDA for the year ended 31 December 2019. Our revenue from the Capacity Market was 101 ----- £34.0 million for the six months ended 30 June 2020, compared to £nil in the six months ended 30 June 2019 (in 2019, £36.7 million of such income due in respect of the first half of the year was not recognised until the reinstatement of the Capacity Market in October 2019). For the year ended 31 December 2019, our revenue from the Capacity Market was £78.1 million (including £6.8 million related to the period in 2018 subsequent to the Capacity Market suspension), compared to £8.5 million for the year ended 31 December 2018. Prior to the DGEL Acquisition, the DGEL Group received £11.7 million in Capacity Market revenues for the year ended 31 December 2018. See “—Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Generation Capacity and _System Support” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—The reduction or abandonment of governmental support for generation of electricity from biomass or other forms of renewable generation or other relevant changes in governmental energy policy may materially adversely affect our business, operations, financial condition and results of operations”._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Comparability of Financial Information
Subsubsection Text: The comparability of our financial information from year to year is affected by the acquisitions and pellet production investments we have made since 1 January 2018. For more information as to the effect of these initiatives on our financial results, see “—Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Acquisitions, Dispositions and _Pellet Production Investments” and “—Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations— Other Acquisitions, Dispositions and Pellet Production Investments”._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Comparability of Financial Information
Subsubsection Text: The total tax credit for the six months ended 30 June 2020 was £5.0 million (compared to £0.4 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019) and includes a charge of £9.8 million due to the revaluation of deferred tax balances following the reversal of the reduction in UK tax rates to 17 per cent. from 1 April 2020. In 2020, the Group falls into the new arrangements in respect of corporation tax payments for very large companies in the UK for the first time. As a result, the Group must now make tax payments earlier than under the previous regime. Cash taxes paid in the six months ended 30 June 2020 were £24.3 million higher than for the six months ended 30 June 2019. This includes the one-time impact in the year of transition.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our management uses a number of key financial and non-financial performance indicators to track the performance of our business. The principal key performance indicators we monitor are Adjusted Revenue, Adjusted Gross Profit, Adjusted EBITDA and net debt. Additionally, we rely on commercial availability to track the performance of our Generation segment, Customers business contribution to track the performance of our Customers segment and the cost per gigajoule (“GJ”) of biomass produced (in $/GJ) to track the performance of our Pellet Production segment. Adjusted Revenue, Adjusted Gross Profit, Adjusted EBITDA and net debt are not accounting measures within the scope of IFRS. We define Adjusted Revenue and Adjusted Gross Profit, respectively, as revenue and gross profit, excluding the impact of certain remeasurements on derivative contracts which are not designated as hedging instruments under IFRS. We define Adjusted EBITDA as profit/loss for the year before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation excluding the impact of exceptional items and certain remeasurements. For an explanation of the items excluded from Adjusted EBITDA for the six months ended 30 June 2020 and 2019 and the years ended 31 December 2019 and 2018, see “Presentation of Financial Information and Other Information—Non-IFRS Financial _Measures”. We define net debt as current and non-current borrowings and overdrafts (net of deferred finance costs)_ less cash and cash equivalents. See “Presentation of Financial Information and Other Information—Non-IFRS _Financial and Other Information”._ The following table sets forth certain key performance indicators for the Drax Group for the six months ended 30 June 2020 and 2019 (restated) and for the years ended 31 December 2019 and 2018 (restated), respectively.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Revenue represents amounts receivable for goods or services provided to customers in the normal course of business, net of trade discounts, VAT and other sales-related taxes and excluding transactions with or between Drax Group companies. Revenues from the sale of electricity by the Generation segment are measured based upon metered output delivered at rates specified under contract terms or prevailing market rates, as applicable. ROCs earned from the biomass-fired generation units are initially recognised as a reduction in the Generation segment’s biomass fuel costs and subsequently recognised as revenue when the ROC is sold to a third party. Income or costs arising from the CfD are recognised in the income statement as a component of revenue at the point we meet our performance obligations under the CfD contract. Revenue from the sale of electricity and gas directly to business customers through the Customers segment is recorded after deduction of agreed discounts, VAT and CCL. Revenue is recognised on the supply of electricity or gas when a contract exists, supply has taken place, a quantifiable price has been established or can be determined and the receivables are expected to be recovered at the point of sale. Energy supplied, but not yet measured or billed, is estimated based on consumption statistics and consumption price estimates. Revenue for contracts satisfied over time is recognised in line with the progress of those contracts. The measurement of progress is based on cost inputs for fixed price contracts from the Customers segment, and volume supplied for other contracts. Assumptions are applied consistently but third-party costs can be variable, therefore actual outcomes may vary from initial estimates. Other revenues derived from the provision of services to National Grid (for example, the supply of System Support Services) are recognised by reference to the stage of completion of the contractual performance obligations. Most such contracts are for the delivery of a service either continually or on an ad hoc basis over a 105 ----- period of time and thus stage of completion is calculated by reference to the amount of the contract term that has elapsed. Depending on the contract terms, this approach may require judgment in extrapolating probable future outcomes. Other revenues derived from the sale of goods (for example, by-products from electricity generation such as ash and gypsum) are recognised at the point the control of goods is transferred to the customer. All sales of the Pellet Production segment are intra-group sales and are eliminated upon consolidation.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Cost of sales consists of the cost of fuel required for electricity generation, the cost of transportation, the cost of raw materials for the production of wood pellets, the cost of electricity purchases from third parties, grid charges payable to the System Operator and the operator of the electricity transmission network in Great Britain and other retail costs. In the Generation segment, cost of fuel is the principal driver of cost of sales and represents the cost of purchasing the sustainable biomass that is used to generate electricity in Drax Power Station (net of any ROC support earned) and coal (including the cost of carbon). ROCs earned from the biomass-fired generation units are initially recognised as a reduction in the Generation segment’s biomass fuel costs at the point of generation, and the subsequent revenue is recognised at the time of sale of the ROC. Frequently, the Generation segment also purchases electricity from the market either when it is more economical to do so because the market price for electricity is lower than our marginal cost of production or when delivery obligations cannot be met by our own generation. Grid charges mainly comprise distribution, transmission and system balancing costs. In the Customers segment, cost of sales is mainly driven by electricity purchases. The Customers segment purchases a significant proportion of its electricity requirement from the Generation segment under intra-group electricity purchase agreements. Other costs of sales include third-party costs such as grid charges, the costs of meeting our obligations under the RO and small-scale Feed-in-Tariffs (“SS-FiT”) schemes required to demonstrate the supply of renewable source electricity, CCL-exempt energy to customers. Grid charges reflect costs of distribution, transmission and system balancing costs. In the Pellet Production segment, cost of sales is principally influenced by the price and type of raw fibre used in producing the wood pellets. Our wood pellet manufacturing facilities can process various types of raw fibre from primary sources (such as thinnings, tops and harvesting residues) or secondary sources (such as chips, shavings or sawdust), with secondary sources generally being more cost-effective compared to primary sources. Other costs of sales in the Pellet Production segment comprise costs of transport and other costs related to the production process.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Gross profit represents the difference between revenue and cost of sales.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Operating and administrative expenses primarily consist of staff costs (such as wages and salaries, social security costs, other pension costs and share-based payments) and repairs and maintenance expenditure on property, plant and equipment.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Provisions for impairment of trade receivables are measured at an amount equal to the lifetime expected credit loss. Impairment losses on trade receivables are disclosed separately on the face of the income statement.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: The fair value of a derivative contract at a point in time is generally the difference between the price we have secured in the contract and the price we could achieve in the market at that time. Derivative contracts qualify for the own use exemption if they are contracts for the delivery of physical commodities entered into and held for our own purchase, sale or usage requirements (e.g., contracts for the purchase of sustainable biomass or physical coal). Derivative contracts that qualify for the own use exemption are not accounted for at fair value and therefore not included in certain remeasurements on derivative contracts. In addition, changes in the fair value of derivative contracts that qualify as effective hedges under relevant IFRS standards are accounted for in the hedge reserve and not in certain remeasurements on derivative contracts in the income statement. 106 ----- Fair value movements relating to forward basis points and the time value of money of options are designated as a “cost of hedging” and these movements are recognised as a component of other comprehensive income.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Adjusted EBITDA represents profit/loss for the year before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation, excluding the impact of exceptional items and certain remeasurements. See “Presentation of Financial Information _and Other Information—Non-IFRS Financial Measures” for more information and an explanation of differences in_ the definition of Adjusted EBITDA across financial periods.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Depreciation represents the systematic allocation of the cost of a tangible asset, or other amount substituted for cost, less its residual value, over its useful life. Amortisation represents the systematic allocation of the cost of an intangible asset, or other amount substituted for cost, less its residual value, over its useful life.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Foreign exchange gains and losses arise on the retranslation of non-derivative balances and investments denominated in foreign currencies to prevailing rates at the balance sheet date.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Interest payable and similar charges reflect expenses incurred in managing our debt structure (such as interest payable on our bank loans) as well as the unwinding of discount on provisions for the reinstatement of our sites at the end of their useful lives, amortisation of deferred finance costs, net interest charges on our defined benefit pension scheme obligations and other financing charges.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Interest receivable represents income generated through the use of short-term cash surpluses, for example through investments in money market funds.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: The total tax charge includes both current and deferred tax. Current tax is the estimated amount payable on the taxable profits of the relevant year (which is adjusted for items upon which we are not required to pay tax or, in some cases, for items which are not allowable for tax purposes and therefore on which we are required to pay additional tax). Deferred tax is an accounting adjustment which reflects whether more or less tax is expected to arise in the future due to differences between the accounting and tax rules. The tax charge reflects the estimated effective tax rate on profit before tax for the relevant year and the movement in the deferred tax charge in that year, so far as it relates to items recognised in the income statement.
