Subsubsection Title: Six Months Ended 30 June 2020 Compared to Six Months Ended 30 June 2019
Subsubsection Text: Group _Revenue_ Total revenue, after eliminations for intra-group sales, decreased by £13.3 million, or 0.6 per cent., from £2,232.4 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £2,219.1 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020. This decrease was primarily due to the decrease in electricity and gas sales in our Customers segment following the outbreak of the Covid-19 pandemic, from £1,125.8 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £1,031.6 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020, partially offset by £34.0 million in Capacity Market income (compared to £nil in the six months ended 30 June 2019 related to the period in 2019 during which the Capacity Market was suspended) and an increase in our CfD income from £117.0 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £159.6 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020, primarily due to the increased availability of our CfD unit to 87.8 per cent. over the period, reaching 99.5 per cent. in the three months ended 30 June 2020. Adjusted Revenue (which excludes the impact of certain remeasurements on derivative contracts which are not designated as hedging instruments under IFRS, which resulted in gains of £13.8 million and £5.8 million for the six months ended 30 June 2020 and 2019, respectively) decreased by £21.3 million, or 1.0 per cent., from £2,226.6 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £2,205.3 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020. _Cost of sales_ Total cost of sales decreased by £157.7 million, or 8.4 per cent., from £1,867.3 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £1,709.6 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020, primarily due to certain remeasurements on derivative contracts which are not designated as hedging instruments under IFRS, which 108 ----- decreased total cost of sales by £98.9 million (reflecting a remeasurement credit of £94.5 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020 compared to a charge of £4.4 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019), the decrease in the cost of power and gas purchases in our Customers segment from £498.3 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £435.8 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020 due to the decrease in electricity and gas sales following the outbreak of the Covid-19 pandemic, and the mark-to-market losses from exiting hedged positions, also linked to lower demand in our Customer segment following the outbreak of the Covid-19 pandemic. The above factors were partially offset by increased fuel costs in our Generation segment (as more biomass was burnt due to the increase in generation output), from £586.8 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £668.7 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020 and the increase in other costs in our Customers segment from £321.4 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £336.1 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020. Adjusted Cost of Sales (which excludes the impact of certain remeasurements on derivative contracts which are not designated as hedging instruments under IFRS) decreased by £58.8 million, or 3.2 per cent., from £1,862.9 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £1,804.1 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020. _Gross profit_ Total gross profit increased by £144.4 million, or 39.6 per cent., from £365.1 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £509.5 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020, reflecting the movements in revenue and cost of sales, and including a remeasurement credit of £108.3 million on derivative contracts which are not designated as hedging instruments under IFRS, compared to a credit of £1.4 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019. Adjusted Gross Profit, which excludes the impact of certain remeasurements on derivative contracts which are not designated as hedging instruments under IFRS, increased by £37.5 million, or 10.3 per cent., from £363.7 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £401.2 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020. _Operating and administrative expenses_ Operating and administrative expenses decreased by £17.0 million, or 8.0 per cent., from £213.2 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £196.2 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020, primarily due to the reduction in repair and maintenance work associated with the absence of any major planned outages in the six months ended 30 June 2020, compared to one major planned outage at our fourth biomass unit carried out in the six months ended 30 June 2019, as well as strategic operating expenditures in the Customers segment in the six months ended 30 June 2019, which did not recur in the six months ended 30 June 2020. _Impairment losses on trade receivables_ Impairment losses on trade receivables increased by £13.7 million, or 109.6 per cent., from £12.5 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £26.2 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020, reflecting the anticipated impacts of increased business failure and bad debt following the outbreak of the Covid-19 pandemic and associated response measures, resulting in a closing provision, after adjusting for actual credit losses, of £51.6 million at 30 June 2020, compared to £40.7 million at 31 December 2019. The provision is based on a consistent methodology, adjusted to reflect our initial experience and assumptions in respect of cash collections and potential customer business failures in the period since lockdown measures due to the Covid-19 pandemic came into effect in March 2020. _Adjusted EBITDA_ Adjusted EBITDA increased by £40.8 million, or 29.6 per cent., from £138.0 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £178.8 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020, primarily due to the reinstatement of the Capacity Market in October 2019 (including the recognition of £34.0 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020 compared to £nil in the six months ended 30 June 2019, during which time the Capacity Market was suspended), higher levels of biomass generation, System Support Services and increased pellet production and delivery (from approximately 585,000 tonnes delivered during the six months ended 30 June 2019 to approximately 748,000 tonnes delivered during the six months ended 30 June 2020), largely due to industry-wide challenges with biomass production and supply in the first half of 2019. This increase was partially offset by lower demand and lower prices in our Customers segment following the outbreak of the Covid-19 pandemic, which we estimate has resulted in a reduction of £44.0 million in the Group Adjusted EBITDA in the six months ended 30 June 2020. 109 ----- _Depreciation and amortisation_ Depreciation and amortisation charges decreased by £6.9 million, or 6.7 per cent., from £102.6 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £95.7 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020, mainly reflecting the reduction in depreciation charges following the write-down of the remaining coal assets in February 2020. _Asset obsolescence charges_ In the six months ended 30 June 2020, we incurred £224.2 million of asset obsolescence charges following our decision to cease commercial coal generation at Drax Power Station in March 2021, reflecting the limited residual value of our coal-generating assets following such decision. This charge was recognised as an exceptional item and thus excluded from the Group’s adjusted results for such period. _Acquisition and restructuring costs_ Acquisition and restructuring costs decreased by £2.7 million, or 100.0 per cent., from £2.7 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £nil in the six months ended 30 June 2020. In the six months ended 30 June 2019, acquisition and restructuring costs reflected the post-acquisition costs of integrating the new assets acquired as part of the DGEL Acquisition into the Group. _Operating profit/(loss)_ Total operating profit decreased by £66.0 million, from a profit of £34.1 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to a loss of £31.9 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020. This increase was primarily due to asset obsolescence charges of £224.2 million in relation to our coal-generating assets, partially offset by the impact of certain remeasurements on derivative contracts (which are not designated as hedging instruments under IFRS), reflecting movements in the mark-to-market position on our portfolio of commodity and financial derivative contracts representing a gain of £108.3 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020, compared to a gain of £1.4 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019. Adjusted operating profit increased by £48.6 million, or 137.3 per cent., from £35.4 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £84.0 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020, primarily reflecting the increase in Adjusted EBITDA and a reduction in depreciation charges in the three months ended 30 June 2020 following the write-down of the coal assets described above, partially offset by the increase in impairment losses on trade receivables. _Foreign exchange gains_ Foreign exchange gains increased by £0.5 million, from £3.5 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £4.0 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020. _Interest payable and similar charges_ Total interest payable and similar charges decreased by £1.2 million, or 3.5 per cent., from £34.5 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £33.3 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020. This was primarily due to the decrease of unwinding of discount on provisions by £3.7 million, partly offset by the increase in amortisation of deferred finance costs by £1.6 million. Adjusted interest payable and similar charges (which excludes the impact of debt restructuring costs associated with the refinancing of the Group’s debt) increased by £1.1 million, or 3.4 per cent., from £32.2 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £33.3 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020. _Interest receivable_ Interest receivable increased by £0.1 million, from £0.4 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £0.5 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020. _Tax_ Our total tax credit increased by £4.6 million, from £0.4 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £5.0 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020. The total tax credit for the six months ended 30 June 2020 is composed of a tax charge of £12.7 million on Adjusted pre-tax profits and a tax credit of £17.7 million in relation to derivative remeasurements and exceptional items. The total tax credit includes a charge of £9.8 million due to revaluation of deferred tax balances following the reversal of the reduction in UK tax rates to 17 per cent. from 110 ----- 1 April 2020, £4.3 million of which relates to coal assets impaired in the period and is therefore included in the exceptional tax charge. The effective tax rate applicable to the Group’s Adjusted pre-tax profits, before taking into account the effect of changes in tax rates, of 13 per cent. is lower than the standard rate of corporation tax in the UK, primarily due to tax relief under the Patent Box Scheme in respect of the use of a patent within our Generation business. The Adjusted Tax Credit/Charge (which excludes the tax impact of exceptional items and certain remeasurements on derivative contracts which are not designated as hedging instruments under IFRS) changed by £13.4 million, from a credit of £0.7 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to a charge of £12.7 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020. The £12.7 million charge in the six months ended 30 June 2020 was primarily due to a significant increase in Adjusted profit before tax from £7.1 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £55.6 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020. Benefits of £4.0 million and £4.0 million were recognised during the six months ended 30 June 2019 and 2020, respectively, due to tax relief under the Patent Box Scheme, which resulted in a lower effective tax rate than the standard corporation tax rate in the UK. Cash taxes paid (net of refunds) during the six months ended 30 June 2020 were £31.6 million, compared to £7.3 million for the six months ended 30 June 2019, reflecting the one-time impact of the Group falling into the new arrangements in respect of corporation tax payments for very large companies in the UK for the first time, as a result of which the Group must now make tax payments earlier than under the previous regime. _Profit for the year_ Total profit after tax for the year, calculated in accordance with IFRS, decreased by £59.6 million, from a profit of £3.9 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to a loss of £55.7 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020, reflecting the factors discussed above. Excluding the impact of certain remeasurements on derivative contracts and the effect of exceptional items (asset obsolescence charges in the six months ended 30 June 2020; acquisition and restructuring costs and debt restructuring costs in the six months ended 30 June 2019, including, in each case, taxes thereon), Adjusted profit after tax increased by £35.1 million, or 450.0 per cent., from £7.8 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £42.9 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020. Operating Segments The following table shows a breakdown of our gross profit and Adjusted EBITDA by operating segment for the six months ended 30 June 2020 and 2019, respectively.

Subsubsection Text: (1) Our revenue and cost of sales includes certain remeasurements on derivative contracts which are not designated as hedging instruments under IFRS which comprise gains or losses on derivative contracts to the extent that those contracts do not qualify for hedge accounting, or hedge accounting is not effective, and those gains or losses are either (i) unrealised and relate to the delivery of commodity contracts in future periods, or (ii) are realised in relation to the delivery of commodity contracts in the current period. The effect of excluding certain remeasurements from results of operations is to reflect commodity sales and purchases at contracted prices— i.e., at the all-in-hedged amount paid or received in respect of the delivery of the commodity in question. (2) We define Adjusted EBITDA as profit/loss for the year before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation, excluding the impact of exceptional items and certain remeasurements. As a result of the temporary suspension of the Capacity Market, Adjusted EBITDA for the six months ended 30 June 2019 does not include £36.7 million of Capacity Market income due in respect of the first half of the year that was not recognised until the reinstatement of the Capacity Market in October 2019, and Adjusted EBITDA for the year ended 31 December 2019 includes £6.8 million related to the period in 2018 subsequent to the Capacity Market suspension. See “Presentation _of Financial Information and Other Information—Non-IFRS Financial Measures” for more information. For a reconciliation from_ profit/loss for the year to Adjusted EBITDA, please see “—Key Performance Indicators”. (3)   For the year ended 31 December 2019, represents primarily insurance proceeds from property damage. For the year ended 31 December 2018, represents a credit relating to contingent consideration in connection with our OCGT projects. (4) For the six months ended 30 June 2019 and the year ended 31 December 2019, represents costs associated with the integration of DGEL into the Group. For the year ended 31 December 2018, represents costs associated with the acquisition and integration of DGEL into the Group (£21.0 million), closure of our Atlanta office to relocate the US head office to Monroe, Louisiana (£3.6 million) and certain restructuring costs in our Customers segment (£3.0 million). (5) Includes the cost of debt restructure, which comprises costs associated with the refinancing of our debt, within interest payable and other similar charges. Cost of debt restructure was £nil, £2.5 million, £5.2 million and £7.2 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020 and 2019 and the years ended 31 December 2019 and 2018, respectively.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Year Ended 31 December 2019 Compared to Year Ended 31 December 2018
Subsubsection Text: Group _Revenue_ Total revenue, after eliminations for intra-group sales, increased by £484.4 million, or 11.5 per cent., from £4,229.0 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to £4,713.4 million in the year ended 31 December 2019. This increase was primarily due to £359.1 million of revenue from our new portfolio of pumped storage hydro and gas-fired generation assets integrated into the group as part of the DGEL Acquisition (which includes £46.3 million of Capacity Market income), £31.7 million of Capacity Market income related to Drax Power Station (including £6.8 million of income relating to the period in 2018 subsequent to the suspension of the Capacity Market) and increased ROC sales (£733.7 million in the year ended 31 December 2019 compared to £664.5 million in the year ended 31 December 2018). Overall renewable support under the CfD and ROC regimes in the year ended 31 December 2019 remained broadly in line with the prior period as higher ROC generation and indexation of support payments was offset by a decrease in our CfD income due to an outage over the Summer Season at one of our biomass units at Drax Power Station. Adjusted Revenue (which excludes the impact of certain remeasurements on derivative contracts which are not designated as hedging instruments under IFRS, which resulted in gains of £10.5 million and losses of £8.3 million for the year ended 31 December 2019 and 2018, respectively) increased by £465.6 million, or 11.0 per cent., from £4,237.3 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to £4,702.9 million in the year ended 31 December 2019. _Cost of sales_ Total cost of sales increased by £389.5 million, or 10.9 per cent., from £3,589.6 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to £3,979.1 million in the year ended 31 December 2019, primarily due to £191.9 million of cost of sales from the assets integrated into the group following the DGEL Acquisition. Certain remeasurements on derivative contracts which are not designated as hedging instruments under IFRS increased total cost of sales by £190.0 million (which reflects a remeasurement charge of £143.3 million in the year ended 31 December 2019 compared to a credit of £46.7 million in the year ended 31 December 2018). The above factors were partially offset by increased operational efficiencies, mainly at our LaSalle wood pellet facility. Adjusted Cost of Sales (which excludes the impact of certain remeasurements on derivative contracts which are not designated as hedging instruments under IFRS) increased by £199.5 million, or 5.5 per cent., from £3,636.3 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to £3,835.8 million in the year ended 31 December 2019. _Gross profit_ Total gross profit increased by £94.9 million, or 14.8 per cent., from £639.4 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to £734.3 million in the year ended 31 December 2019, reflecting movements in revenue and cost of sales and including a £167.2 million gross profit contribution from our new portfolio of pumped storage hydro and gas-fired generation assets integrated into the group as part of the DGEL Acquisition, as well as £132.8 million on derivative contracts which are not designated as hedging instruments under IFRS, compared to a credit of £38.4 million in the year ended 31 December 2018. Adjusted Gross Profit, which excludes the impact of certain remeasurements on derivative contracts which are not designated as hedging instruments under IFRS, increased by £266.1 million, or 44.3 per cent., from £601.0 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to £867.1 million in the year ended 31 December 2019. _Operating and administrative expenses_ Operating and administrative expenses increased by £119.3 million, or 37.3 per cent., from £320.0 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to £439.3 million in the year ended 31 December 2019, primarily due to 113 ----- operating and administrative costs of £52.8 million associated with the assets integrated into the Group as part of the DGEL Acquisition, a planned outage at our Rye House CCGT power station and a minor inspection at our Damhead Creek CCGT power station during 2019. In addition, the increase reflects a high volume of repair and maintenance work at Drax Power Station (including two major planned outages at two of our biomass units in 2019), higher costs in the Pellet Production segment associated with increased volumes produced and an increase in central costs (which includes incremental research and innovation costs associated with key strategic initiatives, including BECCS), as well as one-off costs of implementing a new organisational structure to enable us to execute our strategy more effectively. _Impairment losses on financial assets_ Impairment losses on financial assets decreased by £13.4 million, or 42.7 per cent., from £31.4 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to £18.0 million in the year ended 31 December 2019, reflecting improved cash collection performance in the Customers segment, as well as the impact of a one-off £3.0 million charge in the year ended 31 December 2018 associated with Opus and a one-off £6.1 million benefit in the year ended 31 December 2019 in respect of the resolution of legacy customers’ credit balances and a change to the underlying provisioning methodology. _Adjusted EBITDA_ Adjusted EBITDA increased by £160.2 million, or 64.2 per cent., from £249.6 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to £409.8 million in the year ended 31 December 2019, primarily due to the new assets integrated into the Group as part of the DGEL Acquisition, the reinstatement of the Capacity Market (including the recognition in the year ended 31 December 2019 of £6.8 million of income related to the period in 2018 during which the Capacity Market was suspended), as well as improved value from flexibility and the increased production at each of our US wood pellet manufacturing facilities, partially offset by lower power sales in our Customers segment, mainly due to a mild 2018/2019 Winter Season resulting in lower coal generation (which had, however, limited margin impact), higher operating expenses in the Customers segment and higher central costs. _Depreciation and amortisation_ Depreciation and amortisation charges increased by £34.1 million, or 19.6 per cent., from £173.8 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to £207.9 million in the year ended 31 December 2019, mainly reflecting the new generation assets integrated into the group as part of the DGEL Acquisition. _Asset Obsolescence Charges_ In the year ended 31 December 2018, we incurred £26.8 million of asset obsolescence charges in respect of the conversion of the fourth unit at Drax Power Station from coal to biomass. These costs were excluded from the Group’s adjusted results for the year ended 31 December 2018. No similar charges were incurred in the year ended 31 December 2019. _Acquisition and restructuring costs_ Acquisition and restructuring costs decreased by £18.7 million, or 67.5 per cent., from £27.7 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to £9.0 million in the year ended 31 December 2019. In the year ended 31 December 2018, this category included transaction and integration costs associated with the DGEL Acquisition and restructuring costs in the Customers and Pellet Production segments. In the year ended 31 December 2019, acquisition and restructuring costs reflected the first-year post-acquisition costs of integrating the new assets acquired as part of the DGEL Acquisition into the Group. _Operating profit_ Total operating profit increased by £2.1 million, or 3.5 per cent., from £59.9 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to £62.0 million in the year ended 31 December 2019. This increase was primarily due to the growth in Adjusted EBITDA described above. In addition, total operating profit includes the impact of certain remeasurements on derivative contracts (which are not designated as hedging instruments under IFRS) and items treated as exceptional in the period. In the year ended 31 December 2019, acquisition and restructuring costs of £9.0 million were treated as exceptional. The impact of certain remeasurements in the year ended 31 December 114 ----- 2019 was a loss of £132.8 million, compared to a gain of £38.4 million in the year ended 31 December 2018. This principally reflected the appreciation of sterling against the US dollar during the year ended 31 December 2019, reducing the value of our forward currency contracts. Adjusted Operating Profit increased by £127.8 million, or 168.2 per cent., from £76.0 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to £203.8 million in the year ended 31 December 2019, primarily reflecting the increase in Adjusted EBITDA, partially offset by the increase in depreciation and amortisation charges. _Interest payable and similar charges_ Total interest payable and similar charges increased by £18.9 million, or 39.7 per cent., from £47.6 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to £66.5 million in the year ended 31 December 2019. This increase was primarily due to the issuance of debt to part-fund the DGEL Acquisition. Adjusted Interest payable and similar charges (which excludes the impact of debt restructuring costs associated with the refinancing of the Group’s debt) increased by £20.9 million, or 51.7 per cent., from £40.4 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to £61.3 million in the year ended 31 December 2019. Costs associated with the restructuring of the Group’s debt was reduced by £2.0 million, from £7.2 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to £5.2 million in the year ended 31 December 2019. _Foreign exchange gains/(losses)_ Foreign exchange gains and losses increased by £0.1 million from a gain of £0.3 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to a gain of £0.4 million in the year ended 31 December 2019. _Interest receivable_ Interest receivable increased by £0.1 million from £1.2 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to £1.3 million in the year ended 31 December 2019. _Tax_ Our total tax credit decreased by £3.1 million, or 48.4 per cent., from a tax credit of £6.4 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to a tax credit of £3.3 million in the year ended 31 December 2019, primarily as a result of adjustments in respect of prior periods, despite a reduction in total profit before tax. The Adjusted Tax Credit/Charge (which excludes the tax impact of exceptional items and certain remeasurements on derivative contracts which are not designated as hedging instruments under IFRS) changed by £28.9 million, from a credit of £4.8 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to a charge of £24.1 million in the year ended 31 December 2019. The £24.1 million charge in the year ended 31 December 2019 was primarily due to a significant increase in Adjusted profit before tax from £37.1 million to £142.2 million. Benefits of £8.1 million and £8.0 million were recognised during the years ended 31 December 2018 and 2019, respectively, due to tax relief under the Patent Box Scheme in respect of the use of a patent within our Generation business, which resulted in a lower effective tax rate than the standard corporation tax rate in the UK. Cash taxes paid (net of refunds) during the year ended 31 December 2019 were £9.6 million compared to £1.0 million for the year ended 31 December 2018, which reflects the timing of payments on account. _Profit for the year_ Total profit for the year, calculated in accordance with IFRS, decreased by £19.7 million, or 97.5 per cent., from a profit of £20.2 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to a profit of £0.5 million in the year ended 31 December 2019, reflecting the factors discussed above. Excluding the impact of certain remeasurements on derivative contracts and the effect of exceptional items (acquisition and restructuring costs, debt restructuring costs and asset obsolescence charges in the year ended 31 December 2018), Adjusted profit after tax increased by £76.2 million, or 181.9 per cent., from £41.9 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to £118.1 million in the year ended 31 December 2019. 115 ----- Operating Segments The following table shows a breakdown of our gross profit and Adjusted EBITDA by operating segment for the years ended 31 December 2018 and 2019, respectively.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: 111 ----- _Generation_ Gross profit for the Generation segment increased by £56.1 million, or 21.4 per cent., from £261.7 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £317.8 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020. Adjusted EBITDA for the Generation segment increased by £66.6 million, or 45.1 per cent., from £147.6 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £214.2 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020. These increases primarily reflect the reinstatement of the Capacity Market in October 2019 (including the recognition of £34.0 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020 compared to £nil in the six months ended 30 June 2019 during which period the Capacity Market was suspended), higher levels of biomass generation (from 6.4 TWh in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to 7.4 TWh in the six months ended 30 June 2020 with CfD income up from £117.0 million to £159.6 million over the same period due to increased availability), as well as increased Systems Support Services income (from £60.7 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £66.1 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020), as the reduction in electricity demand due to the Covid-19 pandemic has made the UK electricity system increasingly reliant on intermittent and inflexible generation options, such as wind, solar and nuclear power generation, all of which require the System Operator to take more actions to balance the system and contract System Support Services from flexible generators like the Group. These increases were partially offset by increased fuel costs (from £586.8 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £668.7 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020) and increased grid charges (from £23.1 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £37.9 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020). _Customers_ Gross profit for the Customers segment decreased by £41.1 million, or 57.5 per cent., from £71.5 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £30.4 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020. Adjusted EBITDA for the Customers segment decreased by £45.6 million, from £8.8 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £(36.8) million in the six months ended 30 June 2020. These decreases primarily reflect the impact of the outbreak of the Covid-19 pandemic and related responses in our Customers business, mainly due to reduced electricity and gas sales (from 9.7 TWh in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to 8.8 TWh in the six months ended 30 June 2020), the increase in costs incurred to exit previously hedged positions by £15.0 million and the increase in expected credit losses on trade receivables (from £12.5 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £26.2 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020), reflecting the anticipated impacts of increased business failure and bad debt following the outbreak of the Covid-19 pandemic. These decreases were partially offset by a decrease in operating costs (from £50.2 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £41.1 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020). _Pellet Production_ Gross profit for the Pellet Production segment increased by £20.1 million, or 61.1 per cent., from £32.9 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £53.0 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020. Adjusted EBITDA for the Pellet Production segment increased by £17.2 million, or 226.3 per cent., from £7.6 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £24.8 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020. These increases primarily reflect the increased output from approximately 646,000 tonnes of wood pellets produced in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to approximately 753,000 tonnes in the six months ended 30 June 2020, reflecting good fibre availability compared to the first six months of 2019 which were adversely impacted by weather, $3.4 million of insurance proceeds received in respect of a business interruption claim due to weather disruptions in the six months ended 30 June 2019, as well as the reduction in the cost of production from $169.7 per tonne of wood pellets in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to $154.1 per tonne of wood pellets in the six months ended 30 June 2020, mainly due to operational efficiencies as a result of our co-location agreement with Hunt Forest Products to develop a sawmill next to our LaSalle site and the new rail spur linking our LaSalle facility to the regional rail network and our port facility at Baton Rouge, as well as the improvement of pellet quality, as measured by the level of fines (larger particle-sized dust) in each cargo, reflecting our focus on incremental improvements to our process. These increases were partially offset by an increase in operating costs, from $32.8 million (£25.4 million applying the average rate for the period) in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to $35.6 million (£28.2 million applying the average rate for the period) in the six months ended 30 June 2020. 112 ----- _Central costs_ Central costs affecting our Adjusted EBITDA decreased by £0.2 million, or 0.8 per cent., from £23.6 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019 to £23.4 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020. This decrease primarily reflects a reduction in corporate costs, partially offset by an additional £2 million of incremental research and development expenditure associated with key strategic initiatives (including BECCs) during the six months ended 30 June 2020.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Generation_ Gross profit for the Generation segment increased by £253.5 million, or 64.0 per cent., from £396.0 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to £649.5 million in the year ended 31 December 2019. Adjusted EBITDA for the Generation segment increased by £175.1 million, or 75.3 per cent., from £232.4 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to £407.5 million in the year ended 31 December 2019. These increases primarily reflect the contribution from our new portfolio of pumped storage hydro and gas-fired generation assets integrated into the group as part of the DGEL Acquisition (£167.2 million and £114.4 million to gross profit and Adjusted EBITDA, respectively), increased Capacity Market income for the year ended 31 December 2019 (including the recognition in the year ended 31 December 2019 of £6.8 million of income related to the period in 2018 during which the Capacity Market was suspended), increased ROC generation and improved spreads following efficiency gains from our investments in the performance of our biomass generating units (high pressure turbine upgrade on our second biomass unit in 2018 in addition to other smaller projects) and benefits from our trading position (by buying back power sold in advance at a lower price to make a margin) and portfolio, partially offset by a decrease in our CfD income due to an outage over the Summer Season at one of our biomass units at Drax Power Station. _Customers_ Gross profit for the Customers segment decreased by £9.3 million, or 6.5 per cent., from £143.4 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to £134.1 million in the year ended 31 December 2019. Adjusted EBITDA for the Customers segment decreased by £10.8 million, or 38.3 per cent., from £28.2 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to £17.4 million in the year ended 31 December 2019. These decreases primarily reflect lower volumes of power sold (from 20.9 TWh in the year ended 31 December 2018 to 18.9 TWh in the year ended 31 December 2019) primarily due to a mild 2018/2019 Winter Season and incremental restructuring costs, which include an £8.0 million investment to more closely integrate Opus and Haven Power and bring them under one management team and a £7.0 million investment for the development of our next-generation IT systems, partially offset by an improvement in the margin per MWh sold and a reduction in bad debt charges from £31.4 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to £18.0 million in the year ended 31 December 2019. 116 ----- _Pellet Production_ Gross profit for the Pellet Production segment increased by £19.0 million, or 29.2 per cent., from £65.1 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to £84.1 million in the year ended 31 December 2019. Adjusted EBITDA for the Pellet Production segment increased by £10.7 million, or 51.4 per cent., from £20.8 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to £31.5 million in the year ended 31 December 2019. These increases primarily reflect the increased output from approximately 1,351 kt of wood pellets produced in the year ended 31 December 2018 to approximately 1,407 kt in the year ended 31 December 2019 and the reduction in the cost of production from $166.0 per tonne of wood pellets in the year ended 31 December 2018 to $161.0 per tonne of wood pellets in the year ended 31 December 2019, mainly due to operational efficiencies as a result of our co-location agreement with Hunt Forest Products to develop a sawmill next to our LaSalle site and the new rail spur linking our LaSalle facility to the regional rail network and our port facility at Baton Rouge. _Central costs_ Central costs affecting our Adjusted EBITDA increased by £17.7 million, or 62.5 per cent., from £28.3 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to £46.0 million in the year ended 31 December 2019. This increase primarily reflects incremental research and development expenditure associated with key strategic initiatives (including BECCS), costs associated with implementing a new organisational structure to enable us to execute our strategy more effectively and increased costs associated with delivering working capital initiatives.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are financed through a combination of cash generated from operations and from financing arrangements (which, following the issuance of the Notes and the use of proceeds therefrom as described under “Use of Proceeds”, will consist of the Notes, the 2025 Senior Secured Notes, the 2022 Fixed Rate Notes, the Private Placement Facilities, the Term Facilities, the ESG Facility and the Term Loan). Cash generated from operations is supported by a number of working capital initiatives, including arrangements in respect of payables, receivables, inventories and ROC assets to ensure that the working capital committed is closely aligned with operational requirements. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements”. Liquidity, including short-term working capital requirements, is primarily financed through rebasing and ROC sales. In addition, the Group also has access to the Revolving Facility, which provides for loans of up to £315 million. On 31 December 2018, we acquired DGEL, a UK power generation business which owns and operates a portfolio of hydro, pumped storage and gas-fired power generation assets, for an initial net consideration of £686.9 million after customary net debt and working capital adjustments. We paid the initial consideration due to the vendor on 2 January 2019 using a combination of £550 million drawn under the 2018 Bridge Facility and £136.9 million of cash reserves. Accordingly, no profit or loss was recognised in respect of DGEL in the year ended 31 December 2018, and neither the drawing under the 2018 Bridge Facility nor the reduction in cash in respect of the consideration paid were reflected in our consolidated net debt as at 31 December 2018. The assets and liabilities acquired were included in our consolidated balance sheet as at 31 December 2018. During the year ended 31 December 2019, we refinanced the 2018 Bridge Facility using the proceeds from the additional 2025 Notes we issued in May 2019 and the Private Placement Facilities in July 2019. Prior to its acquisition by us, DGEL was historically funded by a combination of borrowings from other companies controlled by its former parent, Iberdrola, S.A., and through cash generated from operations. The following table summarises our cash flow activity for the six months ended 30 June 2020 and 2019 and for the years ended 31 December 2019 and 2018.

Subsubsection Text: Cash generated from operations was £226.4 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020 compared to £228.8 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019, reflecting the increase in Adjusted EBITDA, £78.1 million in cash received in respect of 2019 Capacity Market income and a net cash inflow resulting from increased generation and a corresponding reduction in inventories, which largely offset outflows due to an increase in ROC assets. Net cash generated from operating activities was £167.9 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020 compared to £199.4 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019, primarily as a result of an increase by £24.3 million in cash taxes paid in the six months ended 30 June 2020 reflecting the one-time impact of the Group falling into the new arrangements in respect of corporation tax payments for very large companies in the UK for the first time. Cash generated from operations was £471.2 million in the year ended 31 December 2019 compared to £336.4 million in the year ended 31 December 2018, partially reflecting the increase in Adjusted EBITDA, as well as an increase in the amount of cash released from working capital by making sales to manage our holding of ROC assets and rebasing foreign currency exchange contracts. _Changes in working capital (other than Generation segment carbon assets and ROC assets)_ Our working capital mainly comprises receivables and payables balances. In our Customers segment, working capital mainly comprises trade payables related to the obligation to procure a sufficient number of ROCs and trade receivables against customers. Net cash inflow from changes in working capital (other than Generation segment carbon assets and ROC assets) was £231.3 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020 compared to a net cash inflow of £130.6 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019. Net cash inflow from decreases to inventories was £92.2 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020 compared to net cash inflows from increases in inventories of £65.4 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019. Biomass inventory levels decreased during the six months ended 30 June 2020 due to increased biomass burnt, and increased during the six months ended 30 June 2019 as we stocked up following the biomass supply constraints earlier in the year. Coal inventories decreased during the six months ended 30 June 2020 due to the discontinuation of coal delivery orders following our announcement to end commercial coal generation in March 2021, and increased during the six months ended 30 June 2019 due to a greater proportion of the inventory being held on site, therefore attracting carbon price floor costs and resulting in higher average cost per tonne. Cash released from receivables was £135.1 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020 (six months ended 30 June 2019: £79.6 million), due to the receipt of cash from the Capacity 118 ----- Market for the year ended 31 December 2019. Cash released from payables was £4.0 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020 (six months ended 30 June 2019: £116.4 million), primarily reflecting lower build-up of ROC accruals in the Customers segment due to lower sales in the six months ended 30 June 2020 and an increase in the utilisation of payment facilities in the six months ended 30 June 2019. Net cash outflow from changes in working capital (other than Generation segment carbon assets and ROC assets) was £108.8 million in the year ended 31 December 2019 compared to a net cash inflow of £186.5 million in the year ended 31 December 2018. Net cash inflow from increases to inventories was £67.8 million in the year ended 31 December 2019 compared to a net cash inflow from decreases to inventories of £52.5 million in the year ended 31 December 2018. Biomass inventory levels in the year ended 31 December 2019 were higher than in the year ended 31 December 2018 due to a variety of factors, including phasing of electricity generation. Coal inventories increased in the year ended 31 December 2019 reflecting an increased proportion of total stock held on site, which attracts carbon tax, increasing the carrying amount of stock. Receivables increased by £142.6 million in the year ended 31 December 2019 (year ended 31 December 2018: increase of £15.4 million), driven mainly by the increase of income received in the year ended 31 December 2019 following the reinstatement of the Capacity Market. Payables increased by £101.6 million in the year ended 31 December 2019 (year ended 31 December 2018: increase of £149.4 million). _Increase/decrease in carbon assets_ Carbon assets are emissions allowances purchased and held by us to be used in the relevant year pursuant to EU ETS. Carbon assets remained static in the six months ended 30 June 2020 compared to a decrease of £0.3 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019, and decreased by £4.3 million in the year ended 31 December 2019 compared to an increase of £3.7 million in the year ended 31 December 2018. We purchase carbon assets in advance based on our estimated generation from coal during each year. Increases and decreases in carbon assets therefore mainly reflect lower or higher generation from coal than originally estimated. _Increase/decrease in ROC_ The value of ROCs created in the Generation segment is held on the balance sheet until these assets are sold to a third party, at which time ROCs are recognised as revenue. The timing of such sale is driven by RO deadlines and commercial considerations, resulting in a time lag between the time at which the ROCs are booked in the balance sheet and the time at which the purchase price for these assets is realised. We have facilities in place to accelerate cash flows from invoices issued in relation to ROC sales and also sell ROCs to accelerate cash flows, purchasing ROCs at a later date to meet our regulatory requirements. ROC assets increased by £213.4 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020 compared to an increase of £95.5 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019, principally reflecting an increase in purchases (primarily due to increased sales in the six months ended 31 December 2019) and fewer sales in the six months ended 30 June 2020, as well as the increase in biomass generation. ROC assets decreased by £54.0 million in the year ended 31 December 2019 compared to an increase of £71.2 million in the year ended 31 December 2018, principally reflecting lower generation due to a lower ROC cap and the timing of cash released from working capital by making sales and purchases of ROC assets.

Subsubsection Text: Net cash absorbed by financing activities was £41.7 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020 compared to net cash generated from financing activities of £514.1 million in the six months ended 30 June 2019, reflecting primarily the increase in borrowings to part-fund the DGEL Acquisition in the six months ended 30 June 2019. Net cash generated from financing activities was £571.6 million in the year ended 31 December 2019 compared to net cash absorbed by financing activities of £112.0 million in the year ended 31 December 2018, 119 ----- reflecting primarily the increase in borrowings to part-fund the DGEL Acquisition and the reduction in our share buy-back activity in the year ended 31 December 2019, partially offset by increased dividends paid to shareholders. See “—Dividend Policy”.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Net cash (absorbed by)/generated from financing activities . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** **(41.7)** **514.1** **571.6** **(112.0) Net increase/(decrease) in cash and cash equivalents  . . . . . .** **71.1** **(45.9)** **121.9** **65.6
Subsubsection Text: Our capital expenditure on property, plant and equipment amounted to £75.0 million and £48.6 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020 and 2019, respectively. This increase primarily reflects our investments in the expansion of our US pellet production facilities, along with smaller projects within the Generation segment and a planned CCGT outage at Damhead Creek. Capital expenditure to maintain operational performance constituted £33.0 million and £16.1 million in the six months ended 30 June 2020 and 2019, respectively, which represented 43 per cent. and 28 per cent. of our total capital expenditure for the six months ended 30 June 2020 and 2019, respectively. Our capital expenditure on property, plant and equipment amounted to £151.3 million and £113.6 million in the years ended 31 December 2019 and 2018, respectively. This increase primarily reflects additional expenditure in respect of the new assets integrated into the Group as part of the DGEL Acquisition, strategic projects and investments to advance our objective of increasing self-supply and reducing the cost of pellet production. Capital expenditure to maintain operational performance constituted £59.0 million and £55.0 million in the years ended 31 December 2019 and 2018, respectively, which represented 34.3 per cent. and 38.6 per cent. of our total capital expenditure for the years ended 31 December 2019 and 2018, respectively. Our expected capital expenditures for the remainder of the year ending 31 December 2020 has reduced, as various projects have been delayed following the outbreak of the Covid-19 pandemic, including non-essential works at Drax Power Station and initiatives in our biomass supply chain. We expect our capital expenditure for the year ending 31 December 2020 (including the impact of purchases of software assets) to be between £190 million and £210 million, consisting of an estimated £60 million to £70 million of capital expenditure to maintain operational performance, an estimated £30 million in respect of the new assets integrated into the Group as part of the DGEL Acquisition, an estimated £10 million of efficiency and operational improvements, an estimated further £80 million to £90 million for strategic capital expenditure, including a £69.6 million investment in a self-supply project, and an estimated £10 million of other general capital expenditure. In the medium term, we expect to focus our capital expenditure on our upstream pellet supply and on the continuous production of good quality pellets at lower costs. We expect global demand for wood pellets to increase by approximately 60 per cent. over the next five years, inclusive of Drax’s requirements, as other countries develop decarbonisation programmes which acknowledge the benefits of sustainable biomass for generation. Whilst there is an abundance of sustainable biomass globally, there remains limited capacity to convert these fibres into energy dense pellets, which have a low-carbon footprint and lower cost associated with transportation. As a result, we expect the global market for biomass to remain structurally short. We are therefore exploring options to service biomass demand in other markets, including Europe, North America and Asia. In doing so we are creating optionality over our use of sustainable biomass. In June 2019, we approved an investment of £50.0 million for the expansion of our Morehouse, Amite and LaSalle facilities. Such expansion projects are under way in our Morehouse and LaSalle pellet production facilities, and expansion works are expected to begin in our Amite facility in 2021. Furthermore, on 30 June 2020, we approved a $40 million investment in three new satellite pellet plants in the US Gulf region, which will utilise sawmill residues and leverage our existing infrastructure in order to increase production and reduce pellet costs. We expect the expansion of our existing pellet production facilities and our investment in these three new satellite pellet plans will provide an additional nameplate capacity of approximately 350,000 tonnes per annum and 120,000 tonnes per annum, respectively, by early 2022. In the year ended 31 December 2019, the cost of generation across our portfolio was £73.5 per MWh and, in the long-term, our aim is to reduce the cost of generation from self-supplied biomass to £50 per MWh by 2027. We expect to also focus our capital expenditure on the development of our BECCS technical options. On 24 June 2020, we announced that a new BECCS pilot facility will be installed within Drax’s CCUS Incubation Area in the autumn of 2020, when we expect to commence a trial of BECCS technology developed by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries. This project will enhance Drax’s technical understanding for delivering negative emissions and help us drive forward our ambition to become carbon negative by 2030. Subject to the right support from the UK Government, we stand ready to develop and deliver this necessary contribution to the UK achieving net zero emissions by 2050. We are also continuing to develop options for new gas generation which we believe is necessary to provide greater flexibility to the electricity system as it becomes more dependent on intermittent and inflexible 120 ----- generation. As a part of the development options for these projects we are also assessing the potential to introduce hydrogen as part of the fuel mix to further reduce the carbon intensity of these projects. Investment remains subject to an appropriate clearing price in a future Capacity Market auction. Our options range from the development of up to four 299 MW rapid-response OCGT projects requiring £80 million to £90 million spread over three to four years per development, to projects to repower one or both of our coal-fired units at Drax Power Station to 1.8 GW CCGT units (with an initial estimated cost of approximately £600 million per unit, provided in the related planning application for the projects, spread over a number of years), to an opportunity to develop our Damhead Creek II site into a 1.8 GW CCGT plant, with a broadly similar cost to repowering one of our coal units to gas. All projects are in the early stages of development and, accordingly, actual costs may vary. Each of these projects would require an appropriate level of support through the Capacity Market to provide a baseline of expected revenue sufficient to justify a positive investment decision.

Subsubsection Text: As at 30 June 2020, on an unaudited basis and after giving _pro forma_ effect to the Transactions and the Term Facilities, our borrowings are set out in the table below. See “Use of Proceeds”, “Capitalisation” and “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements”.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (1) The Senior Facilities provide for up to £350 million of senior secured borrowings, comprised of a £315 million committed multicurrency revolving credit facility and a £35 million term loan facility. As at 30 June 2020, the Senior Facilities had been utilised in respect of letters of credit with a total value of £35.6 million, and the index-linked term loan facility of £35 million was fully drawn. The carrying value of the term loan at 30 June 2020 is £38.1 million, which includes £3.1 million indexation. (2) The Existing Notes are comprised of the 2022 Notes and the 2025 Notes. The aggregate principal amount of 2022 Notes and 2025 Notes outstanding as of 30 June 2020 was £350.0 million and £405.8 million, respectively, the latter of which represents the pound sterling equivalent of the $500 million aggregate amount of the 2025 Notes calculated using a currency exchange rate of $1.2380 to £1.00, which was the market rate on 30 June 2020, sourced from Reuters, used for the preparation of the balance sheet contained in the 2020 Drax Group Unaudited Financial Statements. The Group has entered into cross-currency interest rate swaps, fixing the sterling value of the principal repayments in respect of the 2025 Notes. If US dollar balances relating to the 2025 Notes were translated at the hedged rate, rather than the rate prevailing at 30 June 2020, our borrowings would have been reduced by £36.4 million. We intend to repay the 2022 Notes in full before 31 December 2020. See “Use of Proceeds”. (3) The Private Placement Facilities represent a £375 million private placement with infrastructure lenders with maturities between 2024 and 2029 and the ESG Facility represents a £125 million ESG facility agreement; excludes the Term Facilities entered into on 18 August 2020, which represent a €126.5 million and £45 million term facilities agreement with maturities between 2024 and 2027, which remains undrawn as of the date hereof. The table above does not include £1,067.1 million in total trade and other payables due as of 30 June 2020.
