The Capacity Market provides a payment for reliable sources of capacity alongside their electricity revenues, to ensure they deliver energy when needed. Existing generators which are successful in the auction receive a one-year Capacity Market agreement. Plants requiring significant refurbishment may also be eligible for three-year Capacity Market agreements. Potential new build generating stations may be eligible for 15-year Capacity Market agreements, if they meet certain criteria. Other types of capacity are eligible to participate, including interconnectors and demand side response. 159 ----- We have secured index-linked Capacity Market agreements for certain of our pumped storage, hydro and CCGT assets, which are expected to result in contract-based revenues in excess of £209.4 million in aggregate between January 2019 and 30 September 2024. We have similar agreements for our two coal-fired generation units until 30 September 2022 and the three small ancillary gas turbines located at Drax Power Station until 30 September 2024, which are expected to result in contract-based revenues of approximately £84.3 million between January 2019 and 30 September 2024 in aggregate. Included in the above is the contracts that were secured through participating in the T-3 Capacity Market Auction held in January 2020 and have provisionally secured agreements to provide approximately 2,333MW of de-rated capacity from our Damhead Creek, Rye House and Shoreham CCGT assets, the Drax gas turbines, the Cruachan pumped storage plant and the Galloway hydro power plant in the year commencing 1 October 2022. A T-4 Capacity Market Auction is due to be held in January 2021, for which the results of National Grid ESO’s prequalification process are expected in late October 2020. We will only accept a contract for participating development projects where it is economically attractive and in line with our capital allocation policy and adheres to a conservative net leverage profile. _A naturally hedged portfolio of generation assets and businesses through the value chain_ We are a multi-site, multi-technology operator and our ability to generate using a range of different technologies with different dispatch economics means we are less exposed to risks inherent to single technologies and movements in individual commodity prices. For example, if power prices and gas spreads fall due to high wind it will decrease the margin available at our thermal sites but the reduced number of thermal plants on the system is likely to increase the level of system support and balancing services required by National Grid, increasing the opportunities for pumped storage as well as the gas units through balancing market activities. At an operational level, we trade our generation assets as a single portfolio, leveraging our established expertise to optimise the running of our assets to maximise returns. We operate an integrated value chain across our three core segments (pellet production, generation and our Customers segment), enabling us to optimise the timing and delivery of sustainable business we produce to meet our renewable generation requirements at Drax Power Station. In turn, our Generation segment provides flexible, low-carbon and renewable electricity to our Customers segment for onward supply to business customers. _Hedging policy_ The earnings of our Generation segment are further supported by our long-term hedging policy pursuant to which we sell electricity generated up to two years in advance. This allows us to secure a margin on such electricity at times when margins for a given generation technology are attractive, thereby increasing visibility with respect to our future Generation segment earnings. As of 22 July 2020, we had contracted fixed price power sales (including both forward sold electricity and gas proxy hedges) of approximately 17.6TWh, 11.4TWh and 4.8TWh for delivery in 2020, 2021 and 2022, respectively. Our average achieved prices for fixed price power sales of forward sold electricity in 2020, 2021 and 2022 were £53.8 per MWh, £49.0 per MWh and £48.2 per MWh, respectively. Our business is subject to risks due to fluctuations in currency exchange rates, in particular, the weakening of sterling relative to other operational currencies, as most of the biomass we purchase is priced in US dollars, Canadian dollars or euro. We operate a long-term hedging policy with a five-year hedging period to manage the risk of a change in the relative values of the US dollar, Canadian dollar or euros relative to the pound sterling, which may increase our suppliers’ cost of business and ultimately our cost of goods sold with respect to biomass. _Increased control over fuel input costs via an integrated biomass supply chain_ Our wood pellet manufacturing facilities have a combined annual nameplate capacity of 1,475,000 tonnes, comprising capacity of 512,500 tonnes at each of our Amite and Morehouse facilities and 450,000 tonnes of capacity at our LaSalle facility, and have operated at or near nameplate capacity in the six months to 30 June 2020. Our US port facility in Baton Rouge, Louisiana has an annual export capacity of 2,100,000 tonnes (with the scope to expand further to 3,000,000 tonnes), which exceeds our current self-supply, enabling us to consolidate supply from third parties to drive further supply chain efficiencies until we are able to increase our selfsupply of biomass in the coming years. Our current US operations are strategically located near one another for operational efficiencies, including optimising the time and cost of wood pellet deliveries to our Baton Rouge port facility. In the first half of 2020, our wood pellet manufacturing facilities produced approximately 753,000 tonnes of wood pellets and our US port facility shipped 747,000 tonnes of wood pellets to Drax Power Station. In 2019, 160 ----- wood pellets manufactured at our own facilities accounted for 22 per cent. of the biomass used at Drax Power Station with the balance sourced from third party suppliers based in North America and Europe under a series of predominantly long-term contracts from sources also certified as sustainable. We aim to increase the amount of pellets we self-supply up to 5,000,000 tonnes per annum by 2027 (71 per cent. of our internal requirement for the year ended 31 December 2019). In furtherance of this aim, we are in the process of increasing capacity at our LaSalle, Amite and Morehouse facilities by 350,000 tonnes in aggregate over the next two years. In addition, over the same time period we expect to complete construction of three new satellite pellet plants, with nameplate capacity of 120,000 tonnes per year and the potential to increase this to 500,000 tonnes. We expect that the production costs at these plants will be approximately 20 per cent. lower than our existing plants. Our ability to source an increasing proportion of our biomass requirements internally via self-supply allows us to better manage the quality of feedstock and the timing of deliveries. This allows us to drive down the cost of biomass, but also enables us to optimise generation and reduce the risk of fuel shortages and supply chain issues curtailing generation from Drax Power Station. Further to this, it allows us to better ensure a stable cost of biomass and reduce exposure to commodity price fluctuations. At the same time, we maintain the flexibility to participate in the biomass spot market when prices are attractive. To date there has been no material impact from Covid-19 on our biomass supply chain or those of our key biomass suppliers, nor has there been any material disruption due to Covid-19 to the shipping of our biomass by sea freight, port or rail.

Subsubsection Title: Strong financial metrics and conservative financial policies.
Subsubsection Text: We have a conservative balance sheet and financial policy, which has been maintained since we listed on the London Stock Exchange in December 2005, and is evidenced by our strong credit ratings from S&P, Fitch and DBRS. In recent years, as the Group has diversified and substantially grown, we have also reduced our business risk profile. Any temporary increase in leverage resulting from our corporate acquisitions have been followed by rapid deleveraging back to pre-acquisition levels. Our reported net leverage at the end of the last four calendar years has been between 0.7x and 1.8x. After the completion of the Opus Acquisition in February 2017, our consolidated pro forma net leverage as at 31 December 2016 only increased to 2.7x and decreased to 1.6x by the end of the calendar year; after the completion of the DGEL Acquisition in December 2018, our consolidated pro forma net leverage as at 31 December 2018 was 3.1x and decreased to 1.9x by 31 December 2019 and further decreased to 1.8x by 30 June 2020. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations— _Significant Factors affecting Results of Operations” for a discussion of factors affecting comparability of_ informationn for the six months ended 30 June 2020 and 2019 and the years ended 31 December 2019 and 2018. We are committed to maintaining leverage at a level that is consistent with our current crossover credit rating, which supports our trading strategy. See “Presentation of Financial Information and Other Information— _Non-IFRS Financial Measures”._ We have a disciplined focus on cash flow and working capital management and have not utilised our cash revolving credit facilities for over two years. We have a strong cash conversion profile with an average annual operating cash conversion for the last four calendar years of 125 per cent., reflecting ongoing low maintenance capital expenditure requirements combined with financial discipline. We announced our current dividend policy in June 2017, and this will pay a sustainable and growing dividend consistent with our commitment to a strong balance sheet and our ambitions for growth. We are focused on targeted selective investments which will help us continue diversifying our earnings and cash flow sources. We also expect our future maintenance capital expenditures to include investments to upgrade our facilities to, among other things, comply with applicable regulatory regimes, which we then expect to translate into greater operating cash flow going forward. We continue to invest in biomass strategy, although there has been some delay in investment due to Covid-19. In the first half of 2020, capital expenditure was £78 million, and the full year expected investment is £190 to £210 million. Further, future investments to increase our biomass self-supply capacity have been approved and will commence in the second half of 2020 in respect of three satellite plants. All decisions on investments and capital allocation are made in line with a prudent capital allocation policy. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations— _Capital and Operating Expenditure”._ We have robust credit policies in place to limit the amount of concentration risk we have with any counterparty (noting that the counterparty’s appetite to trade with us is itself based on its assessment of our credit profile). Sales to the Customers segment (as opposed to third parties) further reduce our concentration risk by spreading the Generation segment’s exposure to third-party credit risk across a wider customer base. 161 -----

Subsubsection Title: Our proven management team has led our business through an evolving regulatory and commodity market environment.
Subsubsection Text: We and our management team have proven experience in leading our business through an evolving regulatory environment, having delivered Europe’s largest decarbonization programme. Management is supported by a skilled operating team who are at the forefront of biomass conversion technology, including the mechanical, engineering, electrical and civil works required for such conversion. Through the conversion of four coal units to biomass at Drax Power Station, acquisitions and organic growth we have successfully transformed a coal generation business into a vertically-integrated generator focused on flexible, low-carbon and renewable electricity. As a result of this transformation, we are an industry-leader in energy generation from biomass and its associated supply chain. We have also gained significant experience in integrating businesses into our existing operations, in particular following our acquisition of Opus on 17 February 2017 and the DGEL Assets on 31 December 2018. The conversion of the first three of our generation units to biomass remains Europe’s largest decarbonisation project, and was delivered on time and within budget. This experience enabled us to deliver the low-cost conversion of a fourth biomass-fired generation unit in August 2018 and positions us to continue to deliver significant biomass cost-savings and growth projects, as well as providing Drax with the ability to adapt to an evolving energy market and deliver on our pipeline of development projects. We have invested £1.6 billion of net cash since 2016 and have deployed strong underlying contracted cash flows for investments beyond 2027 when the current renewable support ends. Our operational experience in handling biomass is also market-leading. We have developed innovative fuel handling systems, logistics and storage solutions for biomass fuel as well as a bespoke, technically-advanced covered rail wagon with a specialised door design and a patented product flow control system to manage biomass during discharge. Further, we have developed an in-depth understanding of the scientific and technological effects of burning a range of biomass fuels, as well as of the critical combustion characteristics of such fuels. This positions us to identify and utilize new fuels (such as sugar cane and bagasse) at a reduced cost to the wood pellets we currently procure from third parties. Sustainability is at the heart of our culture and the sustainable sourcing of biomass is a core principle of the Group. We aim to lead in this area and, in 2017 we appointed a Senior Independent Non-Executive Director with expertise in sustainability. In 2019, we introduced a new Responsible Sourcing Policy for Biomass, which reflects the evolving science in the area and is based on recommendations by Forest Research and the European Climate Foundation, and which exceeds the requirements of the EU Renewable Energy Directive II. We also established an Independent Advisory Board chaired by Sir John Beddington, the UK’s former Chief Scientific Adviser, and including members of Forest Research. The IAB provides independent advice on the role of biomass in climate change mitigation and in supporting the transition to a net zero energy system, forest science and optimising carbon impacts, and societal expectations for responsible and sustainable biomass. The Independent Advisory  Board  has  reviewed  our  biomass  policy  and  confirmed  that  it  reflects  the recommendations made by Forest Research. We seek to source biomass from countries with large areas of growing forests and established forest industries and we comprehensively audit our carbon footprint across our entire biomass supply chain, conduct regular ISAE 3000 assured independent supplier audits and encourage the use of third party sustainability certification. All our biomass is procured in accordance with our Responsible Sourcing Policy for Biomass.

Subsubsection Title: Create a long-term future for sustainable biomass.
Subsubsection Text: The cost of biomass fuel is a key metric in determining the profitability of our biomass generation and our overall financial performance. We have a target to substantially reduce this cost by 2027 through increasing our self-supply of sustainable wood pellets, increasing our operational efficiency and developing a wider fuel envelope. In doing so, we expect to develop a long-term future for sustainable biomass. Our wood pellet manufacturing facilities in the US currently supply all of their output to Drax Power Station and supplied 1,535,000 tonnes (22 per cent.) of our internal requirements for generation from sustainable biomass in 2019. Our target is to increase this self-supply capability to 5,000,000 (71 per cent. of our internal requirement for the year ended 31 December 2019) by 2027, and in doing so become the world’s largest low-cost biomass producer and improve the certainty of self-supply, allowing us to take advantage of economies of scale 162 ----- and making us less susceptible to changes in the wholesale price of biomass. In furtherance of this target, we are increasing capacity at our LaSalle, Amite and Morehouse facilities by 350,000 tonnes in aggregate over the next two years (construction has started at LaSalle and Morehouse, and is expected to begin at Amite in 2021). Our current wood pellet manufacturing facilities are strategically located close to one another in the US Gulf region for operational and supply chain efficiencies. We intend to continue consolidating supply from third parties at our Baton Rouge port facility to utilise unused export capacity and to drive further supply chain efficiencies. Progress in the first half of 2020 included the approval of three new 40kt satellite plants at a cost of approximately $40 million in aggregate ($10-15 million per site). Construction work on the first plant is set to begin this year, which will utilise sawmill residues and share our existing US Gulf infrastructure to produce, we believe, biomass at around 20 per cent. below the current cost of production. Separately, we are undertaking a number of operational, technical and logistical initiatives across our biomass supply chain to further reduce the cost of biomass. This includes increasing the proportion of good quality wood pellets received at Drax Power Station, turbine upgrades and process modifications to improve combustion at Drax Power Station and improving our logistics. For example, in May 2019, we commissioned a new rail spur linking our LaSalle facility to the regional rail network and our port facility at Baton Rouge, which will increase transportation efficiency and economies of scale and reduce the cost and carbon footprint of our operations. Together with the Port of Baton Rouge and the State of Louisiana, we are also commissioning an enlarged chambering yard at our port facilities in Baton Rouge, allowing 80-car train sets to operate from our LaSalle and Morehouse sites. Following the success of the co-location of a sawmill next to our LaSalle facility, which became operational in January 2020, we are looking at identifying additional opportunities to locate sawmills near to our pellet facilities, in order to increase operational efficiency, secure low-cost fibre residues and ultimately to reduce the cost of biomass production. This programme of improvements is expected to deliver savings of $27 million per year by the end of 2020 and $64 million per year by the end of 2022. In addition to the above, we aim to leverage our knowledge of fuel chemistry obtained from our sustainable biomass generation to widen the sustainable biomass fuel options which we are able to use at Drax Power Station. We have set up a dedicated team tasked with identifying new fuels (such as sugarcane bagasse, woodchips and nutshells), forms and geographies which we could utilise at a reduced cost to the pellets we currently procure from third parties.

Subsubsection Title: Delivering on our ambition to become a carbon negative company by 2030 through BECCS.
Subsubsection Text: Delivering on BECCS will also leave us well placed to fulfil our longer-term ambition of becoming a carbon negative group by 2030. To deliver on this carbon negative ambition we are developing a range of engineering options and working with a range of technology and industrial partners to apply BECCS technology to the biomass units at Drax Power Station. This technology will safely capture the vast majority of the carbon dioxide emitted in the biomass generation process and transports it via pipelines to storage sites under the North Sea. Our BECCS ambition aligns with the Government’s target to achieve net zero emissions across the UK economy by 2050 and the advice of its statutory advisory body, the CCC, which highlights that BECCS is both a critical part of the solution to achieve net zero whilst also being part of an evolving, stable and flexible generation mix. Each biomass unit utilising BECCS technology could capture approximately 4,000,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide per annum. Working in partnership with a range of stakeholders, and with the right support from Government, we believe we are well placed to develop BECCS at scale in advance of 2030 and, in all, could provide up to a third of the negative emissions that the CCC has identified that the UK may require. 163 ----- We also expect global demand for wood pellets to increase this decade as other countries develop decarbonisation programmes which acknowledge the benefits of sustainable biomass for generation. Whilst there is an abundance of sustainable biomass globally, there remains limited capacity to convert these fibres to energy dense pellets, which have a low-carbon footprint and lower cost associated with transportation. As a result, we expect the global market for biomass to remain structurally short. We are therefore exploring options to service biomass demand in other markets, such as Europe, North America and Asia alongside the UK. In doing so, we are creating optionality over our use of sustainable biomass. The technology to deliver post-combustion BECCS exists and is proven at scale. We recently commenced a trial of one such technology provided by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries at the technology testing zone at Drax Power Station. This solvent technology is well established and is being used at 13 sites globally, notably at the Petra Nova facility in Texas, USA, the world’s largest post-combustion carbon capture plant, which is capable of capturing 1,400,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide a year. We are also piloting the carbon capture potential of an organic and potentially lower cost alternative solvent treatment developed by C-Capture Limited, and we expect to carry out further trials in 2021. This technology is also being piloted at the Tiller facility in Norway. We are also exploring the viability of alternative uses for CO2 including trials to assess use of biogenic CO2 in plastic and animal food use, and the development of synthetic zero-carbon fuels from hydrogen. Subject to the right support from the Government, we stand ready to develop and deliver this critical contribution to the UK achieving net zero emissions by 2050, which will also help us to achieve our ambition of becoming a carbon negative company by 2030.

Subsubsection Title: Be the leading provider of system support in the UK.
Subsubsection Text: Historically, the vast majority of the Group’s earnings were derived from the operation of Drax Power Station as a merchant plant, selling wholesale power independently to third parties. Accordingly, the Group’s earnings were volatile and exposed to commodity price and/or merchant risk. In recent years, our earnings have diversified and the Group’s exposure to commodity price risk has been substantially reduced. In the Generation segment, we maintain our visibility of future earnings and cash flows through the contracted earnings of Capacity Market and System Support Services payments. We expect that, combined with the support we receive under the CfD Regime and RO Scheme for our biomass and hydro generation assets, this will continue to result in a reduced level of commodity markets exposure and increased stability and visibility of earnings. We have secured index-linked Capacity Market agreements for certain of our pumped storage, hydro and CCGT assets, which are expected to result in contract-based revenues in excess of £209.4 million in aggregate between January 2019 and 30 September 2024. We have similar agreements for our two coal-fired generation units until 30 September 2022 and the three small ancillary gas turbines located at Drax Power Station until 30 September 2024, which are expected to result in contract-based revenues of approximately £84.3 million between January 2019 and 30 September 2024 in aggregate. Looking forward, any final investment decision in respect of any one of our pipeline of development options will be subject to appropriate support to deliver stable contract-based revenues in line with our capital allocation policy whilst maintaining a conservative net leverage profile. 164 ----- With increasing levels of intermittent generation on the UK electricity system, we are continuing to identify opportunities to flexibly operate our generation assets according to prevailing market conditions, such as the provision of short-term power and balancing market activity and the provision of other System Support Services. The flexible, dispatchable and responsive nature of our generation assets positions us to compete in the market over the short and medium term and our pipeline of development projects will, if developed, further bolster our offering in this regard. With the changing grid dynamic, we expect the market for System Support Services to grow. As the UK’s electricity market evolves, the types and tenor of System Support Services being procured by the System Operator is changing. For example, in January 2020, one of the Cruachan pumped storage hydro station’s four turbines secured a six-year contract to provide System Support Services to the UK electricity system, which commenced in July 2020 and is expected to result in contract-based revenues of approximately £29 million between 1 April 2020 and 31 March 2026 in aggregate. In addition, our Drax Power Station and Damhead Creek assets both provide foot room reserve services. It is our intention to offer further assets to tender for similar System Support Services in the future and we will continue to position the business so that it is able to meet the requirements of an increasingly complex UK electricity system.

Subsubsection Title: Develop our Customers segment by giving customers control of their energy.
Subsubsection Text: The Customers segment has a differentiated market position—selling purely renewable power while helping over 2,000 independent renewable generators, access the market. In the same way that the Generation segment provides system support, so too can our industrial customer portfolio. Over time, we expect this business, through efficiency and demand-side response, to contribute increasingly to system support. We continue to believe this approach will support long-term growth. Our Customers segment was the fifth largest supplier of electricity to businesses in the UK by volume supplied as of 30 April 2020, was the largest provider of renewable energy to businesses and the UK leading business to business only supplier. As at 30 April 2020, we supplied 281,500 electricity and gas meters and, in the six months ended 30 June 2020, we supplied 8.8TWh of electricity and gas and our fuel mix disclosure for the period April 2019 to March 2020 100 per cent of our electricity was from renewable generation. As at 30 April 2020, our share of the B2B electricity market was 8 percent. As the power system decarbonises, we believe that there is a significant opportunity for the Group to leverage our status as a vertically integrated utility with a diverse range of assets to provide an evolving range of innovative and flexible solutions to business customers enabling them to manage their energy demand and requirements, which will drive market share growth and increased profitability in the Customers segment. In the first half of 2020, the Customers segment reported a loss. This reflects the significant reduction in demand caused by Covid-19, the cost associated with exiting hedged positions as market prices have fallen and the increased risk and provisioning for business failure and bad debt—principally in the SME market, which represents 30 per cent. of monthly billing. The combined revenues for Opus Energy Limited and Opus Gas Supply Limited, which supply SME customers, were £626.8 million in 2019, 27 per cent. of our £2.35 billion total revenues in the Customers business. We estimate that there is approximately £100 million of SME revenue within the Haven Power Limited revenues in 2019, which would increase this to 31 per cent. However, even with social distancing measures eased we expect the impact of Covid-19 to continue in the second half of 2020 and 2021. Despite the Covid-19 pandemic, the I&C business performed better and has added long dated contracts with water utilities to the portfolio, providing revenue visibility over the next five years. Looking beyond the impact of Covid-19 we will continue to monitor the portfolio to ensure alignment with the Group’s strategy. The Customers business has a differentiated market position—selling purely renewable power while helping over 2,000 independent renewable generators, access the market. In the same way that the Generation business provides system support, so too can our industrial customer portfolio. Over time, we expect this business, through efficiency and demand-side response, to contribute increasingly to system support. We continue to believe this approach will support long-term growth.

_Overview_ We operate a multi-site, multi-technology generation business with sustainable biomass, hydro, pumped storage and thermal assets. The majority of our generation output is produced from our sustainable biomass-fired generation units at Drax Power Station. Our nationwide generation portfolio enables us to meet the growing need for forms of generation that are flexible and dispatchable in response to changes in the needs of the electricity grid in Great Britain whilst delivering increased visibility of long-term earnings and a relatively high proportion of non-commodity related earnings. Our ability to generate electricity using a variety of different technologies with different dispatch economics and provide a range of System Support Services means we are less exposed to risks inherent to single technologies and movements in individual commodity prices. _Thermal generation assets_ Drax Power Station is located in North Yorkshire, on the banks of the River Ouse, between the towns of Selby and Goole. The Drax Power Station site, comprising approximately 1,850 acres, is close to supplies of cooling water and has convenient road and rail access to nearby port capacity. Drax Power Station is the largest power station in the UK, with approximately 4.0GW of connected installed capacity from its six main generation units, each of which can be operated independently. Between 2013 and 2018, four of the six generation units were converted to run on sustainable biomass, the first three units of which formed the largest single decarbonisation project completed in Europe. In 2019, we completed the first in a series of three high-pressure turbine upgrades of our biomass units which will further increase efficiency and reduce maintenance costs. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—The reduction or _abandonment of governmental support for generation of electricity from biomass or other relevant changes in governmental energy policy may materially adversely affect our business, operations, financial condition and results of operations”._ Four of Drax Power Station’s main generation units run exclusively on sustainable biomass and two units currently burn coal and coal derivatives. In 2019, our biomass life cycle carbon emissions were 124kg of CO2 per MWh of electricity generated, well below the 2015-2020 UK limit of 285kg of CO2 emissions per MWh of electricity generated. This calculation compares the supply chain emissions for all biomass used by us against the CO2 emissions which would have been created through the combustion of coal. For the purposes of this calculation, the biogenic CO2 emissions from burning sustainable biomass at Drax Power Station are considered to be zero in line with the methodology developed by the UNFCCC and reflecting that the CO2 released in the process of burning sustainable biomass has been absorbed from the atmosphere during the growth of the feedstock. The four generation units that have been converted to biomass are capable of burning approximately eight million tonnes of sustainable biomass per year. For further information on carbon emissions, see “Industry Overview—Electricity _market: regulatory context—The EU Emissions Trading System” and “Industry Overview—UK clean energy legislation”._ Generation from coal accounted for only approximately four per cent. of our generation during the year ended 31 December 2019 and we plan to end commercial coal generation at Drax Power Station in 2021 and close the coal units in 2022, allowing us to transition away from coal-fired generation entirely. We have been granted a DCO approving the repowering of our retiring coal-fired generation capacity (approximately 1.3GW) at Drax Power Station with up to 3.6GW of gas generation capacity, subject to the outcome of judicial review proceedings, a positive investment decision and other approvals and the receipt of an appropriate Capacity Market agreement in future Capacity Market auctions. This repowering would utilise existing infrastructure to deliver a low cost solution for new gas-fired generation and reduce carbon emissions versus coal, with a wide operating range covering baseload and peak power generation. Our CCGT power stations at Damhead Creek (805MW), Rye House (715MW) and Shoreham (420MW) are all located in the South-East of England where they benefit from grid access income associated with their location in the South-East of England, where energy demand is highest in the country, and provide baseload and peak power generation and other System Support Services. Their location also allows the assets to deliver 166 ----- electricity while incurring lower transmission charges. Damhead Creek is regularly used in the Balancing Mechanism for energy. In addition to these stations, we also own a small CCGT power station at Blackburn Mill (60MW) in Northern England. We are also progressing a permitted option for the development of a 1.8GW CCGT plant at Damhead Creek, which would require sufficient Capacity Market or similar support to be developed. For further information on the Capacity Market, see “Industry Overview—Overview of Electricity Market Reform— _Capacity Market”._ The UK electricity market is changing. A greater amount of intermittent generating capacity is becoming available to the market and, at the same time, older and less efficient thermal plants with the ability to generate electricity more consistently are withdrawing. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has stated that 70-85 per cent. of global electricity will need to come from renewables by 2050 if the target of limiting the worldwide temperature increase to 1.5C is going to be achieved. Additionally, most renewable generation is intermittent in nature. In this context, there is a greater need for the forms of generation found in our portfolio that are flexible and responsive and able to provide the non-generation services a well-functioning and secure electricity system requires. _Thermal generation process_ To generate electricity from either sustainable biomass or coal, the underlying fuel is pulverised into a powder and then blown into boilers, where the fuel is burned. The heat generated by the boiler turns demineralised water into super-heated steam at 568 degrees Celsius, which is fed at high pressure through a series of turbines. The shafts of these turbines are coupled to large cylindrical electromagnets known as rotors, which produce electricity as the turbine rotates. The electricity generated is then increased from 23.5kV to 400kV, allowing for the export of electricity onto the Transmission System. The electricity is eventually reduced to 230V for use by customers. The de-mineralised water in the boilers forms part of a closed system and, once turned into super-heated steam and fed through the high-pressure turbines, is returned to the boiler for reheating before passing through further intermediate and low pressure turbines to increase the overall efficiency of the generation process. Subsequently the steam is condensed and recycled back into the boiler. Excess heat in the form of water vapour is released into the atmosphere by way of cooling towers. Due to Drax Power Station’s design, each unit can operate full time as a baseload generator, or can turn up or down or be taken off line and put back on line with minimal effect on the operating capabilities of the other units. Similarly, the two gas units at our 805MW Damhead Creek CCGT power station and three gas turbines at our 715MW Rye House CCGT power station can each turn up or down or be taken off line and put back on line with minimal effect on the operating capabilities of the other respective gas turbine(s) at those stations. At Drax Power Station and each of our CCGT power stations, generation increases when demand is high, units are available and it is economic for a unit (whether coal, gas or sustainable biomass) to run. In the competitive UK wholesale electricity market, the economics of running a unit are determined by the short-run marginal cost of each technology, which is based on the variable cost of generating a unit of electricity for the relevant half-hour. When there is demand for electricity, the generators that are available with the lowest short-run marginal cost operate until the projected demand in that half-hour is met, subject to balancing actions taken by the System Operator. Due to the higher cost of carbon in the form of the total carbon price, the cost of coal generation today compared to other available generation is higher than it has been historically. As such, Drax Power Station’s coal-fired generation units are not expected to deliver baseload electricity for significant lengths of time prior to their closure or repowering, and are increasingly run to provide electricity to the grid when there are low levels of generation from intermittent sources of energy (e.g., during low-wind periods) or in the balancing mechanism to provide System Support Services. In contrast, the biomass-fired generation units, which benefit from renewable energy support under either the RO Scheme or the CfD Regime, are predominantly delivering either baseload electricity or electricity in peak periods when optimal to do so within the ROC cap under the RO scheme. For further information on the RO Scheme see “Industry Overview—UK Clean Energy Legislation—The Renewables _Obligation”._ Our CCGT power stations produce electricity by using both gas and steam turbine configurations. The gas turbines are powered by natural gas. The fuel is combusted and the resulting heat is converted into mechanical energy, which in turn drives associated electrical generators. The hot gas turbine exhaust gas is used to generate steam in a HRSG (Heat Recovery Steam Generator) which in turn powers a steam turbine which is directly coupled to an electrical generator. By combining the gas and steam processes, the overall efficiency of the CCGT is higher than OCGT units. 167 ----- Our CCGT power stations have a significantly lower cost of carbon than coal units and therefore tend to operate more frequently, albeit none are expected to deliver baseload electricity for significant periods of time. Our CCGTs at Damhead Creek and Shoreham are expected to run most days through the year at times when electricity demand is high, whereas Rye House, which has a lower efficiency, is expected to provide System Support Services or to run for short periods in the balancing mechanism (for example on low wind days). _Pumped storage generation assets and process_ The Cruachan pumped storage hydro power plant is located in Argyll and Bute, Scotland. The Cruachan power plant is built inside the hollowed-out rock of a mountain, Ben Cruachan. It uses electricity from the grid at times of low demand, when electricity prices are generally lower, to pump water from Loch Awe to its storage reservoir part way up the mountain and collects water from the surrounding hills. At times of peak demand, when electricity prices are generally higher, water is released from the reservoir through the station’s turbines to generate electricity. Cruachan, which provides 30 per cent. of the UK’s pumped-hydro storage capacity, can provide longduration storage with the ability to achieve full load in 30 seconds, which it can maintain for 15 hours, making it a strategically important asset for the Group, remunerated by a range of non-commodity based revenues such as System Support Services income and revenues from participation in the Balancing Mechanism. Cruachan’s four electricity generation units currently have a total capacity of 440MW, two of which generate up to 120MW, and the other two up to 100MW. Cruachan has four primary modes of operation: generating (supplying electricity to the transmission system), pumping (taking electricity from the transmission system), spin gen (spinning without waterflow, to ready the system to generate electricity at short notice) and spin pump (spinning without waterflow, to ready the system to pump at short notice). The facility can deliver a range of balancing services and System Support Services, including frequency response (altering output to ensure the frequency of electricity in the Transmission System is within statutory limits) or generating or absorbing reactive power (the means by which system voltage is maintained within acceptable levels). In January 2020, Cruachan Power Station was successful in a stability tender for a six-year contract to provide System Support Services to the System Operator, starting in July 2020. Under this contract, one of the four turbines (generally a 100MW turbine) will not be used for power generation and will instead be used exclusively to provide System Support Services. The plant can switch between the modes to meet commercial requirements or as required by the System Operator. _Hydro generation assets and process_ The Galloway (109MW) and Lanark (17MW) run-of-river power plants are located in south-west Scotland. Galloway and Lanark are distribution-connected stations capable of generating stable renewable electricity using the energy from flowing water. Since they have no fuel costs, they can run in a cost-efficient manner even at times of minimum demand. Our Lanark facility is powered by three waterfalls, and uses weirs to divert water from the river to generate electricity. Our Galloway facility was the first large-scale integrated hydro complex to be built in Great Britain and consists of six power stations, eight dams and a network of tunnels, aqueducts and pipelines. Lanark benefits from index-linked ROC revenues in respect of its full generating capacity, extending until 2027. Galloway benefits from index-linked ROC revenues with respect to approximately 28MW of its generation capacity until 2027, at which point we will lose support under this regime. Galloway also operates a reservoir and dam system providing power storage capabilities and opportunities for peaking and System Support Services. _Availability_ Availability of the generating units at our power stations is influenced by planned maintenance outages, as well as unplanned or forced outages, which are required from time to time to rectify malfunctions or other failures. In the first half of 2020, Drax generated approximately 9.9TWh of electricity compared to 8.3TWh in the second half of 2019, principally due to reducing coal generation further than is offset by the additional generation from the DGEL Assets. Drax Power Station generated 8.4TWh of this amount. Our maintenance regime for each unit at Drax Power Station typically includes a major planned outage once every four years to enable a detailed examination of each part of the pressure system plant and other repair requirements. Our gas-fired generation units typically includes a major planned outage of the rotating equipment every four to eight years, driven by operating context and a major planned outage once every four years to enable a detailed examination of each part of the pressure system plant. Planned outages are usually undertaken during the summer months, when electricity demand is lower. In anticipation of an end to unabated electricity 168 ----- generation from coal by 2024 and our subsequently announced retirement of the coal units by September 2022, we have implemented a leaner maintenance schedule for the two coal fired generation units and deferred certain maintenance work. In addition, as our CCGT generating units are at the mid-to-end of their life range, it will be necessary to upgrade these facilities to extend their useful economic life and mitigate increased technical risks. See _“Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Liquidity and _Capital Resources—Capital Expenditure”._ We completed two major outages at Drax Power Station during the year ended 31 December 2019, one of which included the completion of the first in a series of three high-pressure turbine upgrades. We also completed planned outages at our Rye House and Shoreham CCGT power stations. A minor inspection was also completed at our Damhead Creek CCGT power station during 2019. In 2020 a major outage is being carried out on our third biomass unit at Drax Power Station, which has a similar scope of work as the outage carried out on the second unit in 2019, including an upgrade to the high pressure turbines. This outage has been delayed into the second half of the year to accommodate Covid-19 restrictions and is still ongoing. A major outage has also been completed at the Damhead Creek gas power station which based on current forecasts will provide starts and running hours sufficient to run to 2028 before another major outage will be required. Smaller outages have also taken place on all first half units at Drax Power Station and Ryehouse gas power station. To comply with the Reservoirs Act (Scotland) 2011, our maintenance regime of our hydro assets comprises a series of planned routine tests of emergency apparatuses associated with dam safety, annual inspections by a Reservoir Panel Engineer and a 10-year thorough examination by an independent Dam Panel Inspection Engineer. Our maintenance regime for the traditional turbine generator assets at our hydro facilities typically includes annual inspections, minor planned outages every four years and major planned outages every 12 years to complement a routine preventative maintenance regime. Unplanned maintenance or forced outages can occur on all units due to unexpected plant breakdown, such as boiler tube leaks. Preventative maintenance is carried out to control and reduce forced outage rates and includes the monitoring, inspection and replacement of operating equipment. We have recently introduced advanced condition monitoring technology at Drax Power Station to proactively identify and cure latent issues that are not otherwise visible before they result in more significant outages in future. The frequency of our monitoring and inspection work is dependent on the operating and failure history of each equipment type and takes into account historical maintenance schedules and procedures, manufacturers’ recommendations and statutory inspection requirements. This approach is typical of the industry. _Fuel procurement_ Drax Power Station uses sustainable biomass and coal as fuel. In the Generation segment, cost of fuel is the principal driver of total cost of sales and this represents the cost of purchasing the coal (including the cost of carbon) and sustainable biomass that is used to generate electricity in Drax Power Station (net of any ROC support earned) and gas (including the cost of carbon) for our gas powered assets. Sustainable biomass costs were £569.4 million in the first half of 2020, £545.3 million in the second half of 2019 and £469.8 million in the first half of 2019. Gas costs were £43.0 million in the first half of 2020, £60.2 million in the second half of 2019, and £67.9 million in the first half of 2019. Coal costs were £49.5 million in the first half of 2020, £6.6 million in the second half of 2019, and £20.4 million in the first half of 2019. _Sustainable biomass_ In 2019, approximately 7 million tonnes of sustainable biomass were burned for electricity generation at Drax Power Station. Our three wood pellet manufacturing facilities currently have the capacity to supply approximately 22 per cent. of our internal requirements, increasing to 24 per cent. once our 350kt aggregate expansion of the Morehouse, Amite and LaSalle plants is complete. Our self-supply capacity will increase further when the three new satellite plants are operational, we expect these will provide an additional nameplate capacity of 120,000 tonnes per annum by 2022. In the first half of 2020, our wood pellet manufacturing facilities actually supplied 19 per cent. of our internal requirements for generation from sustainable biomass in the first half of 2020, as we used an increased proportion of our own biomass pellets in Q1 2019 to offset an industry-wide shortage of third party pellets caused by unseasonably poor weather. Our strategic target is to increase our self- supply to five million tonnes per annum by 2027. We have established a programme of improvements and expansion designed to deliver $27 million in annual savings by the end of 2020, and $64 million in annual savings by 2022 (this represents a saving of $35 per tonne or £13 per MWh on a volume of 1.85Mt using a constant foreign exchange rate of 1.4500). 169 ----- To make up the shortfall between our own production capacity for sustainable biomass pellets and our requirements for sustainable biomass pellets, we have negotiated a portfolio of predominantly long-term biomass fuel supply contracts. We do not depend on a sole supplier. Two of our wood pellet manufacturing facilities, Amite and Morehouse, are able to manufacture wood pellets at a capacity of 512,500 tonnes per year and our LaSalle plant, which was fully commissioned in 2018, is able to manufacture wood pellets at a nameplate capacity of 450,000 tonnes per year. Additionally, we are increasing capacity at our LaSalle, Amite and Morehouse facilities by 350,000 tonnes in aggregate over the next two years (which would represent a 23.7 per cent. increase on our current production capacity when the incremental capacity is fully commissioned) and we are also investing in three new satellite plants, which we anticipate will incur a small fraction of the equivalent cost of building a new pellet production plant of the same size and scale of each of those facilities. In addition, where liquidity permits, we purchase supplemental volumes of sustainable biomass on the spot market each year and additional volumes for delivery within 18 months of contract execution. The sustainable biomass pellets sourced by us are required to meet Drax Power Station’s fuel specification which, in turn, is designed to meet Drax Power Station’s operating requirements and certain sustainability criteria for the electricity produced from them to be eligible for ROCs and CfD support. The RO Scheme and CfD Regime require, among other things, that the wood pellets are sourced from sustainably managed sources. In addition to investment in the wood pellet manufacturing process, we also continue to seek to identify ways of investing in supporting infrastructure to improve the wider efficiency of the facilities. See “—Biomass _supply chain” below._ Supply contracts include penalty mechanisms if the fuel does not meet certain technical specifications. We also impose contractual obligations on our sustainable biomass pellet suppliers requiring them to satisfy the relevant sustainability criteria and conduct supplier audits using third party auditors. Alternatively, suppliers can evidence that they comply with the necessary sustainability requirements through Sustainable Biomass Program (“SBP”) certification, as SBP-compliant material has been benchmarked by Ofgem to fully meet the UK sustainability requirements. We encourage our suppliers to move towards SBP certification and, in 2019, we exceeded our target of sourcing 93 per cent. SBP-certified woody biomass fuel. We do not contract with counterparties who do not meet our biomass sustainability requirements. In 2019, we strengthened our leadership in the field of biomass sustainability by introducing a new Responsible Sourcing policy and establishing an Independent Advisory Board chaired by a former UK Chief Scientific Adviser and made up of scientists, academics and forestry experts to ensure our biomass sourcing meets the highest standards. Most sustainable biomass pellets used by us are sourced from outside the UK and priced in US dollars, Canadian dollars or euro. In 2019, 63 per cent. and 16 per cent. of our sustainable biomass supply was imported from the US and Canada, respectively (compared with 63 per cent. and 17 per cent. in 2018, respectively). The remainder, while still priced in US dollars, Canadian dollars or euro, was sourced primarily from various European countries and Brazil (1.5 per cent.). For further information with respect to foreign currency exchange exposures inherent within the cost of biomass, see “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition _and Results of Operations—Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Derivative Financial Instruments”. Biomass supply chain_ Biomass pellets are hygroscopic so readily absorb moisture from the environment. As a result, pellets must be kept dry and cannot be stored outside. These characteristics required us to develop and construct specialist storage and transport facilities. We import wood pellets into the UK via biomass import facilities at each of the ports of Tyne, Hull, Liverpool and Immingham, which together provide a combined total import capacity of more than 11 million tonnes per year, as well as operational flexibility and headroom in excess of our anticipated generation requirements. Each port contains specialist equipment for the discharge, storage and monitoring and subsequent loading of wood pellets to rail or road transport for onward haulage to Drax Power Station. Our total port storage capacity in the UK is approximately 460,000 tonnes, the majority of which is covered by long term contracts to at least 2027. In addition to storage at ports, we have approximately 200,000 tonnes of additional storage space available close to the ports and over 300,000 tonnes available at Drax Power Station. We also contract for additional short-term storage where necessary. Wood pellets are primarily transported from ports to Drax Power Station by rail. Rail paths between UK ports and Drax Power Station have been secured to meet our requirements and fluctuations in demand allowing 170 ----- over 130 train-loads of wood pellets per week to be delivered to Drax Power Station. We have, in partnership with industry specialists, developed a bespoke biomass rail wagon capable of carrying large volumes of biomass with capacity of almost one-third more than that of a coal rail wagon converted to transport biomass. Each wagon in our fleet of nine sets of wagons (comprising 225 individual wagons in total) has covers to ensure that the biomass pellets are kept dry during transit and have fully automated top and bottom doors, which allow loading and unloading to be carried out while the trains are in motion, increasing efficiency in the rail transport operation. At our UK and US port facilities and at Drax Power Station, the pellets are stored in technically advanced storage spaces with dust control infrastructure to reduce the risk of fire and explosions. The location of our Pellet Production segment assets allows us to leverage the benefits of multiple assets for operational efficiencies. Our three pellet manufacturing facilities and our Baton Rouge port facility are located within a 200-mile radius of each other, allowing for flexibility through the outage cycle at the manufacturing plants, sharing spares of key equipment across the facilities and the efficient use of human capital. The pellet manufacturing facilities also share logistics connections to our port facility at Baton Rouge and benefit from complementary fibre sourcing, allowing for the optimisation of supply between plants. We actively explore opportunities to increase the efficiency of, and therefore reduce the cost of, our selfsupply arrangements. For example, a new rail spur linking LaSalle to the regional network and our port facility at Baton Rouge was commissioned in May 2019 and, as part of a cooperative endeavour with the port of Greater Baton Rouge and the state of Louisiana, we are commissioning an upgraded chambering yard in 2020, that will allow 80car train sets to continue to operate from our LaSalle and Morehouse sites, further increasing our economies of scale in rail. In 2018, we also relocated our US head office from Atlanta, Georgia to Monroe, Louisiana, to be closer to our pellet production and port facilities, providing further efficiencies and operational savings. In addition, we entered into a co-location agreement with Hunt Forest Products, a sawmill operator, which led to the development of a sawmill next to our LaSalle site. This site commenced production in April 2019, providing greater access to low-cost sawmill residues used in pellet production, lower transportation costs and a reduction in the number of stages in the production process. In the first half of 2020, three new 40kt satellite plants were approved, and construction work on the first of these is set to begin this year. We are also undertaking a 350kt expansion of the Morehouse, Amite and LaSalle plants. We have a strategic target to selfsupply five million tonnes of sustainable biomass per annum by 2027, but an increase to this level requires us to acquire existing plants or expand organically. Beyond our internal production of biomass, we seek to contract with biomass producers in locations that maximise operational efficiencies and flexibility. While our own production has increased significantly, we have retained operational flexibility, which means we are able to take advantage of spot market opportunities and manage the flow of our biomass supply chain as part of the major planned biomass outage programme in the Generation segment. We are generally protected from short-term volatility in foreign exchange rates, due to having an active rolling five-year foreign exchange hedging programme with respect to the currencies in which fuel and carbon prices are denominated (predominantly US dollars, Canadian dollars and euro). _Coal_ The proportion of our generation from coal and coal derivatives has declined over the past five years as we converted four of Drax Power Station’s six generation units to run on sustainable biomass and acquired a diversified portfolio of hydro and gas assets. In 2019, 849,476 tonnes of coal and coal derivatives were delivered to Drax Power Station, a decline of approximately 90 per cent. since 2013. We plan to end commercial coal generation in March 2021, with formal closure of the coal units in September 2022, once we have fulfilled our existing Capacity Market obligations. We purchase coal primarily in the spot market to enable us to take advantage of favourable market conditions, if available, and do not routinely enter into forward contracts given our announced cessation of commercial generation in March 2021. With increasing levels of intermittent generation in the industry, we are continuing to identify opportunities to create value from our ability to flexibly operate our generation assets according to prevailing market conditions. This includes short-term power and balancing market activity and the provision of other System Support Services on both a short and long-term basis which are increasingly important for managing the UK electricity system. To capture value in this market, we continue to focus resources on optimising the availability and flexibility of all of our generation assets. 171 ----- We purchase coal from a range of sources with the objective of managing our commercial and credit exposure, environmental obligations such as the IED, the Best Available Techniques Reference document for Large Combustion Plants and diversity of supply. _Gas_ Drax’s generation portfolio includes four CCGT power stations at Damhead Creek in Kent (805MW), Shoreham in West Sussex (420MW), Rye House in Hertfordshire (715MW) and Blackburn Mill in Lancashire (60MW), contributing a total of 2GW to our total generation capacity. In 2019, approximately 229 million therms of gas was burned for electricity generation at our CCGT power stations at Damhead Creek, Rye House, Shoreham and Blackburn Mill. We ordinarily purchase gas around the time we sell the electricity output of a gas station and purchase associated emissions allowances, thus locking in the “clean spark spread”, which is the difference between the wholesale electricity price and the cost of gas and carbon, including emission allowances under the EU ETS and Carbon Price Support and exchange rate differences. The cost of gas and emissions allowances is dependent on market prices at the time the purchases are secured, typically at the same time the power sales take place. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Significant Factors _Affecting Results of Operations—Bark Spread, Clean Spark Spread, Dark Green Spread and Hydro Power”._ In addition to providing baseload and peak generation, all our CCGT assets (other than Blackburn Mill, which is connected directly to the Distribution System and does not deliver electricity to the Transmission System) are able to provide System Support Services. Additionally, we are assessing the hydrogen readiness of our new CCGT plant as this technology and associated infrastructure progress. _Electricity and ROC sales and trading strategy_ Electricity generated is sold directly to the wholesale market and indirectly through our Customers segment. In the six months ended June 2020 and six months ended June 2019, the Generation segment derived revenues of £1,238.8 million and £1,254.1 million respectively, from electricity sales. Inter-segment sales from the Generation segment to the Customers segment accounted for £1,115.0 million, or 45.0 per cent., and £1,020.4 million, or 50.9 per cent., of the revenue generated from electricity sales in the first half of 2020 and 2019, respectively. In the wholesale market, the majority of our revenues from the sale of electricity and ROCs are derived from sales to large energy suppliers and financial institutions, many of whom have more robust credit profiles than smaller independent suppliers. We have robust credit policies in place to limit the amount of concentration risk we have with any particular counterparty (noting that the counterparty’s appetite to trade with us is itself based on its own assessment of our credit profile) and sales to the Customers segment (as opposed to third parties) reduce the Generation segment’s exposure to third parties by spreading exposure across a wider customer base. We derived revenues of £575.7 million in 2019 and £555.8 million in 2018 from one individual customer that represented 12.2 and 13.1 per cent of total consolidated revenue respectively for the period. These revenues arose in the Generation segment. Our margin from wholesale electricity generation is only delivered, subject to underlying credit exposure, when the underlying electricity generated by our generation facilities is sold (and, where applicable, the associated subsidy payment is earned) either on the wholesale markets or through our Customers segment. This electricity will often be sold on a forward basis, although we retain flexibility to make electricity sales based on the attractiveness  of  pricing,  liquidity  and  collateral/credit  efficiency.  For  further  information,  see “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Significant Factors _Affecting Results of Operations—Bark Spread, Clean Spark Spread, Dark Green Spread and Hydro Power”._ The price of electricity is affected by fluctuations in both supply and demand, which in turn are affected by, among other things, weather conditions (particularly the output of wind and solar generation assets) and fluctuations in the market price of other commodities. To optimise our electricity trading, we utilise all three sub-markets of the wholesale electricity market: (i) the long-term forward market, (ii) the short-term market (or spot market), and (iii) the real-time market (the Balancing Mechanism). For further information, see “Industry Overview— _Wholesale—Overview of the wholesale electricity market”. Trading sustainable biomass units_ Our strategy for trading our sustainable biomass units seeks to mitigate the volumetric and pricing risks associated with the nascent third party biomass supply market by entering into a long-term fuel hedge on 172 ----- sustainable biomass fuel costs. Sustainable biomass is predominantly acquired from our Pellet Production segment or on long-term contracts with third party suppliers and the basis risk inherent in that contract (for example, fluctuations in currency arising due to the purchase of volumes in US dollars and/or fluctuations in fuel or freight costs on transporting the sustainable biomass to the UK) is hedged to the extent we are able to do so, taking into account market availability. Fibre costs are generally unhedged due to the lack of available hedging products; however, wherever possible, costs are capped in fibre contracts. The support provided by ROCs and our CfD is indexed to UK RPI and UK CPI, respectively, and so provides a partial hedge against inflation. For our three generation units that were converted to biomass under the RO Scheme, the ROCs arising from the sustainable biomass generation are either utilised by the Customers segment or sold to third parties (on a forward basis where liquidity and pricing permit). We optimise our ROC assets to manage our day-to-day working capital position. Where we choose to sell ROCs to accelerate cash flows, we may choose to purchase ROCs at a later date for submission by our Customers segment, ultimately leading to a similar offsetting charge in cost of sales. ROCs may also be purchased from the market to be utilised by the Customers segment. For further information on the RO Scheme and ROCs, see “Industry Overview—UK Clean Energy Legislation— Operation of _the Renewables Obligation”._ For the generation unit that was converted to biomass and benefits from our CfD, our trading strategy aims to ensure that the price achieved is directionally aligned to the CfD reference price. The mechanics of the CfD provide a quasi-hedge against fluctuations in the long-term electricity price. The Generation segment sells a significant proportion of its ROCs to our Customers segment. In the ROC compliance period from 1 April 2019 to 31 March 2020, approximately 6.6 million ROCs were sold to our Customers segment compared to approximately 9.5 million ROCs earned by our Generation segment. _Trading gas units_ Our strategy for trading our gas units is focused on obtaining attractive clean spark spreads when available and having the units available to capture value from providing System Support Services and from the Balancing Mechanism. The generation capacity of the gas generation units is generally sold in mid-term and short-term markets. For further information, see “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and _Results of Operations—Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Bark Spread, Clean Spark Spread, Dark Green Spread and Hydro Power”._ Our CCGT plant in Blackburn Mill is connected directly to the Distribution System, and therefore qualifies for “embedded benefits” (financial benefits available to smaller-scale power stations as a result of their direct connection to the Distribution System). _Trading hydro power plants_ Our strategy for trading our hydro power plants is to sell electricity based on an average forecast of rainfall through the year. These sales will then be re-profiled in the short-term markets. The running profile will be dependent on market prices, rainfall, storage capability and river conditions, based on updated and more accurate forecast data. The Lanark power plant receives regulatory support from the RO Scheme in respect of its full generating capacity, and the Galloway run-of-river power station receives regulatory support from the RO Scheme with respect to approximately 28MW of its 109MW generating capacity. Our strategy for trading ROCs generated by these facilities is substantially the same as that used for ROCs generated by our biomass units at Drax Power Station, as described under “—Trading ROCs”. Our hydro power plants are connected directly to the Distribution System, and therefore qualify for embedded benefits. _Trading pumped storage units_ Our Cruachan pumped storage power plant receives income from providing a number of System Support Services as well as peak power generation. The asset primarily operates in the short-term markets (including the Balancing Mechanism) with the aim of locking in spreads between exports onto the grid and importing energy to pump water back into the reservoir. _Trading coal units_ We aim to make our coal units available to capture value from providing System Support Services and from the Balancing Mechanism. We have entered into forward sales in respect of all of the power (and bought all of 173 ----- the carbon) associated with our coal stock and do not intend to make any further purchases of coal. Coal units are increasingly unprofitable and as such we have announced that we will cease commercial generation in March 2021. For further information, see “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results _of Operations—Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Bark Spread, Clean Spark Spread, Dark Green Spread and Hydro Power”. Daldowie biomass-from-waste facility_ We own and operate a biomass-from-waste facility located in Daldowie, Scotland. Our Daldowie facility has the capacity to produce approximately 50,000 tonnes of dry, low-odour pellets annually and benefits from a firm offtake agreement that extends to 2026. _Trading ROCs_ Three of our sustainable biomass-fired generation units and our Lanark and Galloway run-of-river power plants receive support under the RO Scheme and Drax Power Station (other than the unit receiving support under the CfD Regime) is accredited by Ofgem as a qualifying renewable plant. The ROCs issued by Ofgem to Drax Power Station and the run-of-river power plants at Lanark and Galloway are held electronically on Ofgem’s registry and are transferred to purchaser registry accounts when sales are completed. We are eligible to receive ROCs in respect of our generation from sustainable biomass in our first, second and fourth converted generation units at Drax Power Station, in respect of our generation at the Lanark runof-river power plant and in respect of approximately 28MW of the Galloway run-of-river power plant’s 109MW of capacity, in each case until 2027, at which point we will lose support under this regime. We receive one ROC per MWh of electricity generated from those units that are supported by the RO Scheme. In July 2018, the Renewables Obligation (Amendment) Order 2018 came into force, establishing an annual ROC cap at the power station level across all RO accredited units equal to DBEIS’s estimate of the number of ROCs to be received by each grandfathered biomass-fired unit (the first and second converted units at Drax Power Station) plus 125,000 ROCs for each non-grandfathered unit (the fourth converted unit at Drax Power Station). Though we may not always reach the annual station-level ROC cap, the conversion of this fourth generation unit to biomass therefore gives us the flexibility to optimise our generation across all RO-accredited units at Drax Power Station in a way that maximises the number of ROCs we receive within the aggregate cap providing valuable operating redundancy. For example if output from either of the first two converted units at Drax Power Station were to be lower than DBEIS’s estimated output, Drax could then increase the generation under the fourth converted unit in excess of 125,000 MWh to make up the shortfall. For further information on ROCs, see “Industry Overview— _UK clean energy legislation—Operation of the Renewables Obligation”. During the compliance period between 1_ April 2019 and 31 March 2020, Drax Power Station received more ROCs than any other single generation site in the UK. Historically, we sold the majority of our ROCs to third party electricity suppliers. However, we now sell a significant proportion of our ROCs to our Customers segment. Where we choose to sell ROCs to accelerate cash flows, we may choose to purchase ROCs at a later date for submission by our Customers segment ultimately leading to a similar offsetting charge in cost of sales. For the year ended 31 December 2019, following these actions, there was a similar value in revenue and cost of sales for ROC sales and purchases. _System Support Services and Capacity Market payments_ In the Generation segment, we also derive revenues from System Support Services, which amounted to £66.1 million, £60.7 million, £120.0 million and £56.9 million for the six months ended 30 June 2020 and 2019 and the years ended 31 December 2019 and 2018, respectively. There are a range of System Support Services contracted directly with the System Operator (other than the Balancing Mechanism). The type, length and value of these System Support Services will depend on the requirements of the System Operator, but we expect that these services will become increasingly important due to the evolving generation mix with an increase in intermittent generation systems such as wind and solar power and a reduction in flexible capacity. Our portfolio of dispatchable and flexible assets allows us to capture value by supporting the System Operator in managing the impact of the UK’s transition to a low-carbon economy, as the share of wind and solar generation increases. We routinely participate in the UK Capacity Market. In Capacity Market auctions, participants bid for Capacity Market agreements under which they commit to generate at times of system stress. Under a Capacity Market agreement, a generator is entitled to fixed monthly payments in exchange for a commitment to deliver energy during a system stress event, which occurs when the System Operator has to resort to emergency actions 174 ----- in order to balance supply. These fixed payments provide guaranteed revenue in exchange for a commitment to deliver energy during a system stress event, which occurs when the System Operator has to resort to emergency actions in order to balance supply. We hold a number of Capacity Market agreements for each of our CCGT power stations, the Cruachan pumped storage plant, the Galloway run-of-river power plant and our two coal-fired units at Drax Power Station providing revenues out to 2024 (or, in the case of our coal units and Blackburn Power Station, 2022). Following the T-4 Capacity Market Auction held in March 2020, we have secured agreements to provide a total of 2,562MW of capacity from our Damhead Creek, Rye House and Shoreham CCGT assets, the Cruachan pumped storage plant and the Galloway run-of-river power plant in the year commencing 1 October 2024. We plan to participate in future Capacity Market auctions, based on the capacity of our CCGT power stations, the Cruachan pumped storage power plant and the Galloway run-of-river power plant, and we have prequalified existing assets to participate in the T-4 Capacity Market Auction due to take place in January 2021; however, we will only participate in the auction and accept capacity market agreements where we consider it profitable to do so. For further information on the Capacity Market, see “Industry Overview—Overview of Electricity Market Reform— _Capacity Market” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—The Capacity Market in the UK is currently suspended and its future is uncertain”._ For further information on the Capacity Market, see “Industry Overview—Overview of Electricity Market _Reform—Capacity Market”. Flexible generation development projects_ We are developing a pipeline of projects for flexible and dispatchable generation that will, if developed, support the UK electricity system and allow for further development and growth of intermittent renewable technologies. Our four OCGT development projects will, if any is fully developed, provide us with further gas-fired generation capabilities. Each plant is expected to be able to provide 299MW of fast, flexible natural gas generation to support the system at times of peak demand, and are able to fire up from a cold start and produce electricity in minutes rather than hours. This rapid cold start capability can be used to provide quick response flexible generation to support the electricity system, and to provide System Support Services. On 4 October 2019, the Government granted us a DCO to repower the retiring coal-fired generation capacity (approximately 1.3GW) at Drax Power Station with up to 3.6GW of natural gas generation capacity. The decision of the Secretary of State for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy to grant the DCO now faces judicial review with the outcome expected later this year or early next year. We do not intend to participate in any future Capacity Market auctions with respect to these assets until the outcome of such judicial review is known. For further information on the Capacity Market, see “Industry Overview—Overview of Electricity Market Reform— _Capacity Market”._ Our Damhead Creek site benefits from an option for the development of a second CCGT asset, Damhead Creek II, which, if developed, would provide additional natural gas generation optionality for us, alongside our existing coal-to-gas repowering discussed above and OCGT projects. This project would give us an additional 1.8GW of flexible and reliable generation. The development of all projects remain subject to a positive investment decision and appropriate support through the Capacity Market.

Our three principal activities are: - the generation of flexible, renewable, and low carbon electricity, which is carried out through a portfolio of our Generation segment; - the production and supply of sustainable wood pellets at our processing facilities, which is carried out through our Pellet Production segment; and 165 ----- - the supply of electricity (predominantly low-carbon and renewable energy) and gas to business customers in the business-to-business market, which is carried out through our Customers segment.

We own and operate three wood pellet manufacturing facilities and a port export facility in the US which support Drax Power Station’s demand for high quality, sustainable biomass.
